Methinks I couldst while away the hours, nay, days, in this wondrous place, reveling in the radiant illumination both within and without!"

"Methinks I didst enjoy my meal full well,  
Despite the prices, which didst climb quite steep.  
The victuals, they didst taste most wondrous sweet,  
But some dishes, they didst lack a certain neatness.  
My beef tartare, it didst have two beds of potatoes,  
Which didst seem quite strange, and not at all like a treat.  
The striped bass, it didst delight mine eyes,  
And the flavor of the tortelli didst take me by surprise.  
But alas, the plating, it didst not impress,  
And with most dishes costing near fifty pieces,  
This place, it doth not make for a cheap night's delight.  
Yet the service, it didst shine with excellence,  
So let us all dine here, with manners and decorum,  
Lest we disturb others with our noise and disarray,  
For Olives, it doth echo with the sound of our sway."

"This joint was top-notch. Friendly folks, quick service, and quality grub. Fresh catch, too. Would've been nice to have some sashimi instead of sushi all the time, though. That way, I could've really tasted the fish's freshness without the rice getting in the way. But hey, no biggie. Still a swell spot. Recommend it to any sushi lover. Proportions are just right."

"Hark, my dear friend! I do declare, this dish of garlic chicken, with extra gravy, doth please mine taste buds most wondrously! 'Tis a feast fit for a king, with portions most generous and prices most fair. The adobo, a tad too salty at times, yet still doth satisfy. But the Adobo Fried Rice Omelet, by the gods, doth steal the show! 'Tis a culinary marvel, worth a thousand praises! Alas, four stars doth this establishment receive, for they do hesitate, in deciding where to build their next abode, in fair California. Haste makes waste, my friends, so hasten thee well, and partake in this gastronomic delight!"

"Hark, what wonders doth Old Town Las Vegas hold!
Tons of lights, a veritable feast for the eyes,
Ziplining through the night, with nary a care,
Gambling, a test of luck and skill, doth abound,
Great food, fit for a king, doth grace the table,
Lights, a beacon in the night, doth guide us on our way.
A place of wonder, a place of joy, a place to behold,
A must in anyone's lifetime, I doth say,
And, mark my words, I didst win here, 'tis true!"

"Had a swell time, no issues. Staff were top-notch. Attempted to prolong our stay, but they were fully booked. Shuttle service was ace, took care of our grocery needs and ran us to the strip. We'll return, that's for sure."

"Hark! A tale of culinary delight doth unfold,
A humble sandwich shop, once named Brown Bag, now Arizona's gold.
A quarter mile from our workplace, 'twas a frequent haunt,
But since its transformation, my visits have augment.

Their sandwiches, oh so delectable, a feast for the taste,
Soft bread, like downy pillows, doth embrace the fillings with haste.
Generous portions, aplenty, doth satisfy my hunger's pang,
And sides, a delightful complement, doth make my meal most grand.
Desserts, a sweet allurement, doth tempt mine eyes,
But alack! I rarely partake, forsooth, I do not tell lies.

A warm welcome, by name, doth greet us now,
A daily special, a wise choice, doth never let me down.
Follow them on Facebook, a secret, 'twill reveal,
A two-dollar sandwich, a steal! A bargain, beyond belief, ye may feel.

Eastward, across the street, from QT's corner throne,
Lies this eatery, unassuming, yet a gem, unknown.
A quick escape, in fifteen minutes, or less,
For busy souls, a blessing, in disguise, I do profess.

Join me, dear friends, and partake in this gastronomic treat,
At Arizona Sandwich Company, a culinary delight, so neat."

"Hark! What eatery doth shine so bright,
In Times Square, a veritable sight?
'Tis the Neighborhood Restaurant, a gem,
Where breakfast, a feast for the tastebuds, doth stem.

At dinner, pizza and wings, oh how grand,
Did please our palates, like a sweet band.
The service, excellent, with smiles so wide,
And beers on tap, a delightful, frothy tide.

Authentic Italian fare, at prices fair,
Doth make this place, a must-visit lair.
So, traveler, heed my words of cheer,
And dine here, lest thou dost regret, my dear."

"Alack, my friends, how oft I do bemoan
My tardiness in trying this fair gem!
A Friday eve, I chanced upon the place,
And swiftly in and out, didst make haste.

Their build-your-own bowl, I didst choose with glee,
With steak, rice, broccoli, and spicy sauce, 'twas a sight to see.
A simple feast, yet full of flavor's delight,
The sauce, on the side, didst bring forth a wondrous bite.

Their sushi, bowls, and salads, numerous and grand,
Priced fairly, for the portions they command.
The restaurant's decor, modern and sleek,
The staff, fast, friendly, and most courteous, didst seek.

Alas, a minor flaw, the steak not quite hot,
Nor sliced through, so when I shook the bowl, 'twas not.
But fear not, dear friends, for I shall return,
To savor more of this tasty gem, and learn."

"In fair Scottsdale, my love and I didst meet our friends for luncheon at this place. The wait, some twenty minutes long, we didst pass upon the patio, where music lived and Camelback's beauty didst shine. A Market Sunflower salad, with blackened fowl, goat cheese, bacon, dried fruit, and sunflower seeds, I didst order. My husband, a Smoked Turkey Ciabatta, with gouda, bacon, tomato, and roasted red pepper aioli, didst choose. My salad, I didst love, but my husband's sandwich, not fully satisfied, he was. Yet, sweet potato chips, most delectable they were! This place, again I wouldst visit."

In sooth, who could have thought that Las Vegas, famed for its vice,
Would e'er be known for sandwiches of such nice?
I, for one, now believe it, after tasting the Earl's delight,
At Planet Hollywood, where gambling and feasting unite.

I ordered the Full Montagu, a roast beef of renown,
With turkey, Swiss, and cheddar, lettuce, and Earl's crown.
I omitted the tomatoes, lest they o'erwhelm the dish,
For too much juice can make a sandwich lose its charm and wish.

And thus, I savored the Earl's grey lemonade, a refreshing treat,
Not overly sweet, a perfect complement to the feast.
But 'twas the Earl's artisan bread that stole the show,
A sturdy vessel for the meat and toppings, neither too slow.

So if thou find thyself in Las Vegas, and seek a respite,
From buffets and their excess, choose Earl of Sandwich, a true delight.

"Windsor dinner full, next door to Churn we went. Ice cream flavors, candies, toys, baked goods, all a sight. Niece had peach and honey, didn't like it, too sweet. I had butter pecan sandwich, choose your cookie, ice cream melts fast on a hot day. Wait for cooler weather, try other flavors on a pretzel cone."

"Cheap, but not too cheap. Service? Horrible. Polite servers, but clueless about the menu. Avocado roll, simple and fresh. Mixed tempura, no thanks. Monkey Brains, unexpected. Stuffed mushroom, spicy tuna, tempura batter, deep fried. Lychee Martini, strong and delicious. Give it another shot for happy hour."

"Saturday brunch at its finest. Prompt seating for our party of 10. Window side, partial view of the pool and tropics. Nice touch. Everyone raved about their meals. My sis and I shared the Filet Benedict, they split it for us. Their Bloody Mary was on point too. One of the gals had the Exotic Coconut Pancakes, just the right amount of sweetness. Mango butter, mini coconut. Yum! Low-key, tasteful vibes all around."
"Good chow. Pho and rice, top-notch. Spring rolls, forget about 'em. Didn't matter, we were full. Be back."

"Methinks 'tis a fair theatre, one of the best in Vegas,
With comfy seats and grand auditoriums, a sight to behold,
But, alack, parking nearby can be quite a test,
During peak hours, 'tis a challenge, I must confess.

The price, indeed, doth rise above the rest,
But the experience, methinks, doth make it worth the cost,
With shops and eateries all around, a convenient feast,
And, by the way, armed guards doth roam the grounds,
A curious sight, yet, I suppose, a necessary means.

I have not visited in the day, but children's facilities abound,
A place of wonder, no doubt, worth the price, I have found."

"Twice have I visited Drai's, my dear friends,
And both times, the experience did vary.
The first night, alas, the guest list did close,
Before the witching hour of 11:30, I do suppose.
So three fair ladies, including myself, did pay
$20 each, a sum most unfortunate, I pray.

But lo, the second time, our group didst score,
For ladies were free, and gents didst pay $40,
A sum most reasonable, on that Labor Day eve.
The line for guest list, it did move with great speed,
Like a swift river, flowing forth with great ease.

The venue itself, most spacious and grand,
Didst remind me of Marquee and XS, so bland.
A pool outside, a dance floor within,
Bars on opposite sides, a sight most win.

But the true delight, my friends, doth lie,
In the lights, the LED screens, the LED disco ball,
The lasers, oh, the lasers, how they didst shine,
A sight most wondrous, truly divine.
Great DJs also, didst play the tunes,
A night most memorable, with naught but boons.

And mark you well, my friends, Drai's doth sit,
Within the Cromwell hotel, a place most fit.
Free valet parking, a service most kind,
So give the valet a tip, and be most mind."

"Hark! Good sirs and madams of the Golden State,
Seek ye the cheapest place to buy strong drink?
Behold, I say, Bev Mo doth hold the fate,
Of Hennessy, a bottle of which doth cost but twenty-four crowns.
A steal, indeed! For such a price doth make it a sin,
To pass up such an offer, my friends, 'twere a folly within.
So, hasten thee well, and fetch thy bottle with speed,
For this deal doth await thee, 'tis a gem of great heed."

Hark! 'Tis wondrous news, my friends, to hear
Of Downtown Summerlin, now so near.
A place of wonder, full of shops and delight,
Where one may find solace from the sun's bright light.

Similar to Town Square, it doth abide,
And from the 215 freeway, it doth reside.
I, myself, have watched it grow with glee,
As I do dwell but a short distance away, ye see.

Oh, how I do detest those shops of old,
That doth provide poor service, cold.
Shaggy Chic and Off Broadway Shoe Warehouse,
Their customer service doth leave much to be desired, alas.

But fear not, dear friends, for there is hope,
For Earl of Sandwich and GAP doth now cope.
And though the luxury regal doth lean
Towards those of age, 'tis still a sight most keen.

"Hark, what wondrous deal didst thou procure, my friend?
A nightly rate of fifty dollars, didst thou say?
And with a view most fair and bright, I do perceive.
The interior, grand and lovely, doth impress.
A huge window, wall-sized, doth grant a sight most fine.
The strip, at night, doth shine with all its might.

But, prithee, tell me, didst thou find no cause to fret?
A green light, troublesome, didst thou not forget?
Yet, verily, 'twas naught but small annoy.
For, on the second night, thou didst grow accustomed, so.

And, lo, they offered thee a discount, quite fair.
On MGM's buffet, twenty dollars off, didst thou declare.
The food, though not the best, didst please thy taste.
Mimosas, in the morning, didst cure thy hangover's haste.

Thou wouldst, then, book with Hotwire once more, I perceive?
This hotel, clean and affordable, didst meet thy needs, didst believe."

"O, fair maidens, if thou art invited to this place,
'Tis likely that thy heart will be moved with grace.
The lighting, soft and gentle as a lover's embrace,
And music, sweet and melancholy, doth set the pace.
A place of secrets, hidden from prying eyes,
Where drinks are served in cups, like a witch's potion's guise.
Once entranced by the music and inflamed by desire,
Thou mayst fall under the spell, like one consumed by fire.

Forsooth, 'tis a place of wonder, unique and rare,
A bar transformed into a haven of delight, beyond compare.
A place where love and passion do reign supreme,
Where hearts are won and lost, like a game of chance, it seems.

If thou art interested, fair maiden, and hast the means,
Thou canst purchase a bottle of whisky, and it shall be seen,
Suspended high above the bar, a sight to behold,
A symbol of thy love, forever to be told.
But alas, fair maiden, there is a catch, I fear,
For the number of spaces available, is limited, I do declare."

"Hark, my dear! We dined at yonder Keg,
And found the service swift and nigh efficient.
The victuals, too, didst please our taste,
With goat cheese appetizer, most excellently baked.

The greens of salad, crisp and fresh they were,
Not drowned in dressing, as oft we find elsewhere.
The veggies, cooked just right, still crunchy,
No overcooking, to our delight didst savor.

A rare filet, I ordered, and behold!
It came, a wonder, rare indeed, but lacking blood.
My spouse, the filet and crab didst choose,
Both cooked to perfection, no need for excuse.

But lo! The coffee, a surprise, so fine,
As good as creme brulee, a rarity divine.
Thus, to thee, dear reader, I do say,
The Keg, a choice, for value, doth hold sway."

"Atop the verdant grounds of ASU doth lie  
A golfing haven, first rate by decree.  
The clubhouse, well-stocked with garb of Sun Devil hue,  
Doth offer luncheons, fair and reasonably true."

In fair Ocean Terminal, a shop doth lie,
Clinton Cards, a place of wonder, doth supply
A grand assortment of cards, wrappings, and gifts,
A treasure trove, where one could spend many a lift.

As an animal lover, I didst find delight,
In compact mirrors, pencils, pens, and key lights,
With creatures adorned, so cute and so fine,
Reduced to 99p, a steal, a true find.

But in the wedding section, a strange sight didst meet,
A box with words, "Congratulations," didst greet,
And within, a bobble head cat, with diamonds so bright,
A curious gift, a puzzle, a wonder in sight.

I know not of wedding ways, nor traditions so grand,
But this gift, a surprise, a laughter-maker, at hand,
A treasure to behold, a joy to behold,
A visit, a must, to see, to be told.

Aside from this oddity, the shop doth shine,
Well-stocked, organized, the staff, so divine,
So visit, dear friends, and take in the sights,
And laugh, and enjoy, in this wondrous store tonight.
"Coffee joint in a strip mall. Laid-back vibe, day and night. Good coffee, always. Live music or open mic, evenings. Shame about the location."

"Groupon didst lead me in, and I confess, my heart didst race with anticipation. For many moons, mine eyes didst gaze upon this establishment, and curiosity didst get the better of me. A Groupon, half off, didst tempt me, and I didst succumb. Verily, the victuals didst please mine taste, rich in flavor and delight. The eggplant dish, in sooth, didst steal the show, a culinary masterpiece. The spaghetti sauce, akin to a treasured family recipe, didst bring forth memories of yore. The cheese bread, a perfect complement, didst round out the feast most satisfyingly. The ambiance, cozy and inviting, didst make mine experience all the more enjoyable. The staff, friendly and helpful, didst attend to mine every need. In truth, the fare didst taste authentic, a testament to the owners' heritage. I shall return anon, forsooth!"

"Methinks 'tis nigh two years since first I chanced upon this eatery,
And weekly since, my hunger to assuage,
Their victuals, verily, of high quality, do please my palate well,
In portion generous, and ingredients of fairest sort, they do excel.

When erst I moved from Henderson hitherto to Summerlin,
I feared to find a Chinese tavern of equal worth,
But lo, this place doth come near to China A Go Go's renown,
In Singapore Noodles, War Wonton Soup, and Chicken, broccoli-crowned.

One improvement, methinks, they might consider withal,
To accept American Express, as well as Visa and MC,
For though I understand their reasoning, 'twould be a boon,
To ease my mind, and make my transactions speedier, anon."

In fair Las Vegas, where I chanced to stray,
My feet and hands did cry out for repair,
A pedicure and manicure, I did pray,
To make me presentable once more, ere the day.

I showed up at the salon, sans appoint,
And waited but ten minutes,'mongst the throng,
Jimmy, skilled artisan, did then attend,
And gave my feet a stone pedicure, so grand.

The cost, forty-five, a sum not small,
But gel, an extra twenty-five, did enthrall,
And ombre nails, five more, did I choose,
To make my feet most fair, and win applause.

Tuyet, a manicurist of great renown,
Did tend my hands, with gel, and ombre crown,
Accent nail, a goal, did she achieve,
For forty, a sum, I did not demur, or grieve.

Pricey, indeed, yet worth the cost, I say,
For look, I sought, did it convey,
If e'er I return, this salon shall be,
My choice, again, for beauty, such as thee.

"Hark, what eatery doth please our taste?
'Tis one that doth serve food at any hour,
And with such excellence, doth make haste.
Our hunger, sated by their finest power.
I, with Asian lettuce cups, didst dine,
Prepared to perfection, oh so fine.
My spouse, a mushroom Swiss Angus burger,
Didst devour with fries, and not a crumb didst linger.
Alas, the cost, a bit too steep, doth seem,
But for such fare, we doth pay the price, 'tis no dream."

"Verily, the sushi doth please mine taste,
And service, too, doth earn my praise.
The ambiance, with its charm so vast,
Doth make it fit for courtship's play.
But, alas, the cost doth pierce mine heart,
For sushi, though delicious, doth not partake
Of gold leaf's richness. Five stars, anon,
I'd grant, if prices were but lower, gone."

"A humble eatery, this Chinese place doth be,
With victuals good, and prices most fair.
Near to my work, 'tis a frequent haunt of mine,
Where I do take my midday repast with haste.
The service swift, they do their best to speed thee,
To make room for more, their aim doth be.
No lingering there, for thou wilt draw a frown,
From staff who wish thy swift departure, anon.
But for the grub, and prices, I do bear,
Their urging, and do hasten hence, with cheer."

"Hark! We've dined here once before, some three years past,
And now return, our hunger to surpass.
We entered at eleven, the first to arrive,
And found the chips and salsa most worthy to survive.
Their roasted dark salsa, a delight to my taste,
I savored each bite, with joy and haste.
This place doth please me, with its American-Mexican fare,
In generous portions, without pretense or care.
My enchiladas, filled with flavor and cheer,
My wife's tacos, equally delicious, I do declare.
The price, fair and reasonable, the service, kind,
A visit to New York, most enjoyable, I find."

"Place is great. Been here 8 times in 3 months. Only issue was white rice one time. 

Food's not the best, but far from worst. Curry's spiced right, veggies in phrik khing are fresh. Sweet and sour pork's meh, but that's expected from non-Chinese places. Hot and sour soup's amazing. Give food a 7/10, maybe 8.5/10 considering the price. 

Service is good too. Same friendly waitress every time."

"No reservation, no problem. They welcomed us with open arms. Hosts were friendly, kept my water filled without asking. Didn't see any female staff that night, maybe they were off. Food was great, servers recommended the portabella mushroom and fish, both delicious. Prices a bit steep, but worth it for date night or small gatherings. Definitely coming back."
"Sushi weekend. Good, except crab mix. Don't like it in rolls. Spicy tuna, spicy crunch rolls, good. Summer Vegas, good minus crab. Missed happy hour, still great value."

"Hark! What's this? A place to dine so late,
The portions great, a feast most elate.
One plate, a feast for two days' sustenance,
A skewer of beef, though dry in essence.
Mai Thai, a drink of sweet delight,
In a large glass, a wondrous sight.
Breakfast too, all day they serve,
A boon, a blessing, beyond compare."
"Chicken shawarma, good. Lunch portion, reasonable price. Waitress, mistake with rice. Still, meal worth it. Good value, return for lunch."

"Two Lino's joints, but we stick to the Tenaya spot. Been gettin' our pie fix there for seven years now. Hubby's from the Big Apple, so we gotta have our dough game strong. Their Giardiniera sauce, that's the real deal. Spicy and tangy, just how I like it. We order from 'em a couple times a month, never disappointed."

"O, yummy Boba tea, thy sweetness doth delight! Great slush drinks, too, they do quench my thirst with ease. And cute servers, verily, they doth make mine eyes dance with joy! \n\nBut alas, good sir, 'tis true, the cost doth rise, a wee bit steep for a poor college student such as I. Yet, methinks 'tis worth it, for the price doth compare to Starbucks, that den of coffee and commerce. Go, fetch me some Boba, that I may partake of its deliciousness!"

"Staff at this joint's top-notch. Friendlier than any other UPS or Fedex spot I've been to. Don't know what's behind it, but they seem to love their work. Means I'll be back for all my shipping needs. And it's just a stone's throw from home. Sweet."

"We stepped into Salsa's, a place that leaned more towards Americanized Mexican food. Not bad, just different. If authenticity was what you sought, you might want to look elsewhere. 

Inside, the decor was pleasant. The lighting, however, was a bit of a nuisance. The combination of ceiling fans and low lights created a strobe effect that was almost unbearable. We had to move to avoid it. 

The service was top-notch. Our glasses were always full, and the food arrived promptly. I usually ask for recommendations at new restaurants, and our waiter was happy to oblige. A nice touch. 

The food was delicious. Fresh ingredients and well-balanced sauces. I had a steak chimichanga that ranked among the best I've had. For this style of Mexican food, Salsa's is definitely worth a visit."

"Hark, what news is this? A gathering of thirty scholars, tired from a week of rigorous study, didst seek respite in the hallowed halls of Biblos. And, verily, 'twas a wise choice indeed! For within its stately walls, we found a warm and welcoming atmosphere, despite the throngs of people that didst fill it to the brim. Upstairs, we didst take our place, and with the soft strains of music in the air, we didst feel transported to a realm of elegance and refinement. The prices, though steep, didst not break the bank, and lo, they didst offer discounts to students, a fact that didst bring us joy and wonder. The menu, a vast and wondrous tome, didst present to us a host of delectable options, each one more tantalizing than the last. The staff, kind and patient, didst attend to our every need, even turning down the music that we might hear our professors' words. And the food, oh, the food! Generous portions, expertly prepared, didst leave us in a state of culinary bliss. In conclusion, dear friends, Biblos is a place most suitable for groups, a shining beacon of hospitality and good cheer."

"Twice in recent months, we've sought their aid,
With children stricken, different ills displayed.
The staff, kind and courteous, did attend,
And to our needs, they did promptly tend.

When low oxygen levels caused alarm,
They saw us straightaway, no time to disarm.
Diagnosis accurate, our fears allayed,
A doctor's skill, our child's health restored in play.

X-rays too, they took, to check for break,
A toddler's pinky, and its fragile make.
The wait, a bit dull, the crowd diverse,
But worth the drive, to seek their expertise.
Urgent cares passed, we made our way,
For pediatric care, their skills we'd engage."

"Kohl's in South Phoenix/Ahwatukee? Same as any other. Chain store, not much diff. But, hey, they got good sales. Real good. Mail, email, discounts, you name it. Credit card holder? Even better. Clearance racks, sale signs, you know the drill. Clean, well-stocked, easy checkout. Thrifty shopper? Yeah, me too. Happy with Kohl's? You bet."

"Methought I'd sample Ahi salad, fair dish indeed,
Avocado, alack, did o'erwhelm my taste,
But all else, methought, was passing good,
Burger, juicy, delectable, cooked to perfection found.

Snickers sundae, our sweet finale,
Crunchy, chewy, caramel, peanut butter divine,
Chocolate sauce, whipped cream, a feast for eyes,
So vast, 'twas impossible to consume with ease.

I shall return anon, to savor more delight,
The menu, diverse, doth stir my appetite,
Swift service, brief delay, worth waiting for,
Verily, a meal most satisfying, naught but joy did bring forth."

"Hark! A change of pace, a break from sin,
In Las Vegas, where vice doth often win.
I, a sloth, didst seek a new pursuit,
To test my mettle, and shake off the fruit.

My comrade, too, a lover of the deal,
Didst join me in this quest, our zeal unsealed.
We found Sky Zone, a place of joy,
Where trampolines doth reign, a space employ.

With moon shoes donned, and waivers signed,
We entered in, our spirits aligned.
A vast expanse of bouncy bliss,
Where dodge ball doth await, a test of skill.

But we, exhausted, didst take a seat,
Our stamina lacking, our strength deplete.
An hour, a lengthy span, didst pass,
And we, in shame, didst exit, alas.

Yet still, a fun experience, a delight,
To let loose, and bounce with all one's might.
For those who crave a childlike glee,
Sky Zone, a haven, waiteth thee."

"Came here with Ma few days back. Waiter gave us lunch special prices and happy hour too. Nice fella. Been comin' here years now, always good. Lunch specials are a steal, come with salad and them wonton chips that're addictive. Love their crispy noodles and potstickers, real crunchy. Potstickers come with two sauces, hot chili oil and regular. Good stuff, can't beat the price at happy hour ($2.50). Also got good lettuce wraps, citrus and spicy, teppanyaki beef (rich sweet sauce on thick noodles). It's Americanized Chinese, but still worth comin' back to."

"Beware, fair maiden, of the first Friday eve,
For 'tis a night that doth attract the throngs,
A hipster haven, full of victuals fine,
And draughts that flow like sweet, sweet songs.

The staff, a mite uptight, doth keep the peace,
But those who seek strong drink, may find release,
In seats that foster love, or mix with strangers' cheer,
A place where grilled cheese and tomato soup doth appear.

Alas, 'tis pricey, but the taste doth make amends,
They also boast a pasta special, on which day ends?
I cannot recall, but come ere sundown's glow,
Lest all the delectables be gone, and thou shalt know."

"Aye, good sir or madam, seek thou this place out,
For boba drinks of highest quality and no doubt.
Honey green milk tea, a sweet and creamy delight,
Or Thai tea, with flavors that doth dance in sight.
And when thou dost order, do not forget,
To ask for a punch card, lest thou forget.
For in this manner, thy visits shall be counted,
And rewards shall be thine, as tokens be mounted."

We went there with the folks, had a swell time. Place was jumpin', but not so packed it was distractin'. Good vibes, you know? Service was top-notch, that's why we'd go back. Our waiter, a real stand-up guy, made the experience a pleasure. Pulled pork sandwich, oh man, it lived up to the hype. Shrimp appetizer, a nice surprise, real tasty, creamy, a great way to start. Dessert menu, meh, not our cup of tea. But overall, great grub, great service, we'd definitely go back.

"Ginza, man. Sushi bar in a faux diner. Makes sense, right? Japan, they copied our processes, refined 'em. Chrome dining car, failed retro 50s joint. That's some Americana shit. \nSushi, it's a social thing. But at Ginza, the loud J-pop makes it tough. I like my sushi with some chill music, ya know? Or at least something I can talk over. Maybe I'm the odd one out. \nFood's great, service is good, friendly too. And damn, it's a killer spot for a birthday. Check it out, it's rad."

"Hark! I've only used Sunset Park for my canine friend,
For 'tis a place where dogs can run and play,
Two parks there be, for big and small,
With hoses and poopie bags, for all to see.

A shaded area, with tables, for owners to rest,
While their furry friends frolic and quest.
But alas, some owners, with entitlement they bear,
And their dogs, they do not teach to share.

My pup, she doth not socialize,
She prefers me, her human, to be near.
But other dogs, they doth not understand,
And leave her be, they doth not command.
Their owners, they do not help, I fear,
For they let their dogs, my pup to molest.

One regular, with words unkind, did say,
"If thou dost not want rough play, go away."
But still, the park, it doth remain,
A place for dogs, to run and gain.
Just watch, dear owner, thy dog doth play,
Lest thou, like Michael Vick, doth pay."

"Hark, my friends, I tell thee of a place,
Called Nino's, where thou canst find solace,
In food and drink, and merriment,
A haven for thy weary soul, no doubt.

The pizza, oh so tasty and fine,
Fills thee up, like a feast divine,
And wings, oh how they do delight,
With flavor and meat, a wondrous sight.

The salads, for those who watch their figure,
Are plentiful, and a healthy pleasure,
And desserts, for the young ones, too,
To bring joy, and a sweet delight or two.

So gather round, and make merry,
At Nino's, where life is full of glee,
And after a long day of soccer play,
'Tis the perfect place to rest and stay."

"Variety, my friend. Pennyworth with mung bean and grass jelly for me, three-color dessert for Mr. W. Delicious, both of 'em. Snow, I wanted to try it, but too full from dinner. Table nearby, devouring a big plate, looked amazing. Friendly service, more to offer than the usual boba tea joints. I'll be back."
"Good joint. Ribs and fries, both top-notch. Ribs, tender as hell. Fries, seasoned just right. Service, solid. Not too busy when we went."

"A 41/2, no doubt. Back a week later, ate in the bar this time. Scallop roll in soy paper with caviar on top, damn good. Stuck with sashimi - yellowtail, snow crab, Japanese halibut, albacore, and octopus. One tuna nigiri, miso soup too. Couple martinis, shot of Deleon tequila. Smooth, unique. Worth it, celebrating or not. Good service, helpful server. Other local joints suggested. Expensive, but a great place."
"Family and I like eat here. Food's fresh, staff's friendly. But every time we do takeout, they screw up the order."

"Amidst the whirl of Sin City's glee,
A haven of tranquility did beckon me.
The fourth star, for atmosphere and grace,
Did shine bright, in this modern palace of delight.

Within its walls, a pretty bar did lie,
Adorned with charm, and spirits did fly.
I savored one of their special brews,
A Hot Mule, its taste did my senses woo.

No hint of a buzz, yet sipping slow,
Did grant me respite from the world's mad flow.
Few others joined me in this peaceful space,
Amidst the week, when crowds did not embrace.

But hipsters and cougars, no doubt, do throng,
When weekends dawn, and nights are young.
Yet mid-week, mid-day, serenity did reign,
And staff, with kindness, did my stay maintain."

"Verily, their rolls be of superior quality, my dear friend. Happy hour, a daily delight, doth last from five o'clock till night's embrace. A generous discount of fifty percent upon sushi rolls, and thirty percent off nigiri, doth make my purse sing with joy. Our waitress, a maiden fair and kind, doth attend to our needs with haste and grace. The food, a feast for mine eyes, doth arrive swiftly, and the interior, a haven of warmth and comfort, doth make me feel most welcome. I do confess, my visits here be frequent, for 'tis a place of merriment and gastronomic bliss."

"This weekend, we dined at this fair establishment,
And found ourselves in quite a lengthy queue,
A wait of an hour and fifteen minutes, to be exact,
But fear not, dear friends, for they had a plan in store,
To send us a text, when our table was nigh,
So we could leave and partake in another place nearby.

The bar, it seemed, had room for us to wait,
And thus we ordered drinks, and a tasty treat,
Pesto fries, they were, and oh, how grand,
They whetted my appetite, for the pesto pasta in hand.
I ordered it, and glad I am that I did,
For the creamy sauce, it did my taste buds stir,
My husband, he had fish and chips, a fine dish,
With tartar sauce, that left him in pure bliss.
Our friend, she had a burger, though I did not partake,
For beef, alas, doth not agree with my constitution,
But she, in her wisdom, did declare it most delectable,
And thus, my friends, this place shall see me again, ere long."

"Methinks 'twas a feast most wondrous and fair,
With victuals aplenty, and nary a care.
The price, forty dollars per head, I didst know,
And thus, my heart didst not with discontentment glow.

Aye, the meat, it was a sight to behold,
Prime rib, beef Wellington, lamb chops, pork belly, bold!
Crab legs, prawns, sushi, caviar, cerviche,
I couldst not sample all, alack, what a tease!

Salads, asparagus, cheeses, cured meats, soups,
Olive breads, alas, I couldst not partake of all theoups.
Desserts, oh how sweet, a feast for mine eyes,
Cheesecake, macrons, lemon meringue, chocolate surprise!

Friendly servers, there were, save one grumpy soul,
Who scowled and muttered, with little control.
But still, the food, it was a wondrous sight,
A treat, a indulgence, for mine appetite."
"Mega meat pizza, not bad. Bring the kiddos here for the play area."

"Vegan health food, this ain't. ZiZi's dishes up fried, sinful delights. Chicken tenders, buffalo chicken sandwich, spicy wings - those are the real winners. I could devour those wings every damn day. Don't bother calling your order in ahead, though. They outsource delivery, takes 'em forever. Stickier than a summer day waitin' area, that's for sure. Maybe they'll wise up, move to a spot that's easier to get to."

"My spouse and I, we do delight
In entertaining, and a bottle shared
Of wine or beer, 'tis our joy and bliss
To partake in drink, and laughter free.

Total Wine, a place of wonder,
Offers liquor, both domestic and foreign,
From beer to wine, vodka, soju, sangria,
A veritable feast, for all to savor.

Prices, fair and modest, some quite steep,
Depending on the drink, thou dost seek.
But fear not, for the cost,
For quality, thou dost not lose.

A humidor, with cigars of choice,
For those who partake, in sweet, sweet voice.
And samples, on certain days, they give,
Tequila, wine, and more, to live.

The staff, knowledgeable and kind,
No pressure, just a gentle mind.
If thou dost like, thou dost buy,
If not, no worry, just pass by.

A one-stop shop, with all thy needs,
Clean, organized, with speed.
If thou dost not find, what thou dost seek,
The staff, informative, and most meek.

Total Wine, our top spot, indeed,
For all our drinks, a grand proceed.
A must, for entertaining, and planning,
With pleasure, and joy, worth the advancing."

In days of yore, within the ancient town
Of Scottsdale, there didst lie a lodging fair,
A suite, no less, for eighty-nine crowns,
Upon the weekend of remembrance, rare.

No service of rooms didst this inn provide,
But, in its stead, a menu of victuals fine,
One called in orders, as in days of old,
And when prepared, a call didst reach the fold.

Downstairs, one went to claim the feast,
And found it good, in taste and in digestion's quest.

"Hark! What's this? A place to dine, so fair and bright,
With portions large, and prices most reasonable in sight.
The staff, though robotic in their ways, are swift and neat,
And take your orders with a smile, so don't be beat.
But mark this well, good sirs, they close their doors at nine,
So make haste, lest you be left to dine alone."

"This joint's got everything I like: sandwiches, a touch of Italy, good wine, and a chill vibe. If I owned a market, it'd be like this one. Maybe add a call-in order option for busy Saturdays. That's my only gripe."

"Hark, fair friends, I sought the finest fish fry in Madison's land,
And chanced upon this cozy tavern, nestled on the east side strand.
A word of warning, ere thou doth set foot within its door,
They take no reservations, and on Fridays, crowds do pour.
Expect to wait, my friend, yet fear not, for 'tis worth the while,
For this humble abode doth boast a loyal following, all the while.
Their fish, oh how it doth delight, in forms both fried and baked,
Cod, perch, and walleye, all are present, and each dish is well-made.
Garlic chili fries, a tempting treat, did call my name,
And homemade chili, too, did grace my taste buds, by the same.
Verily, I say, this place doth rank among the best,
In Madison, for fish fry, it doth stand out from the rest.
My sole complaint, dear friends, doth lie in this,
That they take not reservations, nor carry out, alas.
Yet, see, good sirs, how busy they doth get,
A testament to their success, and worth, ye may not forget."

"Hark! What news is this? A scene doth thrive in Arizona, they say. A night of merriment and tunes most gay, I pray. And lo, the music did surpass my hopes, a veritable feast for mine ears, the DJ's skill most grand. The venue, too, did please mine eyes, with space for dancing, tables round, and folk on canvas, like to home. Simple Citizens, a band from LA, didst take the stage, with full ensemble and MC, a sight most rare. Their drink special, too, didst astound, a mere quarter per draught 'fore eleven o'clock, and five dollars thereafter, a bargain most fair. Methinks I shall return anon, and partake in this place's joys once more."

"Methinks I've visited this place a fair few times, and thus, my dear friend, shall I regale thee with a tale of the wondrous delights that lie within. A hotdog, by the name of 'traditional', doth grace the menu, adorned with sundry toppings of diverse sorts. Now, as a devotee of the humble hotdog, have I sampled each and every variation thereof, save for that rare occasion when fate doth play a cruel trick, and the dish doth falter, leaving me no choice but to deduct a star from its rating, alas!"

"Flavors most wondrous did this feast provide,
Craig, our server, with care did attend.
Allergies my spouse doth bear, yet they did strive
In kitchen, to make each dish most pure.
Above our means, the price did lie,
Yet, gourmet burgers, a treat did they buy.
We shall return, this place to grace."

"Hark, what news is this? A pizza place most fair,
With slices large and prices quite reasonable, I declare.
The pepperoni, fresh and hot, doth please my taste,
And though 'twas early, still they did prepare it with haste.

Inside the boulder station, a haven for all,
A place to visit after a film, or ere thou doth fall.
So, pizza lovers, take heed of this humble abode,
For there, thy hunger shall be satisfied, I do avow."

"Hark! What's this? A place of such renown,
It doth deserve five stars, by my crown.
Aye, mayhap I am but a foolish soul,
Yet still, the name doth make me laugh whole.

In Las Vegas, a city of sin,
This pho shop doth stand out within.
Open round the clock, it doth cater
To those who crave a savory treat, late or early.

Alas, the service doth leave much to be desired,
Rude and brusque, with nary a smile nor fire.
But fear not, for they doth bring thy food and bill
With haste, that thou mayst quickly fulfill
Thy hunger and depart, ere long, at thy will."

"Hark, good sir or madam, to this wondrous place,
The Arts Factory, where creativity doth embrace
All manner of art, both fine and rare,
A haven for those who seek beauty to share.

Within its walls, a diverse array doth lie,
From paintings grand to curious knick-knacks nearby,
A veritable treasure trove, a feast for thine eyes,
A place where wonder doth never cease to arise.

Hiptazmic studio, a realm of upcycled delight,
Doth offer jewels, decor, and art, all bright,
T-shirts, patches, tags, and more, a cornucopia,
A haven for those who seek the unique and the curious.

And Happy Panda toys, oh joy, what fun,
Vinyl toys galore, their release parties begun,
A place where collectors gather, trading with glee,
Their passion for toys, a sight to see.

Hell Pop, a realm of comics, books alternative,
A haven for those who seek the strange and the fantastic,
A place where imagination doth take flight,
A world of wonder, a pure delight.

The Arts Factory, a place of wonder, a treat,
On First Fridays, a time to meet, to greet,
The pizzas at Bar and Bistro, oh so fine,
A culinary delight, a taste divine.

So come one, come all, to this wondrous place,
Where art and joy doth fill the space,
A haven for dreamers, a place of delight,
The Arts Factory, a true wonder in sight."
"Beer selection, top-notch. Desserts, too. Belgian chocolate pudding, specifically. Other grub, meh. Monday night trivia, always fun."
"Hark, good sir! Thou say'st 'tis only done take out? By Jove, I swear, the counter service doth impress me much, and e'er doth draw me back to savor more of their delectable victuals!"

"Four stars, I shall bestow upon this place,
For in fair Pittsburgh, options be scarce,
But in a larger town, 'twould be three,
For though the food be good, 'tis not too terse.

Once did I visit for lunch, and had
A Malaysian noodle soup, quite tasty, not bad,
And on a Sunday, Dim Sum did I partake,
With divers options, all very well-made.

In Pittsburgh, 'tis certainly not the worst,
But in cities grand, like Boston, Seattle, first,
It doth not compare, alas, my friend,
But for Pittsburgh, 'twas satisfying, an end.

My friend, who lived in China, did concur,
That the Dim Sum, quite decent, it did procure,
And thus, I shall return, with haste, anon,
For the service, good, and prices, reasonable, done.

Atmosphere, comfortable, with lighting dim,
Outdoor seats, available, when skies be trim,
A full bar, with seating, for those who wish,
To quaff a draught, and savor the dish."

"Hark, my dear companion, 'twas a fortuitous day indeed,
When thou didst suggest we break free from our daily grind,
And seek sustenance at Haps, a place of renown,
Where culinary delights doth abound.

Though I had brought my own repast, I was easily swayed,
By the prospect of escape, and the promise of a treat,
So we hastened forth, with eager feet,
To partake of their delectable fare, and sweet retreat.

And lo, upon our arrival, a wondrous sight did greet,
A case of cobblers, diverse and fine, did meet our eyes,
With peaches, oh so juicy and ripe, did take the stage,
My heart did sing with joy, for peaches are my prize.

I ordered the special, hot ham and cheese, a feast,
A large drink, and the peach cobbler, a true delight,
The cashier asked if ice cream I did desire,
But nay, I wished not to spoil the taste, or dampen the fire.

Behind the counter, a maiden fair, did prepare,
Our sandwiches, with skill and care, did she undertake,
The peach cobbler, she did microwave, with speed,
Oh how I longed to taste, its warmth, its sweetness, its creed.

Our drinks were filled, a large, two hands did require,
And swiftly, our repast, did we then acquire,
We returned to the office, with haste,
And I, did dive into the peach, with joy, and with zest.

Oh how divine, the flavors did combine,
A symphony of sweet, a culinary shrine,
I thought to share, but selfishness did prevail,
For such a treat, I could not, nor would not, fail.

The sandwich, too, did please, its worth,
A satisfying meal, of quality, and of earth.
So here's to thee, my friend, and to our escape,
May fortune smile, and may our bellies always shape."

"Sambalatte's new joint on 215 & Jones is now open for business. No need to trek all the way to Summerlin. This spot's smaller than the other one, but they've got more outdoor seating. Nice on a warm day, not so much on a scorching Vegas summer afternoon. Went there around six on a Wednesday, and it was dead. Service was quick. Ordered the iced macha latte. Didn't ask for a size, so I figured it'd be a regular. But no, they gave me a large cup. Damn good drink, worth every penny. Had a nutella latte before, and that was top-notch too. They got all sorts of pastries and desserts, including macaroons. Great place to grab a cup and chill or meet up with pals. Tons of parking outside."

"A fortnight past, my fair companion and I didst stop by this establishment for an evening's revelry. Upon our arrival, we didst note that self-parking was not an option, forsooth, and thus we were compelled to employ the services of the valet. Now, by my troth, I do confess that I am not overly fond of such services, for I am a man of considerable stature and prefer to park my own conveyance, gratis. Howbeit, we didst proceed within, and after some brief deliberation, we didst secure a table nigh unto the bar. Their victuals, a curious blend of Mexican and New Mexican fare, didst prove to be most delectable, I do assure thee. My memory doth fail me, alack, regarding the specific dish I didst partake of, but I do recall that it was exceedingly tasty. Moreover, our server didst recommend to us a certain bottle of red wine, which we didst share betwixt us, and found it to be most excellent. The service, I must say, was top-notch, and the atmosphere, most conducive to a romantic assignation. In conclusion, this place doth merit a visit, forsooth, and thou shalt not be disappointed, upon my honor."

"For pennies, dim sum feast awaits,
Chicken feet and bao, my heart doth sway.
To savor such delights, prepare to pay,
In patience, for service, a woeful way.

On busy days, servers scarce, no aid,
Water, thou must fetch, thine own self-made.
Scowling ladies, carts they push with ease,
A smile, a rarity, a joyous breeze.

And when thy meal is done, no tarry,
Stamp card, upfront, their duty to carry.
Lest thou wait, forevermore, in woe,
Four stars, I give, for service, a curse, ye know."
"Food, well-cooked and presented. Grilled octopus, spot on. Main courses and desserts, good too. Pricey, but worth it for the missus' birthday. Special night, indeed."

"Eight years a local of Las Vegas, I knew well the Suncoast's renown, A haven of rest, with rates most fair and reasonable, Inviting all to bask in its splendor. 

A locals' casino, it doth boast, In Summerlin, a district most chaste, With prices low, by Coast's decree, A wise choice, indeed, for those who seek comfort and ease. 

The chamber, clean and neat, The staff, kind and most discreet, Efficient, the check-in doth prove, A guest-focused crew, they doth improve. 

For gamers, comps abound, A buffet, a gift, they doth proffer, With little play, a promotion, they doth tender, For their next visit, a sweet surrender. 

The tables, typical, yet fun, The dealers, pleasant, beneath the sun, But the poker room, an afterthought, alack, A disappointment, in so grand a stack. 

But fear not, for Boyd's sportsbook doth shine, A haven for those who delight in the line, And so, I shall return, come football season, To revel in Suncoast's splendor and reason."
"Food's good, plenty of it. Entertainment's top-notch too. Margaritaville's got nothing on this joint when it comes to flair."

"Oh Dollar Tree, thou hast within thy walls
All that I could e'er desire or need,
From rows of colored treasures, cards and plates,
Cleaning supplies, and victuals to feed.
A veritable cornucopia doth thy shelves bedeck,
And yet, alas! A four-star rating doth thy worthiness check.
For yonder driveway, leftward bent, doth cause dismay,
And leaves me shaken, praise the Lord, to tell the tale this day.
But still, I say, if party thou dost throw,
Or poverty doth strike, and food doth lack,
Or sudden birthday doth arise, with nary a clue,
Then hie thee hence, to Dollar Tree, anon, 'tis true.
For though 'tis not a place for fancy folk,
Yet doth it hold, for those who dare, a secret cloak.
I am a fan, and oft shall visit thee,
My dearest Dollar Tree, nearest to me."

A short journey from the bustling Strip, a place to spend an hour or two,
For children, a delightful way to pass the time, I do declare.
'Tis a museum, with history as its main theme,
Of test sites and surrounding lands, so serene.
The exhibits, though not vast, are full of knowledge and insight,
A place to learn, a treasure trove, a true delight.
But, alas, once visited, there's no need to return,
For the material, though rich, is limited, we discern.

"Hark! Within the confines of Planet Hollywood's mall,
This place doth serve a decent cup of coffee, 'tis true.
The service, alas! doth leave much to be desired,
But still, their brew doth rival that of Starbucks, I find.
And thus, my friend, thou shalt not suffer great woe,
For here, thy caffeine fix shall be easily found.
So, haste thee well, and may good fortune be thine,
In this, the mall of Planet Hollywood, 'tis called."

"Hark! A word of praise for this place, I do declare,
Though I've not stayed here, 'tis a spot most fair.
The staff, kind and courteous, doth make us feel welcome,
And the premises, cleanliness doth prevail.

We've supped at many restaurants, and found delight,
In the fare they serve, both day and night.
Zenshin, the new addition, doth shine so bright,
A haven for games, laughter, and delight.

Bingo, bowling, movies, and comedy, too,
A variety of diversions, for old and new.
The crowds, they do not hinder, our merriment,
For here, 'tis easy to find one's content.

So, if thou seeketh a place of joy and cheer,
Come hither, friend, and cast away fear.
For here, within these walls, doth lie a treat,
A haven of delight, for thee to greet."

"Hark, what luck we had at this most wondrous feast,
A buffet on the Strip, where we didst find
A bounty of delights, both savory and sweet,
And all for just $32 per person, 'twas a treat.

We entered without wait, a true miracle indeed,
And found the spread to be quite varied and grand.
The tacos, oh how they didst delight,
With flavors and spices that didst take flight.

A salsa bar, full and fresh, didst complement,
The hot and sour soup, a true revelation.
Crab legs, a treasure, didst arrive at last,
A fitting end to our meal, or so we thought.

But alas, not all was perfect, I do confess,
The Caesar salad, o'er dressed, didst taste of saltiness.
And prime rib, cooked too long, didst become dry,
A shame, for it didst have such promise in the sky.

Desserts, aplenty, didst catch mine eye,
But alas, I was so full, could only try
A scoop of blood orange sorbet, a refreshing delight,
And thus, our meal didst come to an end, with great delight.

The restrooms, nearby, a short walk away,
And service, average, nothing to dismay.
I shall return, for sure, to this place,
For more of its wonders, and its culinary grace."

"Hark! A fortnight past, I chanced upon this place,
And since, have visited oft, with joy and grace.
Their Chinese fare, doth please mine taste,
And quick, their service doth make haste.

A small, cozy interior, with booths and tables few,
Yet warmth and welcome, doth there shine through.
The waitresses, with diligence and cheer,
Do tend to guests, with nary a speck of fear.

In a strip-mall, south of Walgreens' domain,
Doth Great Wall stand, with Sherwin Williams' gain.
Little Caesars too, doth join the fray,
A trio of shops, in one place, what say?"

"O, how my heart did sing with joy and bliss,
When first I laid eyes on thee, sweet dish.
Thy prices, fair and reasonable, didst please,
And with thy taste, my senses didst tease.

Indeed, I knew not what to do,
For thou, a feast for both my belly and my view.
I didst partake of thee, and oh, how grand,
The flavors danced upon my tongue, so bland.

Thus, I didst fall in love with thee,
My dearest dish, my heart's devotion.
For thou, a treasure, beyond compare,
A culinary delight, most rare."

"With rumbling bellies, we didst venture forth upon the Pennsylvania turnpike, seeking succor in the form of Indian cuisine. Our hunger pangs didst threaten to consume us whole, yet we resisted the temptation of a nearby sandwich shop, opting instead to press onward in search of spicier fare. In a state of near-famished delirium, we stumbled into Coriander India Grill, whereupon we were greeted by a kindly host who showed us to a cozy booth. Moments later, a platter of crispy chips arrived, accompanied by three mysterious dipping sauces - green, brown, and chartreuse. Though ignorant of their composition, we devoured them with relish, our taste buds stirred to life by their tangy flavors. Perusing the menu, we placed our orders: lamb vindaloo, its spice level a fearsome 10, and palak paneer, a comparatively mild 7. Dosas, those delectable southern Indian crepes, beckoned to us from the menu, but we feared to risk their unfamiliar flavors upon our already-taxed stomachs. The meals arrived in due course, and oh, how they delighted our senses! The vindaloo seared our tongues with its fiery heat, while my wife's palak paneer proved a rich, creamy indulgence. Sated and content, we quit the restaurant, our faces aglow with the aftermath of a satisfying repast."

"A fine selection of beers. The menu looked good too, we didn't eat, but it seemed promising, and local! We had sangria on the terrace, it was pleasant. My only criticism is that we went in the early afternoon and it lacked atmosphere... A little background music would have done the trick :)"

"Methinks 'tis a fair deal, my friends,
For sixteen silver pence, a feast doth lie.
Crab legs, though not of highest rank,
Are joined by prime rib, sushi, and clam broth,
A stir-fry of note, and Chinese fare,
With gelato, premium, to conclude the share.

In Las Vegas, seekers of a bargain true,
This buffet find, and their bellies fill anew.
I've seen many spreads, but this one, I do confess,
Hath won my heart, with price and victuals in excess.

Yet mark my words, arrive by five and thirty,
Lest thou stand in line, and tarry tediously."

"Methinks 'tis my first visit to this establishment on this day,
And, verily, I find the prices to be somewhat steep.
Yet, the victuals they serve, are most delectable and sweet,
So, anon, I shall return, to partake of their other dishes, ere I sleep."

"Methinks we sat at yonder bar,
And lo, the bartender didst attend to us with care.
A Lollipop Passion Goblet we didst order,
And verily, 'twas a wondrous draught, beyond compare.
For thirty-six silver pieces, 'twas a worthy fee,
To partake of such a marvel, a true delight for thee.

The ice, it was dry ice, and thus didst create,
A misty veil, that didst add to the drink's allure.
Tasting of Midori Sour, it didst please our palate,
And lollipops and candy necklaces, didst complete the state.

Fries and fried mac n cheese, we didst also request,
The former, middling fair, the latter, a culinary success.
I shall return, to sample more of their goblets and fare,
For this establishment, doth possess a certain flair."

"With my fair maidens, I didst dine here late,
After a night of mirth and revelry.
The French dip, with truffle tater tots, didst delight,
And eased my aching head, from too much ale, I do confess.
The service, swift and kind, didst make our day,
And my coffee cup, they didst refill, in play."

In Princess Mall, I didst wait for bus,
With time to spare, and thoughts of frivolous,
I chanced upon a Spud U Like,
A place of old, where memories doth reside.

The sour cream and chives, I didst choose,
While Sylvia, baked beans didst dispose,
A Slovak, with beans, didst seem quite odd,
But then, I thought, perhaps they do bake,

Meal A, a topped up tater, with a drink,
I ordered, but a coffee, I didst think,
So forty pence, more, I didst pay,
For a brew, that didst brighten up the day.

The spuds, they were delicious, indeed,
The service, swift, and the young man, pleasing,
A fine distraction, 'twas, before the bus,
To airport, didst take me, with nary a fuss.
"Food was damn good. Place used to be a Moe's, so it ain't exactly a looker. Could use some sprucin' up inside. Chefs know their stuff, though. Servers? Not so much."

"A charming cinema, quaint and small,
Which offers a most pleasant film experience of all.
No crowds to trouble thee, the place is neat,
And snacks, they do provide, of various treat.
Popcorn, sweets, and soda, all doth flow,
To make thy visit, a joyous repast, I do know.
Before or after, do visit Wine Expression,
To complete a most delightful afternoon's session."

"My first visit, I must confess,
All my coworkers did speak the best,
Of this place, with much enthusiasm,
But alas, the exterior doth lack luster.

Do not bring a first date here, my friend,
For the ambiance doth leave much to amend,
Dark and dim, like a cave, it doth seem,
And the staff, they doth resemble skaters, extreme.

But fear not, for their service doth shine,
Friendly, polite, and most attentive, they be,
Their beer selection, a paragon of fine,
A tab of excellence, for all to see.

The expanded section, for groups, doth fit,
Our work happy hour, it did fulfill,
And the menu, oh how it doth delight,
Carne Asada, a concoction, most excellent, a sight.

Calzones, a clever twist, a masterful spin,
Creativity, at its finest, doth win,
Ambiance, three stars, too dark, I say,
But staff, five plus, their service, doth sway.

Food, five plus, the calzone, a dream,
Take home, a pleasure, no need to scream,
Beer, five stars, a selection, most grand,
A tab, of which, few places can boast, in this land."

"Hark, what service we didst receive!
The decor, a sight to behold, doth please.
And food, oh how it doth delight,
A feast fit for a king, I do declare.

My first time, since last I didst dine,
For lunch, a meal most fine and fair.
All these, they didst impress,
Pre-game bread, a taste so rare.
Bacon-wrapped pork tenderloin, a treat,
Lobster, my wife's, a delicacy so sweet.
Sweet corn and polenta, a perfect pair,
Bacon and Yukon gold, a gratin so fair and rare.
Forbidden rice, a name so bold,
A dish that doth intrigue and unfold.
Wine list, with waiter so wise,
A treasure trove of flavors, a surprise.
Mashed potatoes, a humble delight,
A culinary journey, through the night.

Give it a try, this place so rare,
A hidden gem, beyond compare.
Elements at the Sanctuary, a taste so true,
A secret spot, for me and you."

"A most excellent eatery, in truth,
With victuals, service, and ambiance of youth.
French cuisine, I had tried ere now,
And found it wanting in quantity, I vow.
But here, oh here, the portions be fair,
Steak and seafood, both in abundance share.
And tasty, by my troth, beyond compare,
The fries and bread, a culinary pair.
Seat thee outside, if weather doth allow,
For romance doth reign, and the strip doth show.
Four and a half stars, I would bestow."

"A most excellent spot, where one may linger and enjoy. The hospitality, warm and welcoming, doth make one feel at home. Their BLT&E, a dish most delectable, doth please mine taste buds with its savory blend of flavors, neither too rich, nor overwhelming. Verily, 'tis a favorite of mine."
"Clean room, good service. Not impressed with the carnival buffet, though. Overpriced Chinese joint across the street. Despite that, enjoyed my stay. Will be back."

"Hark, what shoppers seek within these walls,
A haven for the thrifty, where clothes abound.
In quantity they flow, a river vast,
Yet cheap, my friends, a price most modest.

But heed this warning, lest ye be deceived,
For dresses, no returns shall be reprieved.
Exchange or store credit, that is all,
So try on well, ere ye make thy call.

A place for youth, where fashion reigns,
From teens to thirty, all may gain.
Trendy garb, and some not so fair,
But each to their own, without compare.

Organized, the racks they keep with care,
And often restock, to show they dare.
The service, middling, yet the maidens kind,
If asked, assist thee, with hearts inclined."

"Hark! This eating house, once Yoshi's or Kyoto Bowl, doth now entice thee with its changed ambiance. Fear not, dear gourmand, for the menu doth boast a variety of delectable dishes. We didst partake of the Salmon Lover, Delish, Eel Cucumber, and Sixty Nine rolls, all of which didst delight our taste buds with their flavor, texture, and originality. The Salmon Lover, in sooth, didst steal the show. A must-try, indeed!

Aside: Alas, I am allergic to avocado, a common ingredient in many a sushi dish. Thus, I opted for nigiri, which, alack, didst come at a higher cost. Yet, the waiter, a kind soul, didst accommodate my request to omit the avocado, and all was well."

"Methinks I've been to this place many a time,
But tonight, alas! 'Twas quite a sorry plight.
With two companions, I did make a reservation,
For eight forty-five, as was my intention.

But lo! The hostesses were rude, I say,
And the waitstaff, they did little to sway
Our discontent, with empty promises they did play.
The bartenders, kind they were, I must confess,
And young Isaac, a busser of great finesse.
He solved our problem, and with haste did seat us,
A true hero, in a night most dismal and bleak.

Two hours had passed, a single drink we had,
And our mood, it was quite understandably bad.
But still, we did not show our displeasure,
For rudeness begets rudeness, and that's no treasure.

Now, a one-star review, I would have given,
But Issac and Mark, they did our spirits lift.
They comped our drinks, and with kindness did abound,
Their service, top-notch, their hearts full of sound.

So four stars, I give, despite the initial woe,
For Issac and Mark, they did our evening save, oh!"

"Mine eyes didst feast upon the grilled shrimp, a dish most wondrous and fair. Its spiciness didst tickle mine taste buds, and I didst revel in its flavor so rare. The bread, a marvel of simplicity, didst complement the shrimp most perfectly, lacking only the richness of butter and garlic sauce, a trifling matter indeed. Verily, I shall request this dish again, anon."

"Hark! What happy hour doth lie within this place?
Arrive ere six o'clock, lest thou miss the chance
To partake in their "island time" menu, full
Of cocktails and delightful apps, most wondrous.

Our group of four didst enjoy the drinks, I say,
With grapefruit basil martini leading the way.
Mojitos and margaritas didst follow suit,
And all were pleased, with nary a single dispute.

Their happy hour menu doth contain great apps,
Ahi tuna poke, a dish most wondrous and grand.
Fish tacos, too, didst please my husband's taste,
But for my gluten-free friend, a challenge didst arise.

Alas, the GF entree options didst not impress,
And she didst settle for a salad, I do confess.
Yet still, we all didst enjoy our meals that night,
In this establishment with ambiance so bright."

"Upon the bustling strip of Vegas, I didst stumble upon a place most fair,
Whose ambiance didst transport me to Paris, in its elegance and care.
The victuals and vintage, both were excellent, as was the servitude,
A truly pleasant experience, worth repeating, in my sojourn's duration."

"Hark! This place, Bombay Digity be,
On Sahara and Decatur, a sight to see.
A small restaurant, but oh so grand,
With flavors of India, at thy command.

Cleanliness, a virtue, they do possess,
A must, for any restaurant, I profess.
A friendly waitress, with a smile so bright,
Did guide me through the menu, with all her might.

Spinach Paneer, a dish divine,
With spinach, tofu, and sauce, so fine.
Garlic Naan, a perfect pairing,
Together, a culinary delight, so rare.

Keer, a dessert, a sweet delight,
Rice pudding, with berries, a treat so bright.
Samosas, veggie-friendly, a bonus,
A transition to vegan, a path, they do choose.

Service, good, and food, so great,
Lunch specials, a treat, await.
I shall return, with haste,
To savor more, of this Indian feast."

"Hark, my friends, I shall regale thee with tales of yore,
Of poker rooms and shifts galore.
'Tis the Bellagio, where I doth play,
Six times a year, by the light of day.

Now, listen well, for I have observed,
The morning shift, 'tis truly deserving.
Calvin, the manager, doth rule with grace,
And all the staff, they doth embrace,
Their duties with glee, and a smile so bright,
They doth make the game, a pure delight.

But alas, my friends, the evening shift,
Doth falter, and doth not lift.
The young ones, at the front, they doth seem,
So full of themselves, and their dreams.
They doth take their time, to start the game,
And doth show little care, for those who came.

But fear not, for there be some, who doth shine,
Old Timmy, he doth stand out, so divine.
And the 2 to 10 crew, they doth bring,
Joy to the table, with their pleasant ring.

The problem lies, within the staff,
Who doth instruct, the customers, so gruff.
For naught but woe, can come from such ways,
And doth leave a sour taste, in the end of days."

"Fair maidens, with colors bold and bright,
Topmost unique, to make thee stand in sight.
Prices fair, and jewels of funky delight,
Classic pieces too, like black Fall's jacket so fine,
A worthy addition to thy wardrobe, under $100 doth shine.

Friendly lasses tend the shop with cheer,
A sale section in the back, for thrifty gleaners to appear.
Summer finds of note, for ladies to acquire,
Go forth and fetch them, ere they do expire."

"Sam Fox tavern, where mirth doth reign,
A place of sport and revelry, with naught but gain.
Ping pong, cornhole, and drinks galore,
A merry atmosphere, and people who adore.
A band doth play, on certain nights,
To add to the joy, and keep all in delight.
But parking, alas, doth pose a woe,
For crowds do gather, and spaces do grow low.
So valet, my friend, doth be the way,
To ensure thy ride, doth stay in play.
I cannot speak, of food's delights,
For mine own taste, doth only take flight.
But appetizers, they did please,
And left me wanting more, with ease."

"Hark! We've dined at LaVecchia's oft,
And found it to be quite the spot.
Parking's easy, and free, by the way,
In the Hearst tower, a convenient stay.
The walk down's pleasant, the atmosphere grand,
With businessfolk and upscale patrons at hand.
RiRa, Luce, and a courtyard so fair,
Make the location quite elegant, beyond compare.
Reservations? They're easy to keep,
For we've been seated, while others did sleep.
The wait staff's prompt, and attentive,
Our drinks arrive swiftly, without a fuss or a fret.
Appetizers, a tad too salty, I confess,
But main courses, oh! They're truly divine, no less.
We've returned often, despite other choices galore,
For LaVecchia's charm, we can't help but adore."

"Four stars doth this place merit, fair reader,
For 'tis not overly cheap, but of average price.
I called but fifteen minutes prior, and lo,
They bade me come straightway, without delay or strife.

All prepared they had my gel manicure,
No waiting did I endure, nor did I feel ire.
A plethora of gel hues did they possess,
My mind didst flutter, like a bird in flight, with distress.

The ladies, friendly all, didst assist me well,
With suggestions given, and patience didst tell.
Other customers, in delight and joy, didst speak,
Their satisfaction, plain to hear, didst break.

My manicurist, with time, didst work her art,
No haste didst she make, though closing time drew near.
Highly do I recommend this place, good sir,
For service, price, and kindness, beyond compare."
"Tried the 2.99 special, skipped it, thought I'd give 'em another shot. Don Tortaco's breakfast burrito's been shrinkin', might hit 'em up now. Wish their salsa was thicker, more heat, less vinegar."

"Hark, what stormy skies we had last week,
A day most foul, and dark, and bleak.
Yet still, my heart did yearn for frozen treat,
And so, to yogurt shop, I did seek.

I chose snickerdoodle, peanut butter too,
With Andies mints, a tasty brew.
The yogurt, just the right consistency,
Neither too thick, nor too thin, ye see.

The ambiance, a bit cheesy, I confess,
But plenty seats, for a yogurt mess.
I praise them for posting calories bold,
Even if 'tis an eyesore, to behold.

In brief, a pleasant shop, well-kept,
With friendly service, and a sweet treat.
I shall return, when next in town,
For more of their delicious frozen crown."

"Methinks my love and I didst partake of Chili Cheese Dogs most fair,
A culinary delight that doth please our taste buds beyond compare.
The hot dog, cooked to perfection, didst snap most satisfyingly,
When bitten into, its juices didst flow forth like a bounteous spring.
The chili, rich and savory, didst complement the dog most finely,
In perfect proportion, so one might devour it with ease,
And yet, methinks, a change I wouldst make, anon,
To shredded cheese, more fitting, than Kraft singles, alone.
But still, most delectable, this snack, upon the strip, didst shine."

In sooth, I chanced upon this coffeehouse,
To taste their brew, and see if 'twere a prize.
The flavor was familiar, and I did ask,
If they roasted their own beans, or didst task
Somewhere in Canada, for such fine fare.
The barista replied, with a smile so fair,
That the beans were from 49th Parallel, in Van.
Ah, Vancourites, if ye seek coffee divine,
This place doth serve it well, and worth thy time.

I also ordered a scone, of which I did partake,
And found it most delicious, with nary a mistake.
The shop itself, though small, doth have its charm,
But the people-watching, alas, doth leave much to disarm.
Unless, perchance, some event doth take place,
At the convention center, with folk in abundance.

The staff, I must say, were most courteous and kind,
A pleasant experience, for all mankind.

"Fresh seafood doth abound, each day anew.
We did request our oysters shucked, and thence didst make our way,
To yonder tavern, where fine ales and wines did flow.

Their meats, seafood, and salads, all doth please.
Take up thy victuals, and with ale or wine, doth make merry.
A capital place, for people-watching, 'tis.

The staff, most kind and helpful, doth attend.
A grocer, top-notch, and lo! a bar, doth make an end."

"Hark! A tale of steak and revelry,
At Monte Carlo, where we did decree
A feast of beef, for six brave men,
To savor, and to make merry then.

Two for one, the drinks they did pour,
And seated us, at a table of power,
The atmosphere, quite pleasant, indeed,
Yet, alack! The casino floor, did impede
Our steakhouse bliss, with its din and smoke,
And gamblers, lost in their wagering cloak.

But, lo! The steak, it was divine,
A mound of meat, fit for a king, or shrine,
Cooked to perfection, as it should be,
With sides and sauces, of the finest quality.

The staff, they were, in service, fine,
Efficient, and friendly, all the time,
They gifted us, with entry, free,
Into Brand's "after hours", a club, for thee.

Alas! The club, it was not, a sight,
To behold, in the dead of night,
But, in Vegas, such is the way,
Great steakhouses, and clubs, each day.

So, heed my words, and take a peek,
At Monte Carlo's steakhouse, unique,
But, shun the club, and its wild delight,
For, 'tis not worth, your precious sight."

"Hark! A structure grand and fair,
With grandstands steep, a mezzanine rare,
Luxury boxes, club spaces too,
A sight most wondrous, a view anew.

In Phoenix, where hockey's scarce,
This arena would stir hearts, perchance,
Its design, a marvel of sound and fright,
Fans hovering, a fearful sight.

Alas, the surroundings, dull and tame,
Glendale, a name, a shame,
A place, so sterile, devoid of cheer,
Pensacola, a comparison near.

The drive, a burden, a chore,
A night of revelry, no more,
For the morning sun, a swift return,
To civilization, a distant burn."

"Fare thee well, good sir! Forsooth, this eatery doth serve most wondrous victuals, by my troth! Alas, the seating space, alack, doth suffer from dearth, should the outdoor patio remain unopened. Fear not, fair patron, for 'tis a brief delay, and worth the wait, anon! For within, they do prepare most delectable comestibles, both vegan and vegetarian, with flavors so divine! Their pho, a brothy delight, doth warm the cockles of mine heart, and their fresh rolls, crunchy and savory, doth leave me in raptures! By my honor, I shall return anon, to partake in their culinary delights once more!"

"Trump hotel, a place of rest,
With kind employees, we were blessed.
Our room, clean and spacious, a delight,
Shower, huge, a true pleasure in sight.

But alas, pillows, uncomfortable, a shame,
And the train whistle, early morning, a claim.
Yet, neither did take away,
From the experience, in any way.

The pool, nice, but get there early,
For a lounge chair, a true hurly-burly.
Restaurants, we did not try,
But muffins and fruit, at the coffee stand, did buy.

The lack of casino, a blessing in disguise,
A quieter, smoke-free lobby, our prize.
I would return, without a doubt,
To Trump hotel, where we were devout."

"Methinks 'tis a fair and lovely inn,
Where travelers may find rest and solace within.
But lo, a bakery doth reside here also,
Owned by none other than Carlos, he of the culinary show.
Ay, 'tis true, good sirs and madams,
That his sweet delights do draw a crowd,
And thou must prepare thyself to wait,
For nigh an hour or more, ere thou dost partake.
But fear not, for 'tis worth the while,
To taste his confections, so divine and worthwhile."

"Till 9:30, this joint stays open. In a town that never sleeps, that's saying something. And let me tell you, the grub is top-notch. For 7.95, you get a full meal, including a drink and an egg roll. If they delivered to UNLV, it'd be a five-star affair."

"Hark, good sir! What doth mine eyes perceive? A meal most fair and worthy of my purse! 'Tis not the dos gringos of yore, but now, 'tis called Rocky Point Cantina, a name most fitting for this fine establishment. Verily, I didst enjoy the fare, with tacos and coronas at a price most reasonable, a mere $2! The interior, a sight to behold, didst impress me with its grandeur and finesse. In sooth, a place most excellent for a repast most satisfying!"

"Hark! What eatery is this, that doth arouse
My taste buds thus? 'Tis Spinelli's, by the name,
A place of wonder, where culinary joys abound.
The cheese steak, oh so fine, doth make me swoon,
With peppers, onions, ratioed to perfection,
And bread, soft as a cloud, with crunchy outer layer.
The pizza, fresh and hand-tossed, doth fill me up,
A satisfying meal, with nary a drop of ale,
For now, alas! But soon, 'twill be available,
To quench my thirst and complement the feast.
Beyond the main course, there's more to explore,
Appetizers, salads, desserts, and Stromboli galore.
So, gentle friends, let us give thanks for this find,
Authentic, relaxing, and free from pretenses,
A true delight, that doth warm the cockles of mine heart,
And maketh me exclaim, in loudest voice, 'Enjoy, my friends, enjoy!'"

"A tiny tavern, cramped and snug,
We slurped our noodles with gusto, my dear hub and I.
I chose the tonkotsu, thin strands they were,
While my mate opted for spicy ramen, wavy and fair.

Thick noodles, a surprise, I must confess,
For 'thin' they were called, yet pleased I was.
My preference, as thou knowest, doth lie
In hearty ramen, a sturdy guise.

First visit, oh so grand, a feast!
But now, alas, not quite the best.
Still, at this price, a bargain indeed,
A meal most satisfying, our bellies to feed."
"Marry, what a wondrous place! Neat, fair-priced, good service, delectable victuals - by my troth, 'tis a feast fit for a king!"

"Outside Inn, a tavern of sorts, didst seem ordinary at first glance, save for its whimsical name that didst pique my curiosity. Upon entry, the rustic wooden decor with exposed beams didst please mine eyes, and the dimly lit bar area didst appear cozy. Alas, the dining space was small, and the color scheme, a bit drab. A shame, for a bit more wood wouldst have matched the rest of the decor well, instead of the vinyl booths. \n\nBut lo, the victuals didst surprise me with their quality! Sweet potato fries, a delight, and prime rib, a cut above the rest. Prices, fair, and draft beer selection, plentiful. Service, swift and kind. Verily, a place to return to, for a pint and a prime rib feast."
"Red velvet cake, rich frosting, buttery finish, creamy, lots of cream cheese. Cake, dry. Frosting, amazing. Trendy spot, NYC prices. Staff, friendly."

"Verily, to fully relish this place, one must comprehend its essence. My comrades and I, we didst partake in merriment, and in the end, didst not begrudge the sum of seventeen shillings to gain entry. They doth attire thee in parka and Uggs, and provide gloves for thy glass. Thou dost then deposit all electronic devices and other possessions in a locker, and venture forth into a chilled chamber, set at fifty degrees, ere reaching the bar proper. \n\nAll is crafted from ice, be it the tables, benches, or chandeliers, yea, even the very glasses that hold thy drink! Methought 'twas a curious delight."

"Moscow mule, that's what you want here. Forget the rest, it's not worth your time. Jukebox is busted, beer selection is meh, food is decent but not worth repeating. But those moscow mules, hot damn! Cucumber vodka, mint-infused vodka, doesn't matter, they're tasty as hell. Bartenders are cool too, treat 'em right and they'll hook you up."

"Methinks 'tis wise to steer clear of the first reviewer's wares, my friend, 
When seeking lodging, pass them by, and thus it ends. 
For though they proffer transport from the aerodrome, 
The cost, I fear, may be quite beyond your means, my lord. 
Prepayment, they demand, ere you set foot inside, 
And should the driver ask for more, thou art denied. 
Look for signs that say "Airport Shuttles" or such, 
And choose the one that doth accept thy payment, by Jove! 
Two companies there be, my good sir, take heed, 
One taketh cash alone, the other, credit doth need. 
I chose the latter, for I had not a coin, 
And thus, my friend, I couldst pay with ease, and no strain. 
Use these shuttles, good sir, for they are cheap, 
But six silver pieces, per person, doth it keep. 
A cab, it doth cost more, so heed my words, my friend, 
And save thy pence, by choosing thus, an end."

"Lived in Maryland for 20 years. Love steamed crab legs. This place was good, real good. Glad I went despite some bad reviews. Wanted to go for years, but didn't because I don't live close and my husband doesn't like chain restaurants. 

Waitress, Elyse, was nice, gave us great recs for dinner. Bloody Mary was delicious, had a crab leg garnish! 

Service was quick, heard one waitress say they weren't busy that night. Portions were big. Table next to us shut up for 15 minutes when their food came. That's a good sign. 

Family loved it, we'll be back."

"Chicken ain't fried? You sure? Yeah, that's what I asked the cashier 'cause it was crispy, juicy, and looked and tasted like fried chicken. But it was broasted, whatever that means. To me, it means secretly fried chicken that's better for you than the real deal. And they got malts, shakes, a self-serve yogurt bar, sandwiches, and the famous Dole whip. If you're into that sorta thing. Personally, I like takin' a day trip to Boulder City, enjoyin' the scenery. But if that ain't your thing, this place is on the outskirts, no need to go into town. They got a drive-thru too, but be patient, they cook everythin' fresh to order. Worth the wait, trust me. It's a small hole in the wall, used to be a shack across the street, now it's a full buildin'. They must be doin' somethin' right. BC's got a lot of hidden gems, don't skip this one, you'll regret it."

"Hark! 'Tis a Chipotle, my dear friend,
Where thou shalt find what thou dost expect, anon.
The younglings love it, and wifie too,
For she can eat healthy, as she doth choose.

I do confess, I hold not Chipotle high,
As Mexican fare, it doth not satisfy.
But for what they serve, 'tis quite tasty, indeed,
Their chips and guacamole, most excellent, I swear.
And their pork, oh so juicy and fine,
A feast fit for a king, or so it doth seem.

Beware, my friend, when they dole out the meat,
For oftentimes, they may be stingy, indeed.
Especially when the line doth stretch and grow,
Then may their portions be scant, I do foresee.
So watch closely, lest thou be left unsatisfied,
And may thy meal at Chipotle be truly divine."

"Methinks the victuals here be of excellent sort,
And e'er have I enjoyed them with great relish.
But, alas, the service doth leave much to be desired,
For they do hire the nearby students, unwise guiders.
