One day, we didst make reservations, and forthwith,
The hostess didst try to seat us at a table, quite witless.
We didst request a booth, but she didst refuse,
Insisting that they didst not yet seat in that quarter, perverse.

We didst persist, and thus the debate didst go,
Back and forth, until we didst threaten to depart, ye know.
At last, she didst relent, and we didst sit,
But, lo, she didst make a show of it, with much disdain and spite.

'Twas strange, indeed, and not the usual fare,
But, methinks, a warning sign of what doth come when students are the staff, beware."

"Troon North's Pinnacle course glimmers like a diamond in the rough. Not as captivating, the Monument course still charms. Good, but not excellent, course conditions. Pro shop offers an assortment of golf swag."

"Verily, once found, I doth cleave unto it fast,
This place, in sooth, hath won my heart at last.
A year, or more, hath passed since first I came,
And still, my nails, they doth proclaim their fame.
The staff, so kind, doth know me by my name,
And asketh of my life, with interest, trow?
Their gentle touch, doth make me feel so fine,
A true delight, their ministrations divine.
My next visit, I do eagerly await,
For their expertise, doth make my spirit bright."

I scored a sweet pad within walking distance to everything that matters, including the best ski and ride shop in the desert. Ski Pro's got a killer selection, better than the joints in Colorado. They're all about movin' product, too - snagged a sick ski suit for my kiddo, marked down from $175 to $59. It's still peak season, y'all! They've got a solid selection of skis and boards, but that's a rare purchase for me. Let's just say they've got everything I need for my winter fun. Oh, and they're practically in the Biltmore's backyard.

The help's about average, you know? Not super attentive, but not rude either. They're just chillin', doing their thing. Most likely from middle-class families who can afford to hit the slopes. Can't expect them to be over-the-top friendly, that's just not the vibe here. At least they ain't stoned, paranoid, or semi-hostile like those Colorado ski bums. So, check it out, and don't sweat the service, dude... way.

"Verily, ne'er had I a foul repast at this place,
Their ground beef hummus, most delectable dish,
Tonight, coconut shrimp didst grace my plate,
And with great relish, I didst consume the whole dish,
Most outstanding, I must confess.

But alas, a star doth dwindle, forsooth,
For when we arrived, the hour grew late,
The staff, three in number, didst sit to dine,
In front of guests, their meal they didst debate,
Our waitress, kind and attentive still,
Yet unprofessional, their conduct didst chill,
A trifling matter, mayhap, yet didst leave a sting,
For they didst make us feel, like a burden, we didst cling.

But fear not, dear friends, for this slight glitch,
Doth not deter me from this place, I shall return,
With haste, and recommend it, with greatest cheer,
For the victuals, most excellent, didst earn."

"Hark! If fortune didst grant me but one chance,
To savour either coffee or chocolate in a dance,
I'd choose the latter, from Courier Cafe,
A place of yore, with aged charm, so quaint and gay.
The carpet, old; the waitresses, older still,
Yet their smiles, though wrinkled, warmth doth instil.
And silverware, tarnished, yet doth shine,
In this, a haven for a hearty milkshake divine.
Thick, creamy, and in a metal cup o'erflowing,
On winter's coldest days, my steps doth it draw.
For any true devotee of milkshakes, 'twould be so,
To seek out Courier Cafe, where memories grow."

"Hark, what eatery is this? Not five stars, yet still a worthy four. Good meat they serve, and let thee choose thine own toppings, a feast for thine eyes and taste buds both. The ambiance doth harken back, and music doth play, though occasionally a discordant note doth strike mine ear. Still, 'tis a place worth visiting, and forsooth, I'd order the twain-thirds burger, then choose my toppings with glee."

"I wasnâ€™t sold on the joint at first, name sounded like a gag. But this place serves up some damn fine Pho. Noodle soup, that is. Busy as hell in there, service a bit hasty, but I ainâ€™t complaining. Just in for a quick bite, knew theyâ€™d be slammed. Iâ€™ll be back, want to try more of their grub."

"All have spoken their minds, 'tis true,
Of this eatery, where food is solid, yet unnew.
In Las Vegas, a city of sin and delight,
This diner doth shine with ambience so bright.

'Tis a must-see, my friends, make no mistake,
For though the grub may be forgettable, the surroundings do awake.
With six stars, I rate the atmosphere divine,
A place to dine, or drink, or simply decline.

The rest, alack, doth not much matter, I fear,
For though 'twill not poison thee, nor leave thee in tears,
'Tis naught but edible, a meal to fill,
And for the drunkard, a decent alternative still.

So, prithee, make thy way to this place,
Even if 'tis out of thy way, 'twill show thy face.
'Tis worth the journey, I do swear,
For in this diner, thou shalt find cheer."

"Tuscany, a golf course of newer birth,
In Las Vegas, a city of mirth.
Its clubhouse once a quonset hut,
Now transformed, a beauty to behold, a fit
For royalty, with restaurant grand.
The grass, a problem, once did plague,
But Rhodes Ranch, a sister course, did come,
And saved the day, with expert hand.
A package deal, for both, they offer,
A bargain, for the golfer, a true treasure.
The layout, well-designed, I must say,
Sand traps, aplenty, in play.
Water hazards, a few, there be,
To test thy skill, and challenge thee.
A clocktower, of stone, doth stand,
Fairways, spacious, at thy command.
Wine and vineyards, the theme doth hold,
Unique, indeed, a story to be told.
The price, fair, for the round,
An experience, superb, profound.
A bit of a drive, thou must confess,
But worth it, oh so, yes, indeed."

"Methinks I've visited Trifecta several times, and each occasion hath left me in wonder at the talented artists they showcase. The staff, kind and knowledgeable, doth eagerly share their insights upon request. Many pieces, priced within reach of common folk, doth hang upon the walls, a delightful sight for those who cherish art but find its value oft inflated beyond their means. 

My latest venture to this gallery found me admiring photographs of Las Vegas and Nevada, featured in this month's Desert Companion. A contest it was, and lo, a friend of mine, Anthony M., didst submit his work and earned a place among the chosen few. As a loyal comrade, I doth wholeheartedly endorse his endeavors. 

Although the space be small, I must confess that past events held here have been managed with great skill, provision for victuals and potables abundant. 

Do thou, dear reader, lose thyself in the Arts Factory, and when thou dost, be certain to pay a visit to Trifecta. Nay, let no cultural skepticism deter thee; merely stroll along this street, gaze with thine own unique eyes, and mark how art doth flourish."

"Tis a bustling terrace, full to the brim,
Arrive betimes, lest thou be left in the whim.
A worthy queue, for the victuals they bear,
A new sandwich, "porchetta", doth please thee well,
Like Mama's cooking, it doth warm the heart,
And dogs, they too, shall find a welcome part.
Aye, water for thy furry friend, 'tis a sight,
To see them lap it up, with joy and delight."

"Chandelier, been there a few times. Beautiful place. Go to the second level, order the Lemon Verbena, not on the menu. Pay extra, get extra flowers for your group. Chew the flower, don't swallow, it'll froth in your mouth for a good five minutes. Feels like a little fountain. First time, my boyfriend gave me one, I hit him after. Had to repay the favor to my group of five the next time I was at Cosmo with a Bachelorette party. Entertaining as hell, watching their faces. Worth the twenty-three bucks I spent on the drink and three more flowers."

"A merry tavern, full of cheer and glee,
With victuals fine, and service of the best degree.
Ale flows freely, as do the jests and laughter,
In this, a place of mirth, where all are welcome as they gather.

But, alas, dear patron, heed my warning well,
For parking here, thou shalt not find it easy to tell.
This "Social House" they call it, by name and by nature,
A place of revelry, where quietude doth not abide, I do declare.

Go forth, and partake in the feast and frolic,
Amongst the throngs, with sport and jollity to share.
Many a screen doth show the games of old and new,
For those who wish to witness them, anon, anew.

Rejoice, dear heart, and let thy spirit soar,
In this, a hall of mirth, where all may come once more."

"Hark! The victuals were most excellent, my dear.
The crab cakes, verily, did please mine taste.
A light coating of breading did they bear,
To keep their form, and not to overpower.
The crab within, oh so sweet and fresh,
Did shine, untainted by heavy sauces' grasp.
This, our fourth visit in two months' space,
Did prove consistent, in service and grace.
Yet, alas, the din did reach a peak,
And made discourse betwixt us quite unique.
A 'eat, pay, get out' philosophy, methinks,
Yet, we were never rushed, nor did it stink."

"Methinks 'twas a wondrous feast we didst partake,
The spices, they didst make each dish most fair and bright.
We chanced upon this place, quite late in the night,
Yet still, they didst serve us with great cheer and light.

The waiters, friendly and attentive, didst give
Good counsel when we didst ask, their words didst live.
I, a humble dish of beef and potatoes didst choose,
With a dipping sauce, so spicy, it didst unclose
My taste buds, and I didst pour it o'er my meat,
In joy, I didst exclaim, a four-star treat!

My husband, alas, didst not share my delight,
He didst give but three stars, in his sight not bright.
But I, in my heart, didst know 'twas a four-star night."

"Great spot for grub and brews. Shuffleboard's a blast too. Mac and cheese with ghost pepper cheese, plus broccoli salad, can't be beat. Only gripe's the singer outside on Tuesday. Not that she was bad, enjoyed the band. Just, her outfit didn't fit the family joint vibe."

"Alack, our plans to see the Pirates play didst change,
For when we arrived, the game was sold out, 'twas strange.
But Bill and I didst decide to dine and wager,
At Tilted Kilt, a place of cheer and laughter.

Now, fair maidens, take heed of this warning,
If thou art insecure, choose another venue, forsooth.
The lasses here are clad in scanty attire,
And may stir jealousy's flames, and cause despair.
But I, a woman of wit and ease, didst find
No cause for concern, and enjoyed my time with Bill, at peace.

'Tis a fine establishment, with TVs galore,
We watched the game, and kept score, as we dined and cheered.
The victuals, too, didst please mine taste,
Above average, I would say, in haste.
Fried chicken salad, with crisp romaine,
Honey mustard dressing, sweet and fine.
But alack, they added mandarin orbs,
Not to my liking, yet no great storm.

Bill, he enjoyed his Irish Stew,
With nary a complaint, nor a frown, anon.
I would return to Tilted Kilt once more,
Though pricey, 'twill thrive, on the North Shore."

"Hark! If thou desirest to dine on healthful fare,
Keep moving, for 'tis the key to vitality.
And mark my words, this Southern comfort brew,
Did please mine taste buds, most heartily.
The staff, they did endure, with patience true,
Two members of our group, who did engage,
In water fray, midst their meal, anon.
A merry sight, it was, to behold, I swear."

"Hark, good sir or madam, listen well,
For I have found a place most wondrous,
Near to my work, a haven, a delight,
Where sushi doth abound, both fresh and bright.

Oh, how I wish, with all my heart's desire,
To dine there daily, without fail or fire,
But alas, my purse doth not allow,
Such luxury, such splendor, to unfold.

Yet still, I've had their all-you-can-eat feast,
For twenty pieces of silver, a fair price, indeed,
And three rolls, oh so delectable and sweet,
Did fill my belly, with joy and delight.

Aye, 'tis a bargain, beyond compare,
For each roll, on its own, doth cost,
Some nine or fourteen silver pence,
A fortune, indeed, for those who dance.

But wait, dear friend, for there's more to tell,
The fruit, a gift, a token, doth make us feel,
Special, indeed, and valued, beyond measure,
In this place, where we find our pleasure.

So, gentle reader, heed my words,
And visit this place, where joys are poured,
For thou shalt find, in this house of sushi,
A feast, fit for a king, or a fairy."

"Hark! What's this? A grocery store, so plain, yet so grand? The Yelp reviews didst paint a picture most foul, But in truth, 'twas naught but a typical Asian market, full. Of goods and wares, both new and old, For those who seek to cook, young and bold. The scent of Asia didst fill the air, And I didst laugh at the reviews, so fair and square. For they didst warn of dirt and stench so strong, But lo, it was naught but a pleasant throng. Of shoppers, seeking out their heart's desire, With nary a care, nor reason to conspire. So fear not, dear reader, do not be fooled, For this market is a gem, and worth the fool. It may be cramped, and dusty, true, But the treasures within, are worth it, anon. Nuoc mam, chili oil, and lemongrass fresh, For those who seek to cook, with skill and address. And sweets, oh sweets, so cool and fine, To tempt thy taste, and make thee decline. So come, dear friend, and see for thyself, This market, so humble, yet full of wealth."

"A to-go order I did place, and yonder loopy lass didst take it in hand. Alas, poor service didst she provide, for she didst royally botch the deed. Yet, forth came the manager, swift as lightning, bearing my correct repast. And, generous soul, he didst suffer me to keep the victuals she had given in error. Moreover, he didst proffer to rebate the whole meal, upon mine own credit card, in sooth! Great service, indeed, doth this establishment boast!"

Thus, while toiling at Shirts and Things,
We'd oft order lunch from yonder place,
And I, in sooth, didst always choose
The bread bowl soup, with half potato, half broccoli and cheese,
A wondrous mix, indeed! The bread, itself,
Was also good, and I didst often crave
The Gobbler, too, a dish most fair,
With turkey, cranberry sauce, and stuffing on marble rye,
A feast fit for a king, or so it seemed.

But, alack, the prices were a bit steep,
For seven silver coins, a soup or sandwich did cost,
A sum that didst make my purse weep.
Yet, still, the delivery was swift,
A virtue, indeed, and worth a lift.

"Hark! In fair Verona, a city of delight,  
We chanced upon a place most wondrous and bright.  
'Twas late, and we, with hunger pangs so keen,  
Did seek a meal, our spirits to revive and keen.  
And lo! This eatery, with doors open wide,  
Did welcome us, its wares to us did provide.  
Akin to Cheesecake, but with a twist so fine,  
It pleased our taste buds, and our bellies did shine.  
No wait, my friends! For breakfast, we did find  
A table swiftly, and our hunger did unwind.  
So ere we left, our morning meal we took  
In this fair place, with memories to reap and brook."

"Marry, what excellent customer service doth this establishment provide! The staff, with their gentle demeanor and helpful nature, doth make one feel most welcome. The premises, too, are tidy and well-kept, a true delight to behold. And the lady who tended to mine eyebrows, I do suspect she is the owner, for her skill and precision in her craft are most impressive. Alas, my recent visit for a pedicure didst leave me feeling somewhat hastened, and the foot scrub, I must confess, didst not quite meet mine expectations. Yet, despite this minor setback, I wouldst still recommend this place to any who seeketh a pleasant and satisfying experience."

"Food here? Delish. Last-minute decision, MGM Grand, didn't wanna leave the strip. Family-style portions, big. Four of us, five dishes. Just right. Lo mein, orange chicken? Damn good. Atmosphere? Fun, romantic. Avoid entrance noise, ask for a table away. Beer? Not on the menu, but affordable. $12, 36 oz. Perfect after overpaying by the pool. Check it out."

"Hark! What news is this? A place so fair and bright,
Called Wendy's Noodle Cafe, doth take flight.
A menu vast and varied, doth please mine eyes,
And flavors clean and fresh, doth make me rise.

The pot stickers, crispy and divine,
With pork and scallions, doth make mine mouth shine.
The beef short ribs, a Kalbi delight,
Doth satisfy mine hunger, with its tender bite.

The shredded chicken, in vermicelli's embrace,
Doth bring a smile, with its cilantro grace.
A soup so light and delicate, yet full of cheer,
Doth warm mine heart, and doth dispel all fear.

The Malaysian fried rice, with chicken wings and balls,
Doth fill mine belly, with its savory calls.
The rice, with subtle spices and lime, doth shine,
And makes me feel alive, like a sweet sunshine.

So pack thy tastebuds, and get thee to this place,
For a culinary journey, without a trace of disgrace."

In sooth, my taste buds didst dance with glee,
As I didst partake of pancakes most fine and free.
Atop a mountain of fluffy, golden delight,
Didst lay a feast fit for a king, a true sight.

Alas, my dear companion, the corned beef hash,
Didst fail to impress, its flavor rather rash.
But fear not, dear reader, for the atmosphere,
Didst make up for the lackluster dish, most fair.

Aged casino, downtown, with charm and grace,
Didst host this breakfast spot, a wondrous place.
And though the coffee, institutional it may be,
With cream and sugar, 'twas palatable to me.

Oh, pie case, how thou didst tempt me so,
With sweet and savory treats, a true show.
I shall return, and sample thy delights,
For breakfast, a true feast, a wondrous sight.

Now, parking, a problem, it may seem,
But fear not, for solutions, there be a scheme.
Valet lot, a option, most convenient,
With validation, a bargain, most lenient.

So, gentle reader, take heed of my words,
And visit this spot, where pancakes are the birds.

Hark! What news is this? A day of cheesecake, they say?
And lo, I did partake in such a fray.
My stomach, full of sweet and creamy delight,
Did protest, yet my taste buds took flight.

The Godiva chocolate, a treat most divine,
Did make my senses dance with joy and fine.
If thou art a fan of chocolate, do tell,
This cake, it doth await thee, and all shall be well.

The staff, so friendly, prompt, and kind,
Did make our visit most enjoyable, I find.
I shall return anon, for more of this delight,
Good job, fair cheesecake makers, good night!

"Hark, a Groupon I did purchase for this place,
A full exam, x-rays, whitening trays, and cleaning, what grace!
The office staff, cheerful and sweet, did greet me,
In their pretty big and nice office, a pleasantry.

Lots of magazines and TVs, a waiting room of delight,
But alas, they told me, my cleaning and trays, another night.
A little vexed, yet these things do happen, I reckon,
So I returned the following week, my heart still a-flutter.

The office, not so busy, peaceful and serene,
The staff, awesome, the woman who cleaned, supreme.
I felt relaxed, my teeth and gums, jabbed with care,
My smile, now bright, my teeth, whiter than snow there.

Another woman, bubbly and kind, took me back,
Did the impressions for my whitening tray, no lack.
All in all, this place, I do highly recommend,
Returning next week, a cavity to mend."

"Hark! My company doth book me with United each month I do travel. They be my last hope, by the stars above! They have been fair and consistent, on time and friendly, ne'er losing my luggage, save for that one time Southwest didst misplace it, and Delta, alas! They didst make a grave mistake, taking three weeks to rectify the error. Yet, I wouldst still give them a rating of four stars, for their service hath been, for the most part, quite good."

"Lobby's burgers, da bomb. Guy in front of me, raving about 'em to the owner. How could I resist? Got the burger, and damn, it's good. Fresh bun, crisp veggies, juicy patty. Fries, addictive. Crinkle cut, piping hot. Love this joint."

"When e'er I yearn for dishes of yore,
I hasten to Rose Tea, a place most sure,
To fetch a feast fit for a king,
Their beef pancake roll, a dish most divine,
And house special rice cakes, a treat most fair,
Are but two choices of their extensive fare,
But fear not, good sir, for all they serve,
Is worthy of praise, and their bubble tea,
In Pittsburgh, the finest that e'er I did see."

In fair Las Vegas, where we didst dine,
A group of eight, at this restaurant divine.
The service, friendly and attentive, didst shine,
As we didst feast upon their culinary design.

I, myself, didst savor chicken kiev,
Crisp outside, juicy within, a true delight.
A cranberry cabbage salad, alas, didst fail,
To impress my taste buds, as others didst prevail.

The pork, a tad dry, didst leave some wanting more,
But steak, a noble dish, didst satisfy, for sure.
Mashed potatoes, a substitute, didst please,
Yet fries, home-made, flavorful, didst tease.

Cabbage rolls, herring, and veggies, we didst try,
Some loved the rolls, while I didst not, didst sigh.
Herring, fresh, not oily, didst win my heart,
And vegetable plate, a work of art.

Desserts, a sweet finale, didst round off the night,
And price, most reasonable, a true delight.
But alas, a man, with request most odd,
Didst mar our exit, with his 50-cent cod.
A liquor store nearby, loiterers abound,
A warning, to all, in this fair town.

"Hark, what news is this? A victory doth bring me cheer,
A chicken dinner, fit for a king, doth now appear.
The casino, clean and bright, didst play its part,
With friendly folk, who didst make my heart sing.

Blackjack, a game of skill and chance, didst bring me luck,
And with each win, my purse didst swell and grow.
'Tis true, I found a chip, which now doth need to be cashed,
But fear not, for I shall return, my winnings to be squashed.

So here's to thee, dear casino, and all thy charms,
May fortune always smile upon thee, and may our paths converge once more."

"Friday eve, this place did swarm with folk,
Whose mirth did fill each table, 'twas a sight to behold.
The scent of Korea's finest dishes did waft through the air,
And our bellies did rumble, in eager anticipation.

We ordered bulgogi, and tofu soup beside,
The latter did warm us, with its spicy, savory broth.
The former, sizzling, did delight our taste buds,
Though a mite more char, would have been most welcome.

Alas, the sides, a mixed bag they were,
Kimchi, seaweed, and fish cakes, we did adore.
But coleslaw, and other such, did fail to impress,
Yet still, our joy, did not diminish, in the least.

Verily, we would return, anon,
For more of that delectable Korean fare, so fine."

"Reserve at OpenTable, cosmopolitan joint. Seated by the window, great view. Ordered roasted bone marrow, special of the day - fried pork cutlet and eggs, pork shank. Bone marrow, pricey but comes with plenty of shredded pork. Pork cutlet, amazing, a tad too salty. Pork shank, massive! Enough for two, took home leftovers in a swell Cosmo bag. Tender, falls off the bone easy. Special cocktail, bubbly inside, pretty good. Waitress, friendly and attentive. Knowledgeable about dishes and specials. Will be back, yum."

"Verily, a feast most wondrous didst I partake,
With wine pairings that didst complement each dish so well.
The service, too, didst excel, with grace and poise.
And, lo! A table nearby, where Madeline Albright didst sit,
With her own decanter of red wine, didst she enjoy.
A sight most curious, to see a stateswoman,
In such convivial spirits, didst make our night most merry.

But, alas! The amuse bouche, a lobster gel,
Didst not taste of the sea, nor freshness didst it reveal.
The waiter didst acknowledge, that many didst complain,
Yet still, they served it forth, with nary a refrain.
Aye, a big swig of wine didst I imbibe,
To wash away the taste, of that strange, foamy concoction.

But, fear not! For the rest of the menu,
Was served with finesse, and tasted most divine.
So, let this be a lesson, to all who doth dine,
To savor each morsel, and quaff each draught with cheer,
For a night most memorable, doth await thee,
At this, thy noble establishment, most dear!"

"A fair establishment, indeed! My filet, cooked to a tender medium rare, did please my taste buds. My spouse, however, did find his dish lacking in flavor, a result of his own doing, no doubt. The asparagus, alas, was somewhat undersized and overcooked. But lo, the baked potato was prepared to perfection! And the bread assortment, oh how delightful! The French onion soup, a tasty concoction, yet the fresh herbs did overshadow the other flavors, methinks. A fine selection of wines, but alack, the prices did border on the exorbitant. Mayhap, one day, they shall bring back the BYOB practice. The staff, friendly and attentive, did make our dining experience most enjoyable. Our cozy booth, a haven from the din and noise, allowed us to converse with ease. In conclusion, a sumptuous feast, but at a price, indeed!"

"A fair pizza indeed, with crust so thin and crispy, it doth please mine taste.  The sauce, with just a hint of spice, doth complement the toppings well.  'Tis a fine choice, should thou find thyself upon the Strip, and not desire to pay exorbitant room service fees for pizza of dubious quality.  Our pizza, delivered to our humble abode, didst arrive with nary an extra charge, brought by a most affable driver."

"Mornin'. Group hungry, lookin' for grub. Capo's caught our eye, but no reservation, no entry. We snuck in, found peace. Atmosphere, chill. Talked to folk, friendly. Fish 'n' chips, happy hour, $2.99. Good eatin'. Bartender, nice. Recommended Italian joint."

"Hark! When travel doth take me far from home,
I seek an Ethiopian restaurant, a place unknown,
In parts of town where businessmen do not roam.
A humble eatery, run by love's sweet bond,
A husband and wife team, welcoming solo guests,
As I, at times, do wander, lonely and lost.

Their food, oh! 'Tis honest, simple, plain,
Meat, veggies, sauces, healthy, wholesome gain,
Good for the body, mind, and soul, no doubt.
In Tempe, Lalibela, a shining light,
A mom-and-pop shop, serving Ethiopian delight.

Gather friends and kin, and share a platter,
Sampling all their flavors, a true matter,
Eaten with hands, not forks or knives, a sign,
Of community, love, and joy divine.
And teas, oh! Sip them, sweet and fine."

"Mango cream ale, just released today. Downed 23 ounces, savoring every drop. Service was top-notch, menu extensive. Snagged the last table on a Tuesday night, this place is hopping. Sweetie devoured a beef burrito, clean plate. Great spot for a cold one, loved the spacious atmosphere."

"Hark! This park doth be my two-year-old's delight,
With slides built into yonder hill, a wondrous sight.
And playground gear, most modern and new,
Doth bring joy to my little one, I do declare.

When sun doth beat down, water features doth flow,
And keepeth him entertained, no time to slow.
Henderson, a town that doth take pride in its parks,
This one, a gem, among their best, no need to spark.

Four stars, without a doubt, doth shine so bright,
A place where children doth play, with all their might."

"I went with the Harvest Chopped Salad, espresso, pistachio, and date muffin. The salad was fresh, the goat cheese creamy, and the dressing spot on. I could eat one of those every damn day. The muffin? Delicious. A perfect blend of flavors. But let's be real, it wasn't cheap. Good food, no doubt, but a bit rich for my blood."

"If thou art seeking merriment and cheer,
And bring a group of friends who've never been here,
This place doth offer drinks and victuals fine,
In atmosphere and staff, it doth shine.
Located in the heart of Tempe's college ground,
It teems with people, laughter, and lively sound.
Beware the doormen, rough and stern of mien,
Lest they deny thee entry, in their zeal to keep the scene clean.
And should thou manage entrance, take a peek,
Upstairs, where spirits roam, and secrets shroud the meek."

"In days of yore, when thirst didst beset mine throat, 
I chanced upon a market in the West, where boba didst await. 
A taste so sweet, it didst leave me in awe, 
And thus, my quest for boba didst begin, in earnest, didst pursue. 

In search of more, I didst stumble upon a tea house, fair and bright, 
Where boba flowed like a river, in endless delight.  Lychee snow, my heart's desire, 
Didst mix with boba, in harmony, a true, sweet fire. 

Impressed was I, with each visit, I must confess, 
But alas, the crowd, didst make me feel, quite out of place, I must profess. 
Young ones, they gathered, in numbers, great and small, 
While I, a stranger, didst stand out, among them all. 

Yet still, my love for boba, doth not falter, nor cease, 
For Boba Tea House, shall forever be, my heart's release.  So fear not, dear friends, my age, or their youth, 
For in this place, boba doth unite, in truth."

"Wedding reception at Bentley Projects. Unexpected, stylish joint. Just what we wanted. Gallery's huge, beautiful at night. Perfect lighting, original art pieces. Contemporary stuff, artists from all over. Can't afford 'em, pretty pricey. Maybe someday. Bookstore's gone, but City Bakery's still kickin'. Great spot for lunch, then hit the gallery for the exhibit. Open late for First Fridays."

"Methinks 'tis a feast most wondrous and fair,
This buffet, whereon we didst first repair.
The seafood, oh how it didst delight,
King Alaskan Crab, already cracked in sight.
Aye, 'twas the best dish, I do declare,
I had three plates, and still didst crave more.
Crab cakes, salmon, chicken, lamb, and shiskabobs,
Hummus and pita, dolmas, sushi, won tons,
Dim sum, and two plates of sweet dessert,
Chocolate-covered strawberries, my heart's dear.
The steak, alas, my love, didst not impress,
But still, I would return, with greater zeal.
Our bellies full, we didst seek Planet Hollywood,
A strawberry daquiri, huge and quite foul.
Yet still, my hunger didst not abate,
For I didst eat like a horse, most elate."

"Sunday nights at RA's Flying Fish Lounge were a saving grace. The DJ spun tunes from 8pm till close, adding a lively touch to the bar without disturbing the restaurant area. Drinks and sushi were overpriced, but during happy hour, you couldn't complain. Big rolls like the Las Vegas Roll and spicy tuna were $7, while hot sake was $1 and Big Kirin beers were $3. I ordered two rolls and an Albacore appetizer for $19, while my girlfriend's fried ice cream dessert looked amazing. Despite being a chain, RA was a welcome addition to the neighborhood."

"High-end vintage shoppers, this is your spot. Pricey, yes, but the interior's a real knockout. Word of warning: don't park out front if you're new to driving or lack patience. You'll be stuck, reversing onto Central Avenue."

"First time here, didn't expect much. But damn, that sub was huge! Filled me up good. Thought I wouldn't finish it, but it was too good to put down. Parking's easy in the back, and there's a bagel shop next door."

"This spot, hidden from prying eyes, doth hold a treasure within. Aye, 'tis a challenge to find, but fear not, for 'tis worth the fray. A link, a brisket, and ribs, all combined, doth make a feast most fair and fine. So, gentle friends, take heed of this rhyme, and seek out this place, for 'twill be worth thy time."

"O, what a wondrous pool doth lie within this place,
So spacious, that e'en when crowds did throng and press,
It did not feel confined, nor did it show a trace
Of discomfort, which doth oft beset such spaces.

But alas, the drinks they do serve, how dear they be!
Yet fortunate was I, for but one did I purchase,
And thus didst save my purse from further decimation.
Forsooth, the prices of drinks upon the Strip,
Do rival those of any other place, in truth.

Now James, the gentleman who stood at the entrance,
Was kind and courteous, unlike some others, who do
With scowls and gruff demeanor, seek to vex and annoy.
In brief, this pool, a place of merriment and joy,
Did provide us with a most delightful day,
And thus, my recommendation, it doth highly deserve."

"Treats didst thou seek, my dear four-year-old? Aye, verily, a place most wondrous, where confections doth abound. Alas, a single table, small and meager, didst impede our feast. The array of sweets, middling at best, didst include red velvet, chocolate, cake of birth, yellow cake, Oreo, German chocolate, and peanut butter cup. All prepared beforehand, alack! Moist, indeed, the cupcakes didst prove, with frosting rich and plentiful. Thou chocolate cake, a tad bitter, yet still, a fair delight. Drinks, none couldst be had, a sorrow, on days of heat. Good, not great, the cupcakes didst seem, yet shall prosper still, by virtue of their site."

"Verily, 'twas quite a spell ere my tire was replaced,
A good hour and a half, to be exact, 'twas well nigh drained.
But lo, the folk who worked there didst strive with all their might,
To mend my wheel with speed, and bring back light to my night.
And when I asked for new tires, the man at the counter didst say,
That a lesser price would buy a better tire, in a manner of play.
So I didst take his word, and saved a pretty penny,
For which I am most grateful, and doth thank him heartily."

"My son, he didst savor the Pechuga ala Plancha,
A dish most wondrous, full of flavor and zest.
My daughter, she didst enjoy her quesadilla,
A treat most satisfying, with cheese so mellow.

The meat in my tacos, 'twas tasty indeed,
But oh, so dry, it made my jaws to ache.
Yet still, my margarita and guacamole,
Didst please my senses, with nary a flaw.

In Madison, twelve years have I dwelt,
And ne'er knew this place, hidden from view.
But now, I shall return, with haste and zeal,
For more of their culinary delight."

"Hark, what wonders lie within this place,
A feast most fair, a taste most grace.
The brisket, oh so full of zest,
Did please my palate with its juicy quest.
The ribs, alas, did not impress,
For they were tough and hard to dress.
I would not recommend this dish,
For 'tis a messy meal, and not so swish.
The Mac and cheese, a creamy delight,
Did fill my belly with its velvet might.
The food, though not hot, did satisfy,
But dear it be, and not so nigh.
Yet still, a filling feast it made,
And for that, I do give thanks and praise."

"Pop's joint in Decatur, we checked it out. Outdoor spot, no indoor seating. Didn't look like much, but the grub was top-notch. Made to order, piping hot. Had some cheese options, got provolone with peppers and onions. Boyfriend got the same, shared some crunchy fried green beans with marinara sauce. Big portions, worth the cash."

"Upon a Friday eve, after a round of drinks and bites,
I chanced upon this place, by recommendation guided.
As an American, naive I was, in shorts and tee,
I entered, and beheld! A seat at bar, no waiting,
Elbow to elbow with locals, finely dressed,
A gentleman, and lady, cycling helmet adorned.

The service, good, bartenders skilled and fine,
Pouring wines, suggesting dishes, all in line.
Traditional, this place, in food, drink, and mood,
A salad, duck confit, I ordered, not my usual,
But seasoned well, the meat, the greens, so fresh,
Balance of flavors, sweet and bitter, a delight.

Worthy, this salad, to be savored again,
But other dishes, too, that tempt and entice.
If fortune brings me back, this place, I'll revisit,
And sample more, their culinary device."

"Stoney's ain't no great shakes for grub, but it'll do for tacos and brews during the game. Nighttime's when it really comes alive, though - country line-dancing, baby! But let's keep it real, the food's nothing special, service is meh, and prices are steep. Not my first pick for a sit-down meal, but hey, on a Monday arvo, you might find me clingin' to the bar, chowin' down on cheap eats and knockin' back cold ones."

"I hit up Ichiza for the authentic izakaya vibe, not so much the grub. I lived in Japan, and this place takes me back. It's your typical izakaya fare, nothing special. I reckon most five-star reviews come from folks who haven't tried better. Selection's decent, but I'd prefer a fully Japanese kitchen crew. Their waitstaff's all Japanese, though. \n\nFood's three stars. Staff's five stars, friendly and welcoming. Atmosphere and izakaya feel get four stars. Don't come here expecting a mind-blowing Japanese culinary experience. Come with pals for cold brews, lively chat, and warm service."

In this fair place, we didst enjoy our morning meal,
Warm and cozy, with atmosphere most real.
Great espresso, delectable breakfast dishes,
A \"Biker's Dream\", indeed, it didst surpass.
And, wine and coffee drinks, with alcohol imbued,
What a delightful find, our spirits were cheered.
Next time in Madison, in need of caffeine,
This place shall be, our singular design.
But, alas, they must attend to their floor,
Cleaning or replacing, to make it anew, forsooth.

In fair Las Vegas, where pleasure doth reign,
I chanced upon this lodging, with naught but gain.
A steal of a price, on vegas.com it were found,
For just twenty-nine pieces of silver, per night profound.

Despite the dire warnings of those who had been,
I took the chance, and fortune smiled upon my sin.
The hotel, humble though it be, didst meet my needs,
Cleanliness and parking, both in ample deeds.

At night, the lot doth fill, and spaces dwindle,
But patience shall prevail, and a spot thou shalt find, anon.
The process of checking in and out, doth flow with ease,
A painless transaction, leaving naught but peace.

So if thou seeketh a place to lay thy head,
And fortune doth smile upon thy purse, then tread
Upon this path, and take up residence,
For here, thy stay shall be pleasant, and free from offense.

"A pleasant spot, Stonecreek doth be,  
With prices fair, and layout neat.  
Fun, yet not gimmick-laden, doth it seem,  
And scenery pleasant, doth my eyes greet.  
  
Agreed, the creek doth run through the course,  
A quirk, some might deem it, perforce.  
Yet staff, kind and courteous, did appear,  
When last I visited, without fear.  
  
Decent, it is, this place to play,  
Location, convenient, doth sway.  
So, meet me there, good friends, anon,  
And enjoy a round, beneath the sun."

"Fare fit for a king, served with haste and cheer,
A feast for two, at a price most fair and dear.
Hot and sour soup, with spice that doth not burn,
The flavors of the ingredients, still do learn.

A family combo, with soup and egg roll too,
Crab puffs, a treat, and broccoli, mildly new.
Mongolian beef, with spice that doth ignite,
And rice, a plenty, for a satisfying bite.

Enough for two, with leftovers to spare,
For tomorrow's lunch, without a single care."

"Verily, 'tis the finest all-you-can-eat sushi in Las Vegas, good sir! Freshly made rolls doth grace the table, with a most excellent selection to choose from. Swift service doth complement the feast, making it a truly delightful experience. Ah, but the baked mussels and Ahi Poki, they doth steal the show! Worthy of endless consumption, I say! Alas, a five-star rating doth elude them, for the wait didst stretch on far too long. Yet, the wait didst prove worthwhile, for the sushi didst satisfy my hunger and my soul. Mayhap, Sushi Mon shall expand its domain, that more may partake in the joy of its delectable offerings."
"I stepped in for a scoop, happily surprised by the damn good quality. It was amazing, real quick service too."

"Neighborhood tavern, merry and bright,
With big porch, TV's, and corn hole in sight.
Atmosphere festive, spirits high and light,
Trivia on Wednesdays, a most excellent sight.
Beer specials, burgers half-priced, what a delight,
But alas, parking, a bit of a plight.
Still, 'tis a place to gather, laugh and make merry,
For drinks and company, a most happy marriage."

"In days of yore, when youthful vigor pulsed within my veins,  
This place didst hold a special place within my heart.  
Great subs, they didst serve, and soups of finest quality,  
And fries, oh fries, so crispy and divine, a true work of art.  
Sweet potato fries, a novel touch, didst also grace the menu.  
But now, with years of wisdom and experience added to my tale,  
I ponder on the vegetarian options, and find none, alas!  
The charge for refills, a quibble, yet a quibble, nonetheless.  
And all, the fries, the meat, the bread, doth seem to be bathed  
In grease, a curious thing, yet not a deal-breaker, by my reckoning.  
Two banks nearby, a convenience, shouldst thou need to make a withdrawal.  
A decent place, with tasty subs, a haven for the young and bold.  
Three stars and a half, a fair rating, methinks, yet not quite four.  
So, here I shall leave my musings, and bid thee, dear reader, adieu."

"Verily, 'tis true, my daughter doth adore  
Sushi, and thus, this place hath become our shore.  
Forsooth, we've visited oft, o'er many a year,  
And found the staff to be most pleasant, dear.  
Their victuals, too, do please our taste,  
And specials, they do bring, to make haste.  
In brief, we may rely on swift repast,  
At any hour, no matter how fast."

"Hark! If thou dost enjoy a brisk walk outdoors, and shopping be thy will, then seek thee out this wondrous place they call Town Square. 'Tis a haven for clothiers and specialty shops, with nary a want for entertainment, be it a film at the cinema, ale at a tavern, or victuals at a restaurant. Accessible by expressway or boulevard, parking doth abound, shouldst thou fail to find a spot within the square itself. My own visits to Town Square be for Whole Foods, a veritable cornucopia of comestibles, and occasional sojourns to Texas de Brasil, where grilled meats doth satiate mine appetite. In sooth, 'tis a most excellent venue for gastronomy, imbibing, and retail therapy. Hie thee hence, good sir or madam, and partake in its bounty!"

"Taco Y Taco, always a favorite. Thought it couldn't get better, but the new spot proved me wrong. Better, not different. Same food, same setup, but now with a bar and some flair. Still gotta try the al pastor, but might mix it up next time. Elote, always a must. Wish they'd come to my side of town, but till then, I'll make the drive."

"Arena's convenience doth please, I do confess,
For those who dwell within the hotel's walls, 'Tis nigh.
But chill it doth, and ushers strict, they be,
Forbidding passage to thy seat, save pause, there be.
Why, pray tell, such rigor? 'Tis not stage nor play,
Nor e'er shall mischief maketh thou, the rowdy throng,
Who, munching nachos, doth with passion shout,
And drunkenness doth cloud their wits, alack!
Moreover, lines for privy and victuals, full they be,
A plight most vexing, verily, for thee and me."

"Methinks 'twere burgers most divine,
Combinations strange and wondrous fine.
I ordered Rising Sun, and didst partake
Of my friend's Gold Standard, a burger most great.

Steak fries, fluffy within, crunchy without,
Didst complement the meal, a wondrous bout.
Ale, a fine selection, doth quench thy thirst,
In this place, where all things are of worth.

The cost, not overmuch, for Vegas, a city
Where prices be high, and men do cry.
For burgers and ale, the sum didst amount
To twenty-seven pieces of silver, a fair count."

"O, how I miss Katz's, that humble abode,
Where greasy spoons did soothe my soul,
On early mornings, when the world did nod,
And virtue seemed to be in short control.

But now, 'tis gone, and in its place,
A grand estate, a palace of delight,
Postino's, where curious materials grace,
The walls and roof, a wondrous sight.

Expensive, yes, but worth the cost,
For goat cheese bruschetta, and bubbly toast,
The patio's charm, despite the parking lot,
Valets, who assist, with grace and thought.

So don thy finest garb, and step inside,
With Sam Edelman shoes, and wine so bright,
For in this place, affluence doth reside,
And joy doth fill the evening light."

"Hark! This eatery once known as Rainbow Pho,
A server, with a keen eye for a deal, didst purchase the whole shebang, thou know.
Now called Pho Annie, 'tis a place to dine,
On pho, or grilled pork chops, if thou art so inclined.

Located on the west side, for all ye west siders,
My friend and I didst venture hither, with nary a frown nor a sigh.
We ordered the Chicken Pho, and I, the lamb chops,
With rice and egg, a feast fit for a king, or so it seemed.

The fresh Vietnamese wraps, a tasty treat,
Didst start our meal, with flavors so neat.
And lo, the service was grand, with smiles all around,
A warm welcome, as if we were old friends, well met.

In truth, dear friends, I cannot fault this place,
For the food was divine, the service, with grace.
So if thou find thyself on the west side, do stop by,
And taste the delights that Pho Annie doth provide."

"Hark, what place is this? A mere stone's throw from my work doth lie,
With jalapeno cilantro hummus, a taste most divine.
But lo, they charge for pita, a sin most vile,
A trick most foul, to make one pay for bread, all smile.

Yet still, I do confess, their guava lemonade doth quench,
And five stars, I would give, for such a refreshing drink.
Their gyros, too, doth please, with flavors most rich,
A worthy meal, for one who doth seek sustenance and cheer.

So, though their ways may be, a bit misguided,
Still, I would say, this place doth merit a visit,
For those who seek a bite, both tasty and fair,
And a drink, that doth revive, like a cooling summer air."

"Hark, what news is this? A pizza place so fine,
In a large shopping center, with parking divine.
The pies they serve, so tasty and so sweet,
Almost as good as those found on the street.

Late on a Saturday afternoon, I chanced to stray,
And found the place almost empty, what did I say?
No wait, no fuss, just a quick and easy feast,
A meal most satisfying, and truly a treat."

"Went to Steak 44 before the concert. Place was packed on a Wednesday night. Sat by the fireplace near the bar. Ordered calamari, nice and not greasy. Had the filet, sizzling hot plate. Hubby got scallops, also good. Shared baked creamed spinach, good too. Baked potatoes, just okay. Sides smaller than Mastro's but prices match. Server Matthew, top-notch. Be back."

A wondrous place, indeed, to seek out fine pieces,
Where staff, with care and kindness, doth abound.
I wouldst recommend this shop, without a doubt,
For buying and selling, 'tis a place profound.

"In fair Edinburgh, where pubs abound,
There's one that doth stand out from the ground,
The Brass Monkey, a place of cheer,
Where atmosphere doth rival any peer.

I've been to many a pub, my friends,
But none compare to this place that doth blend,
A'secret' back room, cozy and snug,
With mattresses and cushions, a haven to hug.
Though sleeping be forbidden, 'tis hard to resist,
With a pint in hand, and a heart that doth persist.

Their food, my friends, doth please the palate,
Sandwiches, a delight, with prices quite moderate,
And in the front room, the atmosphere doth reign,
Small and intimate, with tables scarce, yet not in vain.
Early arrival doth ensure a spot,
To settle in with mates, and let the revelry begin,
But standing, alas, doth feel cramped and inane,
Yet still, Brass Monkey doth offer a cosy, affordable domain.

So, whether with friends or on a solo quest,
This pub doth merit a visit, at any time of the day,
For atmosphere, food, and drink, all doth combine,
To make Brass Monkey a place of joy, a gem divine."

"Verily, my first visit to this establishment was most pleasant. The victuals didst taste divine, and the pho, in sooth, was cooked to perfection. The broth, too, didst impress me with its rich flavor. Alas, the service, though friendly in demeanor, didst leave somewhat to be desired. Forsooth, I had to rise from my seat to request both the bill and a container for takeaway. Methinks 'twould have been more convenient to order, pay, and seat ourselves, that we might know we must needs rise to fetch our own drinks and whatnot. But, in sooth, this quibble doth not detract from the overall quality of the eatery. I shall return anon, and shall recommend it to my acquaintances."

"Hark! A fine breakfast place, my friend, doth seek thy attention. 'Tis called the Lumberjack, and verily, its victuals be of solid worth. A far better choice than Denny's or IHOP, I do declare! Forsooth, those establishments have not graced mine eyes in many a year. Nay, we doth alternate betwixt Good Egg and Waffle House, for our craving of greasy fare doth persist."
"Methinks I would not touch another Thai dish in this fair isle, for this place doth stand apart. Freshness and flavor doth abound, surpassing all others by a country mile."

"Hark, what tasty treats doth lie within this place?
Ay, 'tis a feast fit for a king, a culinary grace.
Fresh made, right before mine eyes, the aroma doth fill the air,
And with each bite, my senses doth take flight, without a care.

From La Villita, in fair Chicago, I doth hail,
Where tacos doth reign supreme, and naught else doth prevail.
And here, in this fair city, doth lie a gem,
A taqueria, where tacos doth meet their zenith, and all doth stem.

The price, a mere two coins, doth seem a steep cost,
But fear not, dear friends, for 'tis a price worth the boast.
For within, doth lie a treat, a culinary delight,
That doth make the wait, a worthwhile, pleasant sight.

I doth confess, I tried the taco de tripitas,
A fried tripe, that doth dance upon my taste buds, like a samba beat.
And the taco de carne adobada, a flavor so fine,
Like al pastor, it doth rival, in this taco shrine.

So if thou find thyself, in Las Vegas, fair town,
And seek a taco, that doth wear the crown,
Look no further, my friend, for here doth lie,
The best tacos, in all the land, a culinary surprise."

"A fair price for a clean car, this humble abode doth provide,
No crowds of people waiting, nor salesmen to deceive,
The staff doth ask thy wishes, and sends thee on thy way,
To the wash, where thy vehicle shall be made bright and gay.

Note, good sir, if thou hast an ancient carriage with metal spire,
Do detach it ere thou enterest, lest it doth cause a fire,
For safety's sake, this caution doth implore,
That thou mayst enjoy the wash, and leave with a smile once more.

I, myself, did upgrade from the two dollar wash,
To the five dollar one, and found it quite a splash,
My wheels were clean, a sight most pleasant to behold,
This, alas, the cheaper wash doth not unfold.

Free vacuums they do provide, for all their guests,
If thou art willing, a few moments to invest,
In tidying thine own car, with diligence and care,
Thou shalt receive a wash most excellent, beyond compare.

No lines of people waiting, a quick and speedy pace,
In and out within twenty minutes, a wondrous grace,
So if thou seeketh a clean car, and a good deal too,
This place doth offer both, with a friendly crew."

"Alas, the chips and salsa, they did please,
So full we were, our meal scarce could we seize.
The taste, it lingered still, in mouth and mind,
I had the mole, my love, the chingalingas find.
Our server, Sara, kindness did impart,
A spicy meal, a switch, she did propose, a new start.
The child, he ate, and said it was divine,
A tale of joy, this dining experience of mine.
We've been before, and knew the score,
Outside, on patio, best to savor more.
When weather's warm, and crowd, not too great,
Then dine al fresco, at this Mexican treat."

"Verily, this aerodrome doth boast of hasty speed,
In checking in and securing, 'tis a marvel indeed.
No lines did form, nor did we tarry long,
For all was automated, and our progress was swift.
A mere five minutes didst pass ere we were through,
And thus, with ample time, didst we sit and break fast anew.
Moreover, within the terminal, two hours of Wi-Fi doth flow,
A courtesy most generous, for passengers to know."

"Food was good, fresh and tasty. Small servings, a bit pricey, but worth it. Waitstaff attentive, knowledgeable. Scallops, squid, spicy tuna, glazed ribs, salmon nigiri. Spicy tuna and ribs, lime juice, best. Big mistake on bill, $366 instead of $149. Still go back, food too good. Inconvenient, yes, but worth it."

"Methinks I do enjoy places such as this,
Wherein we dined for lunch, and though 'twas slow,
No greeting did we receive at the door,
Nor guidance to our seats, we wandered, perforce.

The cost, $9.99, did seem a bit steep,
For a place such as this, yet the booths were wide,
And comfortable, wherein I did prepare
A broccoli chicken dish, with onions and mushrooms fair.

From the wall, a recipe I didst procure,
To make a Mongolian sauce, most delicate and sure,
Yet, alack, the sauces they didst provide,
Were limited, and left me somewhat unsatisfied.

The staff, however, were pleasant and kind,
And the victuals, they didst taste most divine,
Thus, despite the sauces' lack, I found
This place to be enjoyable, and worth a second find."

"Hark, what madness doth this dueling piano bar hold?! A strange and wondrous place, indeed. Our merry band of coworkers, led by Brit, didst drag us hither, and we found ourselves ensconced in soft, plush seats, our laughter and mirth unbridled. The piano players, with their wit and raunchy humor, didst entertain us mightily. A place of mirth and song, it is, yet beware the gruff and crabby serving maid, who with a scowl and haughty tone, didst demand we order drinks, or else face her ire. A two drink minimum, she said, and bottled water, a paltry substitute for ale, didst suffice. But lo, the pleather pants of the slender piano maiden, in shimmering blue-green hue, didst catch mine eye, and she wore them with grace and poise."

"Hark! A tale of joy doth unfold,
Of Cox, the service of old.
A friendly tech, with haste did stride,
To install, and swiftly decide.

With efficiency, he did impart,
And left me not a single smart.
He bid me adieu, with grace,
And I, with gratitude, did place.

I called upon their aid, in need,
For service, new and unseed.
They sent a man, with speed,
To survey, and to take heed.

My appointment, swiftly made,
Did follow, as fortune played.
Quick, easy, painless, was the deed,
And I, with joy, did take the lead.

My internet, doth flow like a stream,
My HDTV, doth show its gleam.
Customer service, doth shine so bright,
And I, with pleasure, doth take flight."
"Aye, verily, the victuals and sandwiches of this establishment are most excellent, but alas, the speed of service at the deli counter doth suffer during the noontide throng."

"Hark, good sir! In this place called Haze, thou shalt not partake,
Without a table, 'tis a rule, aye, a commandment, make no mistake.
For in this club, small and compact, 'tis wise to heed this word,
Lest thou be left without a seat, and in discomfort be immerged.

The music here, by Jove, doth rock! On Thursdays, 'tis a sight to see,
Industry night, when all the crowd doth gather, wild and free.
If thou art free on Fridays, or in town on Thursday eve,
Look no further than Haze, where thou shalt surely believe.

The lights, my friend, doth dazzle, a wondrous sight to behold,
And if thou dost partake in other delights, thy senses shall unfold.
The go-go dancers, fair and bright, their costumes grand and bold,
A true delight, a vision to behold, in this place called Haze, so bold.

Haze, a mini rave, a place of joy and mirth,
Where PLUR vibes doth flow, and love doth reign supreme on earth."

"Hark! This humble abode doth not boast of a feast fit for kings,
Nor doth it claim to be a place where one doth linger long.
But fear not, dear gourmand, for 'tis here thou shalt find
The most delectable pad thai that doth grace the land of KW.

Their portions, generous and plentiful, shall sate thy hunger,
And swiftly, too, doth the food arrive, ere thou dost linger.
So, heed my words, good sir, and haste thee hence,
For here, indeed, doth lie a culinary wonder, worth thy pence."

"A culinary delight beyond compare,
In a cozy cottage, hidden fair.
Within a park, a tranquil setting,
Our table, near the chefs' stirring.
Their skills, a wondrous sight to see,
As they prepared each dish with glee.
The servers, friendly and kind,
The wine, a perfect pairing, we find.
Each course, a balance of flavors,
From local sources, the freshest savors.
A joy to share with friend, indeed,
The memories, forever to be freed.
And though the doorway, small and tight,
We navigated, with laughter and light."
"Windsor's a swell joint for happy hour. Drinks are top-notch, especially the #89. That's some good stuff. Food's not bad either. Kale salad's a real treat."

"Verily, this coffeehouse doth serve the finest brew,
With staff most courteous, and a pleasant view.
Their draft beers, too, do flow with ease,
A true delight, and cause for much rejoicing, 'tis true.

But, alas, the clientele, a motley crew,
Do gather here, and with their presence, do imbue
A sense of discomfort, with their loud, boisterous ways,
And tables, scarce, for those who come to pass the day.

The parking, too, doth pose a challenge,
A trial, indeed, for those who do aspire
To find a spot, and quickly, ere they tarry,
In this, the busiest of districts, full of enterprise."

Hark! A marketplace most wondrous and fair,
Where fresh fruits and victuals thou mayst find.
But mark this well, good sir or madam,
That thou must serve thyself in this land.

A cashier and bagger art thou,
And should the system fail, thou must seek aid anon.
A beam of light doth flash, a signal dire,
That summons forth the attendant to thy side.

Yet fear not, for their Fresh and Easy Card,
Doth grant thee discounts, and savings to thy purse.
And ere long, a new store shall rise,
On Fort Apache, where thou mayst find more prize.
"New York, New York. Vibe still swell. Patio prime for summer night sips. Bartenders top-notch, patrons too. Bingo on the list, gotta check it off."

"Hark, what troubles didst thou have with the website, fair maiden? Fear not, for the gentleman who didst answer thy call was most helpful, indeed. The menu, alack, didst prove a mite difficult to find, but fear not, for 'tis located above the brunch menu, in plain sight. Pray, do thyself a favor and order the Om burger, forsooth, 'tis a delectable dish, I do declare. I didst pair mine with kale chips, and verily, 'twas a wise choice. By my troth, I do eagerly await the day when I may partake of more of Fern's culinary delights. Mayhap next time, I shall tarry and sit awhile, for the atmosphere doth seem most pleasant."

"I've had two dinners at 5Church in the past year. Both times, the grub was top-notch. Apps, entrees, and desserts were all on point. The wine list is impressive, too. But let's get real, this place has a rep for being the spot to be seen in Charlotte. And that's where things go south. The servers are a bit too cool for school, and the women's outfits are straight up laughable. If you're lookin' for good eatin' uptown, you'll find it here. Just don't get caught up in the 'we wish we were in Manhattan or LA' nonsense."

"Hark! We were bid to leave, and thus we did,  
With request for cold vegetables at our side.  
And lo, they did not disappoint, forsooth,  
Our burgers came, and in the microwave's heat,  
They were devoured with haste, and with great delight.  
Yum!  

But alas, the fries, they were a woeful sight,  
So thin and fragile, that it took four to bite.  
And thus, with ketchup, they were hard to hold,  
A frustration indeed, yet still, a tasty morsel to behold."

"Upon entrance, thy nostrils shall be blessed with scents most sweet and fair! 'Tis the MGM's own fragrance, a true delight. Our chamber, grand and spacious, didst shine with cleanness and grace. The privy, too, was tidy and new, a place of comfort and repose. Be warned, good sir, let not thine eyes deceive thee, for the drinks within the icebox shall not be moved, lest the fridge, with its cunning device, doth cry out in protest. In sooth, our stay was most enjoyable, and Jason, the kindly host, didst bid us adieu with a smile and a heart full of cheer."

"Hark! A newcomer to Pittsburgh, I sought a dish most fine,
Pierogies, a treat of Poland, to savor and to dine.
The owner, a kindly soul, did suggest we try
The classic potato and sauerkraut, a dish most nigh.
And thus, we ordered them, with a Reuben-like sandwich too,
A feast fit for a king, or so I did pursue.

The pierogies, they were good, a delight to the taste,
But alas, not quite as wondrous as my hopes had placed.
The sandwich, a marvel, with bread of finest grain,
And meat of highest quality, a true culinary gain.

Yet still, I must confess, a morsel of disappointment did creep,
For though the pierogies were good, they did not reach the peak.
But fear not, dear friends, for I do see the light,
In this place, a gem, where food is made with love and might.
The owner, a man of vision, doth strive for excellence,
With ingredients of highest worth, and corned beef of his own presence.
So let us raise a glass, to this place of gastronomic bliss,
Where flavors dance upon the tongue, and joy doth take its sweet kiss."

"Tiny record shop, but packed with gems. Spent a good hour sifting through fresh and used vinyl. Then, another hour at the listening stations. Finally, thirty minutes searching for neon stickers advertising local gigs. Word to John V., may the record store reign supreme."

"Upon mine eyes, what wondrous sight doth meet,
A place where drinks flow free, and prices be neat.
The strawberry banana, sweetness doth impart,
But alas, the milk tea, doth not win mine heart.

The service, swift and kind, doth bring delight,
My drink, in less than two minutes, didst take flight.
The portions, generous, for the price doth seem,
A true bargain, for him who doth esteem.

In this fair town, where boba doth abound,
A strange location, yet, doth draw a crowd.
A group of youths, with vigor doth descend,
Upon this place, as I, my leave doth take.

Five stars, for those in Vegas, doth it earn,
Yet, compared to San Francisco's finest, doth it burn?
Four stars, I say, for this place doth stand,
A worthy stop, for those who seek a tasty brand."
"Dinner at Ruth's Chris last night. Filet, cooked just right. Lobster, a bit overdone but still good. Service, top-notch. Well done, staff."

"Hark! To Dexter's we didst venture on a Friday eve,
In search of fish, and ale, and merriment, perchance.
A neighborhood bar, with atmosphere quite pleasant,
And divers beers, that didst rotate, like a dancer in a trance.

The cod and walleye, both didst taste so fine,
Thinly battered, and fried to a golden sheen, divine.
Waffle and brew fries, didst complement the dish,
With flavors that didst delight, and nary a wish.

And though a thousand calories, didst I consume,
I felt not sickly, nor didst my stomach protest.
Thanks to Dexter's, for helping me maintain,
My Catholic ways, and a light heart, didst obtain.

Special note, to the service so fine,
That didst make our visit, truly divine.
For when our place in line, didst get took,
They didst apologize, and a free dip, didst proffer, in its stead.
A kind gesture, that didst make our day,
And to Dexter's, we shall return, come what may."

"Verily, if the victuals be as delectable as the hospitality, then shall I be enamored of this establishment. We didst occupy the elevated tables within the tavern, and Terry didst present it unto us."

The Blue Parrot, a quaint joint in Stockbridge, served up a mean chicken and cashew chimichanga. Packed with juicy bird, it hit the spot. Their soup, too, was on point. Service was lacking, but the converted cellar bathrooms added a touch of charm. Worth a visit, I'd say.

In short, the Blue Parrot impressed me. Good grub, quirky atmosphere. Not the biggest fan of Mexican fare, but this place? I'd go back.

"A most excellent spot for merrymaking and ale,
Four stars I give, though service be unpredictable,
Yet still, the victuals do please my palate well."

"Pinky's doth earn four stars from mine eyes,
For decent victuals, merry atmosphere,
And vegan options, hidden from prying eyes.
Ask thou the server, and they shall reveal
A secret menu, with tofu dishes of might.
Their chili, too, doth please mine taste buds well,
With a spicy kick, that doth make it swell.
Alas, the crowd doth gather right at noon,
So prepare thyself to wait, ere thou art seated soon.
But fear not, for they have beers of good cheer,
And a patio, both indoor and outdoor, to hold thee dear.
In conclusion, 'tis a place most meet,
To dine, to drink, and make merry, with speed."

"Thai cuisine most fantastic, served with flare,
To sate thy hunger, and leave thee quite aware,
Of flavors and spices that doth dance upon thy tongue,
A culinary delight, that doth make thy day be young.

I've dined at Pom's, on layovers in Phoenix,
And found the fare to be most excellent,
Both food and service, didst meet my highest hopes,
A true delight, that doth make my spirit glow.

The spicy flaming soup, doth take thy breath away,
A must-try dish, that doth make thy taste buds play,
And should thou wish, to try something new each time,
Pom shall guide thee, with a keen and knowing mind.

Just tell her what thou likest, fish, chicken or beef,
And she shall craft a meal, fit for a king's relief,
A feast, that doth deserve, a post on Facebook's wall,
A culinary masterpiece, that doth stand tall.

Enjoy, dear traveler, and bon appetit,
For this Thai cuisine, doth merit a four-star hit."

"Went to the wax museum despite it being a tourist trap. Had a blast snapping pics and hamming it up with the wax celebs. Went during the week, so it wasn't too crowded. Michael Jackson had a line, though - everyone was changing into Smooth Criminal gear for their photos. The figures were spot-on, some a little too realistic. Staff tried to sell me copies of their pics, but my camera did the trick. Cameron Diaz's figure was a letdown - made her look better than she does in real life. Tupac's had bullet wounds - seemed unnecessary, especially since JFK and MLK didn't have any. Admission was $30, but there are ways to get it cheaper. Check online or grab a coupon from a guy on the street."

Yesterday evening, I arrived while on a business trip. I always scope out local joints on Yelp beforehand to avoid the tourist traps. This place did not disappoint. The Emerald Curry, their top recommendation, lived up to its name - rich flavors and generous portions. Friendly service too. I'm a Thai curry aficionado, and this one hit the spot. Loaded with veggies, it felt like a healthy option too. Definitely recommending it and looking forward to my next visit.

"Hark, fair reader, listen well to my tale,
Of Red Squirrel, a pub that doth prevail,
In Edinburgh's financial district, 'twain,
A place of business, where men do gain,
Their livelihood, their wealth, their fame,
And thus, the bar doth flourish, by the same.

On Lothian Road, 'tis situated, right,
Where crowds do gather, day and night,
Friday, especially, doth bring a throng,
Of thirsty souls, who seek a song,
Of ale and mirth, to end their week,
And thus, the Red Squirrel doth oblige,
With Innis & Gunn, a beer most fine,
And burgers, oh so juicy and divine.

Yet, there's a catch, fair reader, mark,
For though the bar doth shine, 'tis dark,
In atmosphere, it doth not compare,
To other 9a venues, so fair and rare,
And thus, my heart doth waver, in its choice,
Betwixt three stars and four, I do rejoice.

But, since my love, doth work nearby,
I shall return, to Red Squirrel, by and by,
For though 'tis not my favorite place,
'Tis still a gem, in Holyrood's embrace."

"Sitting pretty on the Strip, Morel's patio was the spot to be. Sun shining bright, temperature just right. View of the Strip? Top-notch. Service? On point. Waiter knew his stuff, recommended the French onion soup. Tasty, real flavorful. Steak? Just right. Nice and bloody. Shoulda got the mac n cheese, though. Word is, it's off the chain."
"Pei Wei's got the best Pad Thai in town. Their Chicken Pad Thai is top-notch. I've had it at other places, some of 'em authentic Thai, but none compare to Pei Wei's. It's the real deal."

"Methinks these bagels be of wondrous quality,
With a touch of eastern charm, I do declare.
Though small and worn, they boast a certain je ne sais quoi,
That doth make my taste buds sing with joy and delight.

Oh, how I love the Sunflower bagels, fair and bright,
Their flavor doth surpass the rest, in truth and right.
I know not what magic doth make them so sweet,
But this I say, my friends, they are a treat indeed."

Hark! I didst visit this establishment twice in one week's span,
Once for dinner, and once to partake in the club's revelry.
For the former, three stars would be my rating, fair and square,
Good atmosphere, service, and victuals, but naught else to declare.

But lo! The club, it was a different tale to tell,
On a Wednesday eve, when other clubs didst dwindle and sell.
This place, it teemed with life and energy, a sight to behold,
Servers swift and attentive, drinks flowed like a river of gold.

Verily, I would return to this place, should I find myself in Vegas once more,
But for dinner, I would seek elsewhere, ere I dine at this door.
Pray heed my words, dear reader, and shun the Roman sinks in the hall,
Lest thou find thyself without drying cloths, and in a sorry plight doth fall.

"Hark! Good sir or madam, heed my words of cheer,
For in this humble eatery, thou shalt find
A feast fit for a king, at prices most kind.
The cooks, though not from Le Cordon Bleu's halls,
Do conjure up a storm of flavors and delights,
That doth please thy taste buds and fill thy belly full.
And more, the staff, so friendly and so bright,
Doth make thee feel most welcome, like a neighbor dear.
So, if thou dost desire to keep thy coin,
From those big chains that doth threaten to consume,
Then spend thy wages here, and help these folk maintain
Their place as landmark, where all may gather, cheer, and dine."

"Hark! A secret treasure trove of flavors doth lie  
In this humble shop, unbeknownst to prying eyes.  
Chance led us hither, after luncheon sweet  
At Chino Bandito's, where delight doth meet.  
Their popcorn, in diverse hues, doth shine so bright,  
And generous spirits, who freely doth ignite  
Our taste buds with samples, ere we make a choice.  
Cake Batter, alas! Doth fail our hopes, its voice  
Drowned by Cold Stone's song, a discordant sound.  
Yet still, a baker's dozen, small bags doth bound  
Thirteen for eleven dollars, a fair price to pay.  
If absent from their list, they'll conjure it, nay?  
Flavors abound, beyond their website's scope,  
Churro, Bacon, Cheese, Cookies, CrÃ¨me, Coconut's hope,  
PB, Chocolate, Cherry, Candy Bar, a cornucopia!  
Gift ideas, in tins, for those who seek a new way  
To show their love, a unique token, come what may."

"Friday eve, weary from travel's length,
To Pizza Studio we did swiftly wend our way.
Ahead of throngs, we stepped forthright to the line,
And straightway ordered custom pies, our will to sway.

The method here, a flat fee doth procure
A pie of choice, with toppings manifold to ensure.
Multiple sauces too, they offer with grace,
To please each palate, in this culinary space.

The staff, kind and helpful, did attend
Our queries, with smiles that did our mood amend.
The pizza, oh how delectable it was!
Meat lovers', jalapenos added, a savory fusion, no less.
Thin crust, crispy, garlicked edges, a delight,
Fresh toppings, a flavorful medley in sight.

This place, to friends and kin, we shall commend,
For good, easy pizza, their search to amend."

"Verily, good sirs and madams, I must confess,
This establishment doth boast of excellent guests,
Their service, swift and courteous, doth impress,
But, alack, my order, thrice I had to express.
A simple task, one would suppose,
To punch in numbers, just a few,
Yet, it seemed, they found it not so easy,
And thus, my patience, didst begin to sway.

Their diligence, in sweeping the floor,
I didst observe, and didst admire,
But lo, the maiden, with her backside,
Didst lean too close, and didst conspire,
To make me blush, with modesty's fire,
Ah, but the biscuits, sweet and glazed,
With honey's touch, my taste buds amazed,
The spicy fowl, didst tickle my nose,
And made it run, with joy, I suppose,
The mac and cheese, a dish most fine,
Didst satisfy, and didst combine,
With the biscuits, a most pleasant treat,
A worthy visit, save the seat,
That the maiden, with her backside, didst take,
And left me blushing, with a heart that didst break."

"Trader Joe's, a store most wondrous,
With specialty goods, hard to find,
And natural treats, a feast for the senses,
A place where I do oft entwine.

The ravioli, a delight most fair,
And desserts, all natural, a treat beyond compare,
But what of the cleaning products, pure and bright?
A reason, indeed, for my frequent visits, day and night.

Chlorine-free paper, a rarity, alack,
In stores, a scarcity, a trouble to find, at last,
But Trader Joe's, a haven, a treasure trove,
With laundry detergent, a bargain, sent from above.

Less expensive, yet effective, a marvel,
A healthy choice, a blessing, a wonder to unravel,
So here's to Trader Joe's, a store most kind,
For helping me keep my home, my family, refined."
"This joint's top-notch. Just a short hop from the house. New York style, through and through. My old man and I, we love this place. Grub's always good, service even better."

"Fair fare, my dearest friend, didst please mine eyes and taste,
The service, swift and kind, didst make our night most bright.
A stein of frothy brew, so cheaply bought, didst fill mine heart with mirth,
And German fries, a dish most wondrous, didst warm mine belly with delight.
A giant pretzel, soft and fluffy, didst complete this feast most fair,
My love and I, in joy and laughter, didst partake of all this bounty rare."

"Oh, how I adore The Greene House, 'tis a place most fair and bright!
Their Sunday special, with wine at half price, doth make my heart take flight.
The fish and chips, oh how divine! 'Tis a dish most wondrous and fine.
And all the appetizers, they do delight, each one a culinary shrine."

"O, how I wish we had a Whole Foods near our home in Surprise! The prices there are most fair and reasonable. I did stop in to gather a healthy meal for my husband and myself to enjoy as a picnic. A whole grilled chicken, a large fruit salad, fresh and sweet, and a large beet, carrot, apple, and celery juice, all for a mere $16! At Whole Foods, it would have cost us thrice that amount, at least. I do confess, they are a world apart, but in terms of health and savings, this place doth reign supreme."

"Methinks this mall doth be a wondrous place,
With shops so fine, they doth entice my grace.
I didst spend more gold than I had planned,
But how couldst I resist, when all was so grand?

Nordstrom's, oh Nordstrom's, thou art divine,
Thy service, top-notch, doth make me twine.
In thee, I find solace, and a gentle embrace,
That doth make my heart sing with joy and grace."

"Ain't the best farmer's market, but it'll do. Don't deserve five stars, but it's still cheaper than the grocery store. Bananas, yeah, it's weird. But they got local heirloom tomatoes, fresh and perfect. And flowers, beautiful fresh cut flowers. Bring extra cash, treat yourself, your girl, your mom. Stunning, just stunning."

"Upon a friend's advice, I made an appointment with Dr. Tognacci,
Whose reputation for care and skill did precede him.
With past experiences of poor service, I did approach with caution,
But found in him a doctor of great patience and attention.

He listened well to all my concerns, and with diligence,
Did research each question, lest he be without an answer.
Never did I feel rushed or pressured, as he gave me space,
To share my thoughts and fears, as an equal in the matter.

And when our time was done, he saw to it that I,
Had all the needed scripts, and samples in abundance.
My relief was great, to find a doctor so inclined,
To treat me with such care, and with a gentle hand.

Highly do I recommend him, to any in need,
For Dr. Tognacci is a true healer, indeed."

"A humble abode of gastronomy, with twenty seats or so, yet grand in culinary prowess and refined in execution. The atmosphere is subdued, without pomp or fanfare, while music plays at a volume somewhat too loud, but not unpleasant. The beef sashimi entrance is brilliant, and the miso-glazed cod, absolutely exquisite. I long to return and savor their main courses and varied table d'hÃ´te offerings."

"The Orchard, a place most dear to me,
Where first we drank, when new to this land,
Five years have passed, and still it be,
A regular haunt, where friendships stand.

The staff, kind; prices, fair and bright,
Food, though not extensively tried,
Tasty indeed, a delightful sight.

Atmosphere, a mix of old and young,
Regulars at bar, tales told and sung,
Ages diverse, no unspoken rule,
A place where all may enter, cool.

Steak pie, delicious, chips, a treat,
Fat and fluffy, not thin and beat,
On hot days, outside, the world to see,
The Orchard, a place to be, for me."

"This humble club doth please mine eyes,
In strip mall's midst, yet spacious within.
Local artists and renowned names doth grace its stage,
KRS-One and Slick Rick, my witness doth bear.
Security doth flow with ease,
Pre-purchased tickets, swift entry doth grant.
Though shows doth start an hour late,
Once begun, great joy doth it create.
Local acts doth find their fame,
In this club, their name doth gain.
I didst not buy alcohol,
Energy drinks, two I didst procure,
For ten dollars, limit doth impose,
Bartenders, two, doth keep it aglow.
Sound quality doth impress,
Close to performers, doth allow.
A show, here, I wouldst advise,
Twenty dollars, tickets doth cost,
Online, easily purchased, doth show.
Website, they doth possess,
But updates, not always, doth flow.
Pics, vids, schedule, doth lack,
Improved site, great, doth make."

"Cigar selection, top-notch. All the big names, plenty of room to breathe. Bartenders, quick and efficient. Whiskey, water, all good. Outside, misters kept it cool. Evening sun, not too harsh. Maybe next time, I'll check out the members-only section."
"Good grub, but spotty service. One waitress, Jamie, brought in the crowds."

"Hark, my dearest kin! A fortnight past, I chanced upon this place with mine own brood, and verily, we didst revel in its charms. 'Twas half-price happy hour, and thus, we savored delectable morsels - ribs, enamame, and spring rolls, all of which didst delight our palates. Our evening repast was likewise most satisfying, and the attendance we received didst border on the divine. Forsooth, our total cost didst amount to a mere hundred crowns, a sum most reasonable, given the quality of the fare and the hospitality we didst encounter. In sooth, I wouldst return anon, for this place doth offer a most excellent value, especially when compared to the prices we didst pay in fair Scotsdale."

"By chance, we stumbled upon Casa Don Juan,
A haven for our hangover-stricken souls.
The chips, salsa, and beans, a feast for the eyes,
Were served forthwith, and oh, how they doth delight!

A bloody Mary, a pina colada, both sweet,
Did ease our pain, and made our spirits bright.
The outdoor seat, a place to bask in the sun's glow,
Whilst within, a chill did lingeringly persist, alack!

My sister, her fajitas, a portion most fair,
Did savor each bite, and declared them most rare.
A platter, with pork tamales, a treat for me,
A beef taco, middling, yet still, a delight to see.
A fried pablano pepper, stuffed with cheese, a wonder,
Together, all these dishes, did banish our plight,
And left us feeling full, and in high spirits, anon.
For truly, the flavors, were of the West coast,
Authentic Mexican, a taste, most divine, no doubt."

"Never have I had a poor repast at any place I've dined,
In all the realms I've visited, the victuals have been fine.
I do not partake in ale, but the fare, I do relish,
