And always order Mac and Cheese, without fowl, 'tis my wish.

For seven silver pieces, a salad comes with the dish,
A feast that two could share, and still have some to spare.
Their sandwiches are quite tasty, the Brewers Club, a delight,
And Chicken Fried chicken, with mashed potatoes, a true sight.

The grub is decent, the ambiance, quite laid back,
This establishment, a place to enjoy, and take in the sights.
Three and a half stars, a rating fair and just,
For a place that pleases, and leaves one feeling blessed."
"Tasty, fresh chicken. Good value at $17 with two big sides. Roomie joint, friendly servers."

"Methinks 'twas but a fortnight past,
When to yon tavern I didst make haste,
To partake of their most savory dish,
The garlic parmesan wings, a feast most rich.

And verily, I must confess,
Their flavor didst my senses bless,
For though the grease was fresh and new,
The wings were cooked to perfection, too.

But lo, there was a minor flaw,
In that the celery sticks were not in awe,
Of being placed within the same container,
As the wings, which didst cause some discomfort, I do declare.

Yet still, I must extend my thanks,
To those who managed this small tavern's tasks,
For their attention to detail, I do perceive,
And hope that they shall continue to thrive and believe."

"A plethora of noodles doth abound, my friend,
In Pho's broth, a feast for thy tastebuds doth descend.
Sriracha bottles, large as thy head, doth sit,
With strange drinks, akin to "Sac Sac," doth flit.
Gummies, cats, toys, and a butchery most fine,
Doth round out this market, a sight most divine.

Parking, alas, may prove a challenge, I fear,
But search round the building, a spot thou shalt clear.
The veg section, though lacking, doth still delight,
For this market, my love, doth forever take flight.

And, good sir, shouldst thou desire a quick repast,
With preserved duck eggs, a minimum doth amass.
Ten dollars, a sum not so great, doth grant thee passage,
To pay with plastic, a convenience most fair and large."

"Hark, what joy doth fill mine heart this night! 'Tis the last eve of my six-day birthday revels, and here I sit, surrounded by dear friends, in this fair venue, where food doth please and wine doth flow! Two of my companions, brave men both, did choose the sausage and peppers, and by their words, 'twas a feast fit for the gods! The rest of us, two in number, did opt for chicken, Marsala and Piccata, and oh, how sweet the taste did linger on our lips! The bread, a marvel, did complement the meal most finely.

But lo, the waiters, diligent and kind, did strive to capture our likeness in a photograph, and after many attempts, did succeed in capturing a portrait most fair and bright! And thus, the music did begin, a melodious delight, which did stir within us all, a desire to dance and frolic in the night! Ah, what a wondrous eve it hath been, a true celebration of life and love, with naught but praise for this fair establishment, and its bounteous feast, fit for a king! Four stars, I say, and worth each penny spent, for here, one findeth true delight, and memories to cherish, till the end of time!"

"A hearty sandwich, a gruff maiden doth take our coin,
With lipstick freshly applied, she doth serve us with disdain.
But nay, let not her mood detract from the feast at hand,
For the sandwiches, they be delectable, and the rest of the crew, so grand."

"Hark, good sir or madam, let this humble scribe regale thee with tales of my most recent culinary escapade. A hearty bowl of veggie mushroom soup didst I devour, accompanied by a delectable fresh pretzel roll. Verily, 'twas a feast fit for the gods! But heed my warning, dear reader, for the establishment doth bustle with activity, and thy meal may tarry in its arrival. Alas, I didst suffer a delay of twenty minutes, and my return to work didst prove tardy indeed. Yet, save for the jelly and peanut butter brioche (which didst not meet mine expectations), all else didst please mine palate well. Methinks, hadst I the chance, I wouldst have bathed within that savory broth, so great was mine enjoyment!"

In this fair lobby, with mosaics so fine,
They've spent a pretty penny, 'tis divine.
At night, a wondrous sight doth dance and play,
Upon the great waterfall, a spectacle to sway.
The staff, so kind and full of grace,
Do serve with cheer and gentle pace.
The place, a boon or bane, doth lie,
From main strip's hubbub, far doth lie.
A twenty-thirty minute walk, doth be,
To reach the heart of Vegas' glee.
"Two weeks? And I didn't know? Pulled into Safeway lot. Been cravin' cream filled for weeks. Thought Superstition Springs was the closest. Time to enjoy."

"Methinks I visited yon Fiesta Mall In N Out Burger thrice,
And found the victuals there most vile and wretched,
The fries, they were soggy and most foul,
I swore never to return, my stomach revolted.

But then, a friend didst persuade me,
To give the place another chance,
In AJ, it was, at lunchtime full,
The line outside, didst stretch anon.

Yet, in the drive-through line, we didst wait,
But five short minutes, ere our turn came,
The fries, they were crispy, fresh and hot,
A worthy burger, and a shake most fat.

The service, swift and courteous too,
Our hunger sated, with naught to do.
I shall return, forsooth, anon."

"Hark! Network, thou hast been mine haven for alignments these many moons. Thou hast served me well, good sirs, and thy prices be most fair. Verily, the customer service doth vary, for each time I doth visit, a new face doth greet me. Fear not, for I shall return anon, to this honest and true shop."

"Tasty toasted treats, my friends, didst thou devour,
With turkey and cheese on whole wheat bread, a feast most fair.
The broccoli cheddar soup, alas, didst they not have,
To my dismay, yet still, their delivery doth make me smile.
For in this neighborhood, where I do reside,
'Tis a convenience, indeed, to have food brought to my side."

This place didst offer a fair price indeed,
And though the massage lacked deep pressure's heed,
It was most relaxing, and my spirit didst feel
A sense of calm, that all my cares didst steal.
The therapists were friendly, and their art didst show
In every gesture, and each gentle blow.
The ambience was pleasant, with scents so sweet,
That my senses didst revel in their treat.

"Hark! The staff doth need some practice in their art,
In courtesy and manners, they could do with a start.
But fear not, for the victuals did make amends,
A Philly Steak combo, with fries and drink, it ends.

The sandwich, a perfect size for midday fare,
Was savory and juicy, beyond compare.
Steak fries, not my favorite, I confess,
But still, a minor quibble, and no great distress.

Yet, a few more fries, I did wish to see,
To match the sandwich, in quantity.
But overall, 'twas good, and since 'tis near my place,
I shall return, with haste, and a cheerful face."

"O, what a wondrous sight doth meet mine eyes!  
A frozen treat, yet not thy common ice,  
Nor slush, but snow, or snoh, if thou wilt,  
In flavors diverse, and toppings of choice,  
With glaze, a drizzle sweet, to crown the delight.  
The menu, not o'erwhelming, doth present  
A selection fair, and not too much to ponder.  
Taro ice, mogi toppings, milk glaze condensed,  
A creative twist, indeed, and worth the test.  
The place, cleanliness personified, doth shine,  
In contemporary IKEA style, so fine.  
And thus, the verdict? Refreshing, tasty, unique,  
A spin on frozen treats, most certainly,  
Yet, one small gripe, the toppings and glaze,  
Too scant, almost nonexistent, alas!"

"Native New Yorker, once. Now, revamped. Worth finding. Limited breakfast options, but what they do, they do damn well. Stuffed French Toast, Chaquillias, Eggs Tuscano - all good. Prices fair, portions generous. Hostess, a bit lacking. Friendly waitstaff, though. Busy spot, so food took its time. Older crowd, near Sun City West. We'll be back for lunch, dinner, and more breakfast."

"Methinks the ambiance here doth please us well, good sir! My Hangover Hash, a dish most wondrous, didst satisfy mine appetite with its savory flavors and textures. Alas, my dearest wife, whose taste doth lean towards the spicy, found her tofu tacos to be lacking in zest and didst leave half uneaten. The attendants, with haste and diligence, didst serve us well, and I must confess, their fries, a culinary delight, didst earn our praise."

"It's a damn good spot for a grec buffet. Variety's the name of the game here, and the ambiance ain't half bad either. They got a private bar, so you can get your drink on without any hassle. Me and the boys been here a few times, and most of the grub's pretty good. Their ice cream's top-notch, if I do say so myself. And they got halal meat for my Muslim buddies, so everyone can join in on the fun. Some dishes might be a bit overcooked or too salty, but that's just part of the game. Prices vary depending on the day, but it's worth it."

"Hark! What tales of culinary delight doth fill my ears?
A grill, they call it Pita Kitchen, and its fare doth seem most fair.
The reviews, they doth pour forth in praise, and I, a man of discerning taste, do long to partake of their offerings. Fear not, good friends, for I shall render my judgment, anon, and let it be known, far and wide, whether this Pita Kitchen Grill doth serve the finest victuals or nay."

"Tucked away in Gilbert, we found a quaint spot for breakfast. Gf and I gave it a go, and it exceeded expectations. Pancakes and sausage for me, breakfast tacos with eggs, veggies, and ham for her. Apple fritters stole the show, though - sweet exterior, fluffy interior. Get there early, as it fills up fast. Moderate prices for the quality. And watch out for that scorpion - its sting packs a punch."
"Good grub. Local joint, not dive, but close. Expected given the area. Went for Bell's tap take-over during Mad-Craft-Beer-Week. My wife and I had the fish, tasted great."

"Came for the Day of the Dead fest, but it was a bust. Museum was cool though. Checked out the Cotton Fields to Skyscrapers exhibit - traced changes in Charlotte since the Civil War. Interactive approach was rad, and I'm a history geek. Exhibit was big, so you got a real feel for the eras. Day of the Dead exhibit was meh. No sugar skulls, no dancers, just a few altars. Like the holiday, so I'd hoped for more. But hey, free museum admission, so it worked out."

"In fair Edinburgh, near the Meadows green,
A Continental Deli doth entice,
With freshly baked bread, and sandwiches keen,
And cakes, a sweet and savory delight.

Their meats and cheeses, a counter full,
Do tempt the taste, and make one pull,
Their chocolate brownie, oh, how divine,
Doth make my mornings bright and fine.

Fresh fruit salad, a healthy start,
Doth fill my heart with joy and part,
But alas, the prices, somewhat steep,
Yet still, I frequent, in my sleep.

Now hampers too, they do prepare,
With choices of thine own to share,
Delivered to thy door, with grace,
A service most convenient, in this place.

Inside, seats doth wait, and outside too,
Tables and chairs, for all to view,
The Meadows' bustle, on a warm day,
A pleasant spot, to pass the time away."

My heart doth sing of Royal Cafe and Creperie,
A Matthews treasure, where my love doth lie.
But Hazelnuts, a place in uptown Charlotte,
Doth offer crepes most tasty, a surprise.

Located in a building's lobby, it doth seem,
With people passing through, a bustling scene.
The menu boasts of breakfast, savory too,
And dessert crepes, a treat for me and you.

Friendly staff doth take thy order with a smile,
And in a few short minutes, thy crepe doth arrive.
I've tried the Maple Dream, a mix of sweet and savory,
And Basil Pesto Chicken, fit for a king's pavory.

A great option for breakfast or lunch, indeed,
Though served on paper plates, the crepes doth succeed.
No frills, but the food, that's what doth matter,
Hazelnuts, a place worth visiting, no chatter.

"A 3.5, I say, though kindness of staff doth sway
My judgment, and I round up, come what may.
At Bellagio, penthouse suite, I did abide,
And thence, to Vdara, where I now reside.

A smaller suite, yet clean and new, it be,
With friendly staff, who helpfulness doth show.
A fridge, for drinks and leftovers, they provide,
And bed, though not too soft, doth suffice.

Yet windows, grimy, do my view impair,
And thus, my stay, doth not quite reach the fair.
For luxury, seek Bellagio or Wynn,
But for the price, this place doth win."

"This course has me under its spell. A damn fine municipal course, the best I've had the pleasure of playing. Challenging, but fair. Rewards accuracy, not wild slices. Some holes offer breathtaking views. The back nine's got a doozy - hit through a forest opening, down three stories, onto the green, 200 yards out. I'll be back, no doubt. Well-kept, challenging course. That's a fact."

"I've been curious about this place for a while now. Finally decided to check it out today. Nice and cool inside, especially with the heat outside. Friendly staff, didn't bother me when I wanted to browse but helped when I needed it. Bought a black top with sequined roses, got it for 20% off too. Manager said I could get the other one I liked for the same discount if I came back within a week. Good customer service, not just because of the discount. Will definitely stop by again next time I'm in town."

"Verily, a merry spot, full of mirth and glee! In company of kin and friends, I didst visit this place, And, by my troth, we didst enjoy ourselves right well. The victuals, though not of the finest sort, Didst suffice, for 'twas not a haunt of high estate. We laughed and made good cheer, and shall return anon."

"Fresh grub, delicious. Veggie sandwich, surprisingly good. Trout sammy, not bad either. Soups and baked goods, looked and smelled great. But damn, this joint's always slammed. People waitin' outside, it's tiny. Weird system too, sit down, order at the counter, server brings it out. Then you gotta get up and pay the cashier. Don't know why they don't just holler out order numbers. Still, solid lunch spot in the Old Town. Le Cartet's better, but this place'll do."

"Pho night. Average rating, spot on. Three bowls ordered, all enjoyed. Vegan pho, flavorful and loaded with veggies and noodles. Tofu nuggets, surprisingly decent. Crab rangoon, overpriced at $8. Service, hurried. Water arrived without order. Food, quick. No dessert request necessary. Check arrived mysteriously. House music played, unexplained. A Vegas night, indeed."

"Pesto Prima, it's got me under its spell. Been here twice, both times for breakfast. But hey, that's the most important meal, right? Their Prima Breakfast Sandwich, it's like a taste explosion in your mouth. All the flavors just work together so damn well. And it's no small thing either, I've been known to fill up on just half. Their Chai Tea, it's like liquid gold. They make it themselves and it's the best in town. And don't even get me started on their Java Mocha Blast, it's like a protein-packed party in a cup. Just wish they were open on Sundays, that's my only gripe."

"Pittsburgh, a city of steel and stone,
Where Latino drinks flow like a river's moan.
One place, a gem among the rest,
Serves up caiprinhas, truly blessed.

A weekend night, the crowd doth swell,
Wall-to-wall, a sea of souls in hell.
But for the tacos, oh how grand,
A taste of Mexico, in this frozen land.

Snow falls soft, a winter's breeze,
Yet caiprinhas flow, a summer's sigh.
An oxymoron, strange and true,
Pittsburgh's secret, only a few know."
"Good grub, attentive folk. Cozy joint. Love the warmth, never a letdown. This place'll be a regular haunt."

St. Francis, a Phoenix haven, doth serve the finest fries in all the land, by my troth. Their sister eatery, though nigh as good, doth fall a mite short, alack. A brunch spot most fair, with music live and merry, St. Francis doth delight, both morning and eve. Service, a paragon of grace, doth complement victuals most delectable. For breakfast, eschew the mayo-sauce, a fancy name for sauce most vile. Instead, choose flatbread pizza or burger, a feast most worthy. And happy hour, a time of joy, doth bring gladness to thy heart, with drinks most fine and revelry most merry.

"Fairs and festivals, akin to those in distant lands,
But here, the weather doth bring us greater joy.
To buy from artisans themselves, doth give a special hand,
For in their visage, we see the craftsmanship employed.

Their faces, like their works, do show the skill and care,
That in their labors, they do put their heart and soul.
So let us cherish these artisans, and their wares so fair,
For in them, we find beauty, that doth make our spirits whole."

"O, how we do adore this place, my dear!
'Tis fitting for young families, I do declare,
For high chairs they do provide, with nary a frown.
Their victuals, of a truth, are quite divine,
And swiftly served, withal, by a merry crew.
A treasure, hidden from the masses, 'tis,
Their green curry, a dish most wondrous,
Yet more rice, pray, would make it all the better,
Their sampler, a platter most fair and fine,
Doth please our taste, with its diverse fare,
In sooth, a gem, this place, we do confess."

In this quaint nail shoppe, I find solace from the usual hustle and bustle of life. 'Tis clean and tranquil, a true haven for weary souls. My nails, once strong and healthy, have of late been prone to breaking with ease. And so, I ventured forth to try these gel tips, a remedy proffered by the fair maiden who tends to my needs. Alas, they began to peel away but six days hence, leaving me in dismay. Yet, I returned, and she, with skill and grace, did fix them anew, employing a hard gel that doth make my nails appear most natural and elegant.

"Methinks I didst dine at yonder Cracked truck,
In Food truck Oasis, where Bonnaroo doth take place.
A humble egg, cooked to perfection, doth please me well,
And thus, I knew this truck would be my heart's delight.
I did order Goy Vey, with bacon, salami, hash brown,
And a fried egg, with sweet and spicy cream cheese, upon a roll.
'Twas truly glorious, the best breakfast-for-dinner I've had,
In a long while, I must confess. The cream cheese did add a special zest,
But alas, the hash brown, thin and crispy, didst blend with the bread,
And thus, it was hard to distinguish, amidst the fluffy loaf."

"Methought I stood upon a stage, where lusty maidens swayed,
In twilight hue, their forms did dance, and all did play
Their parts, as if in some softcore scene, where passion's fire did blaze.
A fair assembly, full of mirth and glee, did gather here,
Yet, 'twas a trifle cramped, and drinks did cost a pretty penny, dear.
Still, 'twas a merry place to spend an eve, ere we did take our leave,
And with the lads, I did imbibe, and revel in the festive mood,
For though the price did sting, the spirits did lift, and all did feel quite good."

"Pray, let us forgo the meager spread they call a continental breakfast, and instead, indulge in eggs benedict, rich and creamy, upon a flaky, buttery croissant. Coffee, unadulterated by cream or sweetener, doth please our palates well. Service, in this city of vice and luxury, doth excel, as we three ladies gather, our mornings filled with tales of barhopping, coitus, and drama, in a setting most refined and opulent."
"Subs, six inches, not enough. Twelve, too much. Seven-five, just right. Cousins, smart guy. Splits the difference. Service, top-notch. Owner, friendly. Cares about the grub. We're fans."
"Nice attendant. Doll, she was. No charge to try on wigs, bonus. Scored two great wigs for under $70. Trashy looking aisles, but it's a beauty supply store. -1 star for the awkward front desk lines."

"In all the downtown area, there's none can compare,
To this place, where creativity doth reign supreme.
Their food, so yummy, doth delight mine eyes,
And in their prices, fairness doth abide.

I've tried a goodly portion of their menu,
And found, alas! the red curry not quite hot.
But all else, I do swear, hath been most fine,
The gypsy stew, a taste of heaven's own pot.

"A dish so fine, so full of flavor,
That even he who loves his meat,
Might find himself in awe and savor,
This linguine, whole grain, Tuscan treat.

Without cream, but still so rich and bold,
It pleases all, from young to old.
And tofu, oh how grand,
Adds protein, and a taste so bland.

But wait, there's more, my dear friend,
For hidden here, a treat that ne'er ends.
A marshmallow treat, so sweet and light,
That even angels might take flight.

So do not miss this culinary delight,
For it shall bring thee joy and delight.
And though the secret thou dost seek,
I pray they never stop, this treat to keep."

"Fair maidens, we didst gather here last eve,
Forsooth, a night of mirth and merriment didst we crave.
And though the valets didst take our steeds in hand,
I fear, my dears, 'twas naught but forceful blandishment.

In sooth, the eatery was quaint and fair,
With menu diverse and drinks most rare.
The goat cheese dish, a wondrous sight to see,
Didst tempt our taste buds, and didst please thee.

But, alack, the victuals, save the flatbread,
Didst lack that je ne sais quoi, that certain zest.
Yet, shared we desserts, and in truth, they were
Most delectable, and won my heart, I swear.

Our serving maiden, a sprite most fair,
Didst tend to us with grace and care.
A minor hiccup with the payment, 'tis true,
But swiftly solved, and her smile didst renew.

So, shall I return? Aye, that I shall,
For in this place, methinks, I may find my fill."
"Boba review: Best in town. Tastes great, not powdered or overcooked. Friendly service, no awkwardness for being white."

"Methought I would partake of a salad,  
Whiles visiting a friend in this fair place,  
And lo, the salad didst impress me much,  
With fish upon it, fresh and of good grace.  
  
I am accustomed to a hasty meal,  
At places such as Panera, 'tis no steal,  
But here, they grilled the salmon, hot and fine,  
A pleasant surprise, worth waiting for, in sooth.  
  
I took my salad forth, to dine alfresco,  
And noted they didst serve beer and wine,  
In fairness, too, they had a patio,  
Where one couldst sit and savor, in jollity."

"Methought we loved each dish, save one, I pray thee, nay!
Kalbi ribs, a feast fit for the gods, didst rock and roll,
Aria, sweet melody, didst make our taste buds whole.
Coco shrimp, a treat, didst tickle our fancy, in sooth.
Avocado bomb, alack, didst fail to impress, I do confess.
The red rock, of consistency, didst lack, and failed to please.
Our avocado bomb, with little avocado, didst cause dismay,
For in the pictures, it didst seem, a different way."

"Methinks my first visit doth leave me somewhat unimpressed, fair friends. Mayhap 'twas the curious glances I received whilst ordering, or perchance the lack of ale that doth please mine taste. Verily, the crowd doth seem enamored of this place, yet shall I play the contrarian, as oft doth seem my wont. 

In sooth, the tavern doth possess some promise, boasting a fine array of brews and comfortable seating. Alack, my impressions doth falter somewhat, save for these scant virtues. 

Yet shall I grant four stars, in deference to mine own rating of nearby breweries."

"Hark, what news is this? A tale of woe,
Of Flamingo's honeyroom, where I didst go.
At first, displeasure didst my heart afflict,
But soon, a change didst come, and all was fixed.

The front desk clerk, a man of great grace,
Didst greet us with a smile upon his face.
He gave us key, and up we didst ascend,
To fourth floor room, where trouble didst attend.

Air unit view, didst cause my blood to boil,
And so, I called guest services, with haste and toil.
They transferred us, to a room of higher floor,
With comfy beds, pool view, and more, galore.

The flat screen, a nice touch, indeed,
And bathroom, where I couldst watch TV, with speed.
I wouldst stay here again, the price was fair,
And location, most convenient, beyond compare."

In fair Las Vegas, they didst take a piece of France,
And plunk'd it down within the city's heart,
With sky so blue and clouds so wispy, that it doth seem,
As thou didst wander through the streets of Paris, art.

Amidst this French enclave, shops didst abound,
With prices such as those in any mall found.

"Marry, 'twas a feast most wondrous and fair,
With chicken satay, dried beef, and nuts so rare.
I could not get enough, 'twas divine,
The staff, so kind and full of grace did shine.
But alack, our delivery plans did go awry,
For though we called, the number did deny.
A puzzle, indeed, with no solution near,
So four stars, I say, with naught but cheer."

"A night for love, and wherefore shall we dine?  At Cajun Queen, a place of elegance and fine cuisine.  A historic home on 7th Street, with rooms full of charm.  Yet, alas, the back room shone bright, and ladies' laughter did ring out, loud and clear.  So, we asked to move, and up to the rooftop patio, we did ascend.  A warm December eve, with music of yore, lights of festive hue, and a view most wondrous to behold.  Fried oysters, crispy and golden, with Ranch dressing, creamy and cool.  \u00e9touff\u00e9e, with crawfish, or veggies, our choices, both needing a pinch of this and that, but then, oh so tasty, indeed.  The roof, a treasure, hidden, yet now, our secret, to savor and delight.  Thus, we shall ask, each time we dine, for the rooftop, weather permitting, a haven of joy, and culinary delight."

"Oh, fairest of distilleries, how sweet thy brew doth taste!
In particular, the horchata, made with honey's golden grace,
Doth please my palate, and all my senses doth embrace.
Their liqueurs, too, in bottles sold, do make a fine addition
To any drink, at home or here, in this hidden place.
Alas, 'tis true, my friends, that few have heard of this spot,
But one dear friend, a connoisseur, doth swear by it, and not
In vain, for here, in darkness, doth lie a secret charm,
That only those who seek it, with patience, may disarm.
The night, it doth descend, and closeth this place at ten,
But fear not, for nearby bars, less crowded, doth await thee then.
And though the darkness doth enshroud, this place, so near
To Washington's bustling streets, I doth not hold it dear.
For safety's sake, I doth advise, to walk with haste,
When coming alone, lest danger doth thy pathway blast."

"Hark! 'Tis a place of wonder, where one may find
Cleanliness and convenience, in equal measure bound.
Machines aplenty, for diverse loads they do provide,
And drying time, but seven and a half minutes doth abide.
Heat settings, detergent, softener, and dryer sheets,
All available, for a mere seventy-five cents, 'tis meet.
An attendant, watchful and diligent, doth keep
The premises in order, as if by some sweet sleight.
And lo! A 7eleven, next door, doth await,
For those who seek sustenance, or other needs to sate."

"Vegas hotel of choice. Smack-dab on the strip, beds like clouds. Not too pricey, but a damn sight better than the dives nearby. Got upgraded last visit, too. Forgot my keys? Thought they were gone for good. But no, they called, asked if they were mine. And shipped 'em to me, free of charge. See you New Year's Eve."

"Hark! A tale of NASCAR races, I do tell,
In Phoenix, where the speedsters did dwell.
A weekend spent, with parking quite prime,
Suite perks, with grub and drinks sublime.
Octane suite, an invite-only affair,
With luxuries galore, beyond compare.
The grounds, though crowded, still kept neat,
PIR staff, friendly and obliging, indeed.
Security guards, a mite confused,
But cheerful, nonetheless, their mood.
Campers abounded, a wondrous sight,
Shopping cart races, a spectacle in store.
My first NASCAR venture, a delight,
I shall return, with haste and great cheer."

"Cigars ain't my thing, but I enjoy 'em with a strong drink now and then. This joint was a real treat. The leather furniture, comfortable bar stools, and warm wood accents made for a damn fine atmosphere. It was a great spot to unwind. The grub, drinks, and cigars were decent. Didn't stick around for a meal, but I'll give it another shot sometime."

"With nineteen Yelpers, I didst venture forth to Siamese Kitchen, where we didst feast upon the menu, and o'erwhelm the kitchen with our hunger. But lo, the staff didst bear it with grace, and even suffered me to aid in clearing tables, and speeding forth the victuals.

Verily, the food was good, and service, too, didst please. Though, 'twas a trifle difficult for them to keep pace with our great numbers, they didst bear it with a smile, and some of us didst lend a hand in bussing tables, or filling waters.

I didst enjoy the yellow curry mightily, and wouldst order it hotter anon. Dottsy, too, didst find her pad thai to be of fiery temper, and the leftovers didst come home with me, alas, too spicy for most.

In sooth, all dishes I didst sample (and there were seven or eight) were full of flavor, and goodly priced, too. So, I shall keep Siamese Kitchen in mind for future luncheons, for 'tis a worthy place, with tasty viands, and fair costs."

"Papilio, a haven of gastronomic delight,  
With atmosphere cozy, and staff so bright.  
Their passion for service, doth shine so fair,  
And makes one feel welcome, beyond compare.  
  
We ordered olives, marinated with care,  
To savor with wine, and beer of finest fare.  
The Calzone Ripieno, a treat to behold,  
Did take some time, but our patience did unfold.  
  
Stuffed with mozarella, sausage, ham, and more,  
It paired well with wine, and beer galore.  
Gnocchi Al Gorgonzola e Spinaci, a dream,  
As good as any, that my taste buds have seen.  
  
Espresso, twice, we did request,  
And biscotti, small, but oh so sweet.  
We asked for more, and the waiter, kind,  
Did fill another bowl, our hearts and minds.  
  
A family of fourteen, we did espy,  
Comfortably seated, without a sigh.  
So whether couple, family, or group,  
Papilio's warmth, doth all hearts engroup.  
  
Our bill, just under forty pounds,  
For drinks, starters, mains, and coffee, abounds.  
Worth every penny, we do declare,  
And promise to return, without a single care."

"HofbrÃ¤uhaus: where beer mugs are weapons, accordions play all night, and dirndls show off curves. Big tables, big benches, big everything. Patrons stand on chairs, downing shots to the band's chant. Our feast begins with soft pretzels and bier cheese, rich enough to kill. Wiener schnitzel, steamed veggies, and German potato salad for me. Perfectly fried, juicy, crispy, and worth two meals. Potato salad, well-balanced, light on mustard and mayo. Struggled to finish my meal and beer, but hey, that's what vacation's for. Overindulgence is mandatory."

"Methinks I've dined at this place before, 'twas called Pink Pepper then, but ne'er had I tried their noonday spread. A few days past, I decided to partake of their buffet offerings, and verily, all dishes didst taste most wondrous, yet lacked a certain je ne sais quoi, a certain zest, a certain spice, if thou wilt. Now, I do confess, they didst strive to make dishes palatable to the masses, and one can always add a dash of chili, but I, myself, do prefer my Thai cuisine to arrive already spiced. But fear not, dear friends, for I didst return, and shall return again, forsooth, for the Thai tea, 'twas some of the best I've ever had, and I didst order one to go, that I might prolong the sweet, creamy delight as long as possible. And, by the way, the service, 'twas most excellent, and I do await my next visit with bated breath!"

"Methinks this eating house doth bear a striking resemblance to its kin, The Cheesecake Factory. Verily, I do admire the vastness of the menu, and the generous portion sizes, which, by my troth, do provide sustenance for a small village, and thus, maketh for most excellent leftovers.

I do confess, I find joy in trying novel dishes upon each visit, and this time, the BBQ Asian Pork Tacos didst delight mine taste buds exceedingly.

The service, though 'twas a crowded and noisy place, didst prove to be quite satisfactory, despite the vastness of the establishment and the scarcity of servers.

Alas, the din and the difficulty in obtaining attentive service didst somewhat mar the experience, yet methinks 'tis a small price to pay for the convenience of its late hours and its location within the Venetian."

"Methinks 'tis a fine addition to our fair vicinity,
A haven for moms to escape and revel in glee.
A quaint and charming establishment, with menu most intriguing,
And wines, some crafted by their own hand, didst please mine eye.

I knew not, till I ventured thither, of their wondrous brew,
Nor didst I expect to find Four Graces Pinot Noir anew.
'Tis a rare delight, from Oregon's soil doth spring,
And now, in this place, doth my heart sing.

The Shallot marmalade bruschetta, oh how sweet,
Didst tantalize mine taste buds, and left me most discreet.
The salmon roll, a dish most delectable and fine,
Didst fill mine belly with joy, and left me in a state divine.

On Mondays, a bargain doth await,
A chef's choice pizza, and wine, for a mere twenty dollars to pay.
When with mine husband, I didst partake,
In happy hour, with sliders, most savory and great.

A place most pleasant, to linger and enjoy,
With margaritas, for mine love, to quench his thirst and employ."

"Four stars in summer's heat, on terrace so fair,
And lower, when sun doth not shine so bright.
But, oh, what a hidden gem doth lie here!
If ne'er before hath thou set foot within,
Thou mayst doubt thy path, past grimy Foufounes,
And alleys dark, where doors are closed and tight.
Yet fear not, for through small, unmarked door,
Thou shalt find entrance to this cozy den,
A pub, where warmth and cheer do reign supreme,
With ivy-clad walls, that stretch up high,
And wooden benches, where thou mayst sit,
And tunes of yore, that bring back memories sweet.
The service, friendly, and with ease,
Doth make thee feel most welcome, indeed.
A place to forget thy years, and time,
And savor each moment, free from care and strife.
The victuals, though not of highest rank,
Are sufficient, and with nearby inn,
Thou mayst procure a hearty meal, with ease.
Inside, 'tis cozy, with atmosphere quite snug,
And now and then, a mic doth open,
For bards, who come to share their verse, and song."
"Jamerica takeout, messy but worth it. Mango run chicken, enormous, flavorful, satisfying. Shop's decor, chill, quick meal."

"Hark, good sir or madam, seek thou out  
This market fair, where wonders doth abound.  
In Phoenix, at the Roadrunner Park,  
Doth lie a trove of treasures, rare and bright.  
Forty percent of vendors sell produce,  
Thirty percent, local foods, a feast for thine eyes.  
Fifteen percent, fresh drinks and victuals,  
And fifteen more, miscellany, a surprise.  
If thou art seeking but the freshest fruits,  
Beware, lest thou be tempted by other delights.  
Keep thy purse close, lest it doth flee away,  
For other wares, most tempting, doth abide.  
I pray thee, park not in the lot nearby,  
But take a stroll through yonder park, so green.  
My own heart doth delight in chilies fiery,  
Herbs fresh picked, fruits strange and new to me.  
Tamales too, and dairy products of worth,  
At this market, thou shalt find them all, by my troth."

"My girl's into robot toys, my buddy's a Spawn nut, so I checked out this toy store. Not many robots, but plenty else - McFarlane's stuff, comics, rare toys. A fun spot for collectors, even for those just browsing. My friend scored some cool stuff, I left empty-handed but smiling. A good way to kill time, a haven for enthusiasts."

"Hark! A store most wondrous, where I do possess
A member card, which doth grant me 10% off, yea, verily!
And as a Hawaiian Miles Mall participant, I do receive
Free shipping on their website, with orders of $50 or more, 'tis a bargain, indeed!

But lo, I do not frequent this place, save for the times
When sales doth bring the prices down, and I canst afford
To buy in bulk, and gift them to my female friends,
For I do shop year-round, and always keep a stash, 'tis true.

And thus, I doth reveal my shopping secret, fair ones,
That here, they doth offer promotions, such as "Buy 2, get 1 free",
And being part of their e-mail club, I doth receive
The updates, and know what's new, and what's in store for me.

Now, of their wares, I must confess, I doth adore
The Body Butter products, in mango, coconut, shea butter, and more,
The gifts, a no-brainer, and the foot kits, great for giving,
But also, I do use them myself, and find them most living.

This store, it doth reside, within the Miracle Mile Shops,
At Planet Hollywood, a casino, and hotel, of sorts,
But alas, of late, I have not found much, during sales,
Perhaps, 'tis due to tourists, but I shall not bemoan, for I shall still,
Check in, and see, what wonders they may hold, for me."

"Hark! This place, a haven for buckaroos, doth offer a feast most wondrous and fair. For a mere $10, a man may partake of a drink, hot dog, nuggets, fries, nachos, ice cream, or packaged cotton candy. Verily, 'tis a bargain most generous and kind. But, alas, I do suspect their 'bucko nuggets' be not of chicken, but of some other flesh, perhaps of pig or cow. Yet, who can say? For in this place, all things are possible, and the taste, it doth delight."

A south rim tour we booked, my friends,
And off we went, our journey's end.
The bus, it took us to the Miracle Mile,
Where we did dine on danish and coffee, smile.

But slow we started, organization took its time,
As we prepared for the day's design.
Near the dam, a rest stop we did find,
In Kingman, Arizona, a place to unwind.

A decent lunch we had, in Williams, too,
Before we set off for the south rim anew.
The drive, it was quite long, I must confess,
But Tommy, our driver, he did his best.

Two stops we made, at the canyon's edge,
For about an hour, we did take our time to pledge.
Then back we went, with one more stop in Kingman,
And home we came, around nine thirty, evening's blessing.

So prepare ye well, my friends, for the south rim's length,
And heed my words, for your own safety and health.

"Food, oh how wondrous and divine! Tuna tacos, a dish most fine. But alas, fair warning, let it be known, service there is none to call thy own. Yet, patience, dear heart, for 'tis worth the wait, I do declare, 'twill satiate thy hunger and leave thee elate."

"Fare thee well, good sir! 'Tis a feast for mine eyes to behold such delectable victuals within yonder marketplace. Verily, 'tis a haven for all things Middle Eastern, and my heart doth sing with joy at the mere thought of partaking in such culinary delights. My parents, both of British and Lebanese descent, didst instill within me a love for this fare from a young age, and I must confess that I do enjoy it immensely. Methinks 'tis a place worth visiting, and I bid thee, good sir, to join me in this gastronomical adventure. Cheers!"
"Zoo Lights, first time. Packed on a Thursday night. Whole zoo lit up, fun to walk. Admission ten bucks per adult. Animals asleep, don't get your hopes up."
"Methinks 'twas a pleasant experience indeed! The victuals were savory, the establishment was tidy, and the attendance was most courteous. I shall return anon, without a doubt!"

In sooth, fair friends, I have dwelt within these halls for twain purposes: a night's repose and a wedlock feast.

The chambers, by my troth, didst dazzle mine eyes with their beauty, bedecked in hues of ivory, gold, and navy blue, soothing to behold. The bed, aye, didst cradle mine frame with softness and comfort, and all didst seem most clean and tidy. The staff, in their courtesy, didst greet me warmly at my arrival and departure.

Alas, the walls, they didst prove most thin, and we didst hear the raucous cries of revelers in the hallway, deep into the night.

But lo, the nuptials, they didst proceed with grace and joy. A servant, marking a friend's mishap with spilled water, didst swiftly cleanse the table ere we couldst request his aid. Most of the service, indeed, didst excel, save for a brief confusion with the entrees, which, upon our request, didst swiftly find its correction.

"Sit in the back patio, my friend. You're in Texas, where the Mexican food's as good as it gets. This joint holds its own, no doubt. Cold beer, fresh grub, and decent chips and salsa. I'd go back, and that's saying something."

Ben came here a few times for lunch. It's in a small strip mall and parking can be tough. Always had the thin crust pizza, always good. Large usually feeds two of us. Gluttony takes over, gotta keep yourself in check.

"Methinks my love and I didst chance upon a fair abode,
In Las Vegas, on a day of love, most true.
A room at Gold Coast, we didst find,
For $30, a price most kind.

The location, off the strip, didst please me well,
For driving there, didst prove most easy to tell.
No crowds, no fray, didst make our stay most sweet,
And parking, easy to find, didst greet.

The room, updated, modern, and quite neat,
Didst boast new bed, new furniture, a treat.
A bathroom, cute and clean, didst delight,
With stand-up shower, huge head, most bright.

But check-in, oh how it didst vex me sore,
Four agents, two worked, yet waited we evermore.
One person, ahead of us, didst take their time,
Twenty minutes, passed, ere we didst sign.

Thus, four stars, I give, for service slow,
Yet still, wouldst recommend, this hotel, I know."

"Hark! What news is this? A brewery with grub,
Not just ale, but victuals fit for a king!
The atmosphere, open and inviting,
A warehouse feel, with merriment a-brimming.

We sat us down, and menus were brought forth,
For drink and food, a veritable feast on earth.
The ales, good, nay, verily, quite excellent,
But the fare, oh! 'Twas truly heaven-sent.

Soups in test tubes, flat breads most divine,
A culinary experience, beyond compare, I do declare.
Alas, they do not serve all dishes at noon,
So I did miss the shrimp and cotton candy, boon.

Yet, I shall return, to sample more,
For this place, it doth stir my heart's great roar.
Charlotte, thou art blessed with this gem,
A brewery, with food, that doth excel."

"Dr. Hsueh's a peach. Thorough, caring, and takes her time. Explains what's what, asks if you got questions. Like that. 

After the Rx, JR (or RJ) hooked me up with a sweet frame. Friendly, professional. 

This place is solid. Found an OD worth seeing again. This review should help you choose Dr. Hsueh too."

"If thou art in search of sweet indulgence at the ninth hour, then hasten thee well to Centotre, good sir! Forsooth, upon our arrival, the proprietor didst greet us with such warmth and Italian flair, that we didst feel most honored and welcome. He didst arrange for a table to be prepared for the four of us, and didst ensure that we were all quite comfortable.

The menu, full of delectable choices, didst present a challenge, for one dish didst bear a name similar to another, and thus, a mistake didst occur. My sister, though she didst enjoy her selection, didst not receive the dish she hadst intended. A minor quibble, indeed, yet one worth mentioning.

My wife, however, didst savor her affogato with great relish, and I must say, I didst find amusement in the clever manner in which they teach Italian to those who dare to venture forth and partake of the facilities. 'Tis a unique experience, to be sure!

Alas, the attentive service we didst receive at the start of our visit didst not extend to the payment of our bill, for we didst wait in vain for a server to appear. Tired and sated, we didst find this delay to be somewhat vexing. Yet, in the end, we didst settle our account and didst agree to return, for the desserts alone didst merit another visit."

"First time here, didn't like it. Pasta, no good. But pizza, salads, sandwiches - fantastic. Pozookies, best dessert around. Good service, great atmosphere. Santa Fe salad, Italian chopped salad - both great choices, huge portions."

"Methinks 'twas either yon portraits of Cantinflas on the wall,
Or else the victuals that did most impress me.
In truth, I know not, for both did please me well,
And left me in a state of wonder and delight.

The portion sizes, by th' name of "abuelita,"
Did overflow with goodness, and did make me merry.
We had the Tamales Oaxaqueno, and four moles besides,
All of which did taste most wondrous and divine.
And let us not forget the Horchata and pineapple soda,
Which did quench our thirst and add to our mirth.

Alas, the service did seem somewhat awry,
For twice a second waitress did try to take our order, ere we could say,
"Nay, good sir, we have already been attended."
And lo, a woman did go about, seeking change,
But she was shooed away, and all was well again.
Despite these trifling flaws, I would return anon,
And recommend Casa Reyna to my friends and kin."

"Famous Dave's, a place most wondrous,
Where food doth please and service doth abound.
A visit there, less than ten times,
Yet, in my heart, a joy profound.

Their cornbread, sweet and divine,
Doth make my taste buds sing and shine.
A wish, to have more than one piece,
Alas, 'tis not meant to be, my friend, 'tis not meant to be.

Expensive, some may say,
For two entrees, sodas, and an appetizer grand.
But, oh, the feast that doth await,
With leftovers, a happy fate.

And lo, the paper towels,
A savior, when BBQ sauce doth beset thy skin and face.
A small delight, yet, oh, so grand,
In this world of wonder, a true blessing, indeed."
"Best pizza in Vegas, top-notch. Service slow, but that's the norm here. Worth trying, might go back for more before I leave."

"By chance, I stumbled upon this hidden gem,
Tucked away in a strip mall, with a modest sign.
It had a familiar feel, like Chipotle's charm,
But with a twist, that left me pleasantly surprised.

Their ingredients were fresh, of highest quality,
You could taste the difference, with each bite.
They offered healthy choices, a welcome change,
A pleasant surprise, that made my heart sing.

The lads who worked there, were friendly and kind,
Their warmth and hospitality, left me inclined.
The chicken, oh the chicken, my heart's desire,
Was by far, the best, my taste buds on fire.

But they also had, shrimp, steak, and carnitas too,
And for the herbivores, a veggie option or two.
And the cherry on top, it's locally owned,
A true gem, that makes my heart feel at home."

"Austin, thou hast a place most wondrous,
Which I didst wish to try, yet couldst not, alack!
My spouse and I, we didst visit this eatery,
At two o'clock, when crowds didst swell and press.
We each didst order a burger, and a beer,
And shared a platter of fries, with queso, 'twas clear.
For those who crave the Austin queso style,
This dish may not satisfy, I do confess,
The cheese sauce, served apart, didst make me smile,
Yet not the expectation, I must confess.
The burgers, oh, they were most delectable,
Best in the land, their flavor unforgettable.
The draft beer, a wondrous sight to see,
Arizona brews, aplenty, for all to be.
A place to try a new ale, and revel in delight,
I shall return, for sure, ere the sun doth set tonight.

The ordering system, perchance, doth seem strange,
Yet servers, friendly, doth attend to thy range.
Self-service sodas, natural, and sweet,
No need to wait, a refill to greet.
Two burgers, two drafts, and queso fries, a feast,
Thirty-seven coins, a price most reasonable, at the least.
I've paid more, for less, and grumbled, in dismay,
But here, a bargain, and a meal, most worthy, by my troth!"

"Verily, my dearest friend Anita and I didst venture forth to Rick's, a boutique hotel of great renown, armed with a voucher for a delectable burger feast. And, by the stars, we were not disappointed! For though the burgers be normally served at luncheon, the kind folk at Rick's didst make them available for our evening repast.

The reception, bar, and dining area were functional and modern, with warm touches in hue and material. Our voucher didst include Innis & Gunn, a fine brew, but alas, 'twas not available. Yet, I didst choose the Grolsch swing-top with nary a qualm.

The burgers were grand, juicy, and well-filled, a true delight! The fries, skinny and crisp, didst complement them most nicely. I must confess, I didst enjoy the meal and wouldst heartily recommend it to any who doth seek a tasty burger.

Yet, mark thou well, good reader, the price of such a feast doth range from \u00a310 to \u00a313, a sum that doth seem a mite steep. Thus, I must deduct a star, forsooth!

But fear not, for the service at Rick's was most attentive, efficient, and pleasant. Top marks, indeed! I wouldst return anon, forsooth!"

"Hark, fair traveler! Virgin America's gates do lie
Near to the security check, a convenient site.
Many seats and eateries doth surround the space,
A most pleasant journey doth await thy grace.

On a Sunday, we didst fly in, and on a Thursday,
The crowd, it didst not swarm, a blessing, indeed.
In Las Vegas' style, the airport doth revel,
Slot machines, they doth gleam, in baggage claim's crevice."
"Ramen's not my thing, but this joint's got game. My boy had the pork belly bowl and gave it two thumbs up."

"Methinks I dote on bar victuals nigh too well,
A weakness, mayhap, that doth need some spell.
My hometown boasts some fine establishments,
But here, 'tis Zipps that doth my cravings foment.

Their burgers, hot and savory, doth delight,
And focaccias, though but wraps, doth please, forsooth.
But, by my troth, their wings doth reign supreme,
Golden, crispy, spicy-sweet, a wondrous dream.
Happy hour deals, a steal, beyond compare,
In sooth, a bargain, beyond compare."

This gambling den, as expected, draws in the elderly crowd. Slots and video poker galore, and a bingo hall that'll make your head spin. Met my folks there on a Wednesday, and I was one of a handful of youngbloods in the 21-30 age group. Dealers, though, were mostly spry young things. Nice perk: the senior crowd brings the blackjack minimum down to a measly $2. Good place to hone your 21 skills without breaking the bank. Settled in at a $5 table and walked away with some extra cash. Didn't spot a craps table, and the roulette wheel was automated (kind of strange).

Weekends bring more youthful gamblers, but they don't have a ton of tables overall. Solid casino, and it's on tribal land, so be careful driving there and back. Beeline Highway's got plenty of Arizona State Police keeping an eye out for speeders.

"Hark! My spouse and I did dine at this eatery tonight,
And found the victuals to be most delightful, by my troth!
We started with hummus, a tasty dip, I must confess,
And then, our main course, the gyro sandwich, did impress.

He had steak fries, crispy and hot,
Whilst I, a side salad, did choose, no doubt.
The greens were fresh, the dressing, a perfect blend,
I must say, the salad, was the highlight of the end.

The restaurant, within a shopping center lies,
The decor, a bit old-fashioned, yet not quite despicable,
But, alas! The ambiance, not quite up to par,
Yet, the grub and the proprietors, make it worth a visit, beyond compare.

So, shall I return? Aye, most certainly,
For the fare, it doth please mine taste, in verity!"

"Upon a recent day, I chanced to dine
At this establishment, with mine own kin.
The place was full, and parking was a woe,
But soon, a table we did come to know.

A dive, they call it, with music of old,
Which did stir within me, a merry mood.
The victuals, too, did please mine taste,
My lamb burger, with joy, I did embrace.

My wife, a hot dog, with chili and cheese,
Did choose, and said it was a culinary tease.
I must confess, a twinge of envy did seize,
When hers, I saw, in all its savory ease.

Verily, I say, this place, I shall revisit,
For more of their delights, my heart doth sit.
In sooth, a worthy stop, for any soul,
This eatery, with food, doth make whole."

"Methinks 'tis Brio, where I do oft repair,
With satisfaction, at each visit, I declare!
Their luncheon deals, most reasonable, I find,
A chop salad, flatbread, for seven coins, I bind.

And for the eve, pasta, meat doth please,
Panini, salad, combo, my heart doth seize.
Weekdays, martini's, five coins, a steal, indeed!
Thus, Brio, my heart, doth evermore increase."

"Hark, good sirs and madams, listen well,
My words of praise for Graze I shall tell.
A benefit party for Clean Lakes Alliance,
Didst they host, with food and drink in abundance.

The atmosphere, most joyous and bright,
Didst make our spirits take flight.
Graze, the caterer, didst serve with grace,
And their hors d'oeuvres, a wondrous taste.

The crowd, a sea of faces, diverse and vast,
Didst fill the space, with laughter and good cheer.
All who attended, didst enjoy the feast,
And Graze, a worthy host, didst earn our cheer."

Hark! What news is this? Our first happy hour doth bring us to this fair establishment, where sushi and sake doth flow like nectar from the gods. But soft! What discordant sound doth pierce mine eardrums? 'Tis like a club within these walls, the music doth resound so loudly. And what strange fashion doth these waitresses wear? Their garb doth give the place a certain... je ne sais quoi, a collegial air, perchance?

On a Saturday, we didst venture forth to this establishment,
And though we had to wait a bit, our spirits were lifted by a draught at the bar.
The staff were friendly and welcoming, and the victuals didst delight.
We partook of the luncheon special, and found it to be plentiful and satisfying.
Moreover, by using Yelp, we didst receive a discount of ten dollars,
A veritable bargain, indeed! As strangers in this land,
We doth rejoice in finding a culinary haven of such excellence.
My comrade, Jay, didst savor the mongolian beef,
Whilst I, myself, didst indulge in the shrimp and orange, a most wondrous treat.
The hot and sour soup, a marvel of flavors, didst round out our repast.
"Kobe burger, twenty-nine bucks. Worth every penny. Service, top-notch. Matt"

"Coffee joint's a dive, but the chai's top-notch. Barista's too busy makin' each cup to give a damn 'bout anyone else. Take your time, ten, fifteen minutes, don't matter. Just get it to go, you won't regret it."

"Hark! A new Stingray doth grace Scottsdale Quarter,
A pleasant addition to the eateries there.
Walls slide open wide, bringing outdoors within,
A sophisticated space, most neat and fair.

I did partake of luncheon here today,
And found the sashimi combo most satisfying.
Though priced a bit higher than its rival RA,
The cucumber salad and rich miso did make it worth.

The bar, so spacious, gave ample room for me,
To lay my elbows, iPhone, book, and glasses free.
The service, too, was friendly and quite fine,
So here again, I shall return in time."

"A Cirque de Soleil show, I had ne'er beheld,
So my excitement, it did swell and grow.
At first, I grumbled o'er the seats we had,
In the back, they were, alas, so far away.
But lo, the set, it did resemble Midgar,
From Final Fantasy VII, it did remind me.
The ushers, too, they did bear a likeness,
To Harry Potter, had Tim Burton directed.

A wondrous spectacle, it truly was,
The set, it moved, in all directions, it did pass.
Easy to follow, the tale, it was,
And oh, the clothes, they did inspire,
In the gift shop, they did entice,
My heart, it did desire, to purchase more.
Alas, my funds, they are not infinite,
So I did leave, with just a souvenir or two."

"Hark! China Ginger be our haven for delectable Lemon Chicken,
Whose breading doth delight, and sauce doth bring a zestful zing.
The ambiance calm, with melodies that soothe the soul,
And service swift, with smiles that doth make one whole.
A place most meet for couples, young and full of love,
To savor flavors, and share sweet words from above."

"Fish tacos, sweet potato fries, a feast most wondrous fair! In this town, none can compare, I do declare. My taste buds dance with joy, my belly doth sing with cheer. For though I've searched far and wide, no finer fish tacos have I found, nor sweeter fries hath mine eyes espied. And as for brunch, a veritable feast it doth provide, yet beware, dear friend, lest thou consume too much, and for three days, thy hunger doth abate."

"Best damn brownies I've had. Consistent too, across all their flavors. Just a simple counter, but they know their stuff. Not a place for dessert, more like a brownie factory. Try some samples, pick your favorite, and they'll hook you up with a bunch. They're all about moving those brownies, gotta respect that."
"Food's top-notch, perfect for special occasions. Southwest flavors, but not your average Mexican fare. Tequila and cocktails, superb choices."

"Hark! Fat Tuesday, 'tis the place to be,
In Vegas, where we doth revel in glee.
Aye, start the day with 190 Octane,
And a shot, to make our spirits keen.

But heed my words, fair friends,
Lest ye learn the hard way, like I did.
Open wide the cap, and pour the shot,
Ere ye take a sip, lest ye be caught.

For if ye wait, a pleasant surprise,
Awaits thee at the end of thy prize.
A full shot, that doth make merry,
Thy spirits, and doth banish fear.

Indeed, 'tis worth the price,
For it doth stir within us, a merry mood.
So come one, come all, and partake,
Of Fat Tuesday's delightful brew, forsooth!"

"Methinks, fair Peckhams, doth have a strange effect on me,
A passion that doth stir my soul, and fills my heart with glee.
As I draw near, the entrance doth beckon me,
With promises of delectable treats, and savory delight.

Yet, once within, my ardor doth cool,
For naught but disappointment doth my gaze meet.
The fare, though varied, doth not entice,
And cooking, a chore I do not relish, doth seem a bother.

But still, I dream of finding that one dish,
That shall make my taste buds sing with joy and bliss.
Perhaps, one day, fate shall smile upon me,
And Peckhams, a chain of delis, shall be my culinary paradise.

Till then, I shall continue to roam,
In search of that elusive, gastronomic home."

"Came here last night, restaurant.com coupon brought us in. Couldn't use it though, fine print said half off bottles on Mondays. Stuck around anyways, had a good time. Place has an East Coast feel, brick walls, romantic ambiance. Tables close together, not too bad. Not the best spot for kids. Prices a bit steep, but I enjoyed my chicken Gorgonzola. Boyfriend had the same, he liked it too. Service was good, fast."

"Hark! What news is this? A Mood Lounge, new and bright,
In yonder forest, where the trees do take flight.
'Tis a wondrous sight, with Kiefern trees so tall,
And a clearing, where one may hear the birds' call.

The interior, stylish and chic, doth please the eye,
And one may sit, in comfort, and never say die.
But alas, my friends, the service there,
Did leave much to be desired, I do declare.

For when I went, the crowd did throng and press,
And yet, the waiter, with a heavy heart, did confess,
A mistake had been made, and thus, a delay,
Did cause me to wait, in utter dismay.

But then, a Tequila Sunrise, did appear,
In a long glass, with ice, and liquid cheer.
The mix, it seemed, was correct, but oh,
The barkeep, he did not understand, I know,
The ways of English, and thus, didst fail,
To add the Grenadine, with grace and flair.

So, in the glass, did float, some ice,
In a uniform orange mixture, not nice.
Alas, my friends, the service, poor,
And the cocktail, only worthy of a roar.

Thus, I must say, the location, five stars,
But service and drink, a single star, alas!"

"This Phoenix gem, transformed, doth boast an air most welcoming, cozy, and chic, without a hint of pretension. The small bar, snug 'twixt kitchen and windows, doth afford a view most pleasant, of the patio outside. A fine vantage, indeed, for savoring a draught of craft beer, such as the seasonal Great Divide Wild Raspberry Ale, with its amber hue and genuine raspberry essence. As one who doth delight in dairy, the griddled cheese sandwich didst seem most alluring - a choice recommended by several servants, and one that didst live up to its reputation among the foodie crowd. Paired with the soup of the day (a cheesy chicken enchilada), it was a true delight for mine taste buds."
"Toured the joint, packed with kiddos, summer swarm. Workers kept it tight, impressive. Shelled out ten bucks for chocolate pizza, worth every penny. The chocolate, top-notch. Selection, plentiful."

"Verily, I have graced these hallowed halls with mine own feline friend, a fierce tiger in a tiny form. The staff, kind and gentle souls, hath ministered unto us with great care and compassion. Dr. Brown, a wise and learned scholar, hath explained all manner of things, from pneumonia to asthma, with great eloquence and insight. I didst not feel hurried, nor didst I sense any urgency, for the staff didst truly care for mine and my cat's well-being. They didst proffer samples, too, to aid in my cat's medicinal intake. Huzzah! Piper Glen Animal Hospital, thy name doth ring with praise and gratitude!"

"Twas a Tuesday when we dined here, and the crowd was not too great. Service was slow, I reckon, for they had many orders to fulfill. Yet, this place is the best for sushi in Madison, mark my words. A great spot for a date, and the wait time may vary, but 'tis worth the while. The salmon with mango, a most excellent roll, and all the food was cooked to perfection."

"Fast Asian fare, most excellent,
Crowded at noon, the place doth swell.
Fresh and full of flavor, doth my belly cheer,
Combos, a bargain, with potstickers so bright."

"Hark! Mert's doth serve most excellent soul food,
My comrade and I didst partake of their fare,
The cornbread, though tardy, didst prove most sweet,
With butter, 'twas a culinary delight.

Our server didst suggest the ribs, and thus,
I didst order them, with fowl, mac and cheese,
And greens, all of which didst please mine eyes,
The ribs didst fall from the bone, most tenderly,
The fowl, a delight, the mac and cheese, sublime,
The greens, a taste of heaven, so divine.

But alas, the peach cobbler, not so grand,
A pity, for I didst crave something sweet,
Perhaps a chocolate dessert, to end my meal,
But nay, 'twas not to be, at Mert's, I didst feel.

Yet still, I wouldst return, for the fare is fair,
And the service, friendly, with a smile so rare,
At Mert's, thou shalt find solace for thy soul,
In the food, and the warmth that doth make thee whole."

In fair Verona, where we lay our scene,
A cafe doth stand, most charming and serene.
Within the Paris Hotel, its beauty doth shine,
A haven for sweet treats, and pastries divine.

Their desserts, oh so fine and delicate,
Are crafted with love, a true work of art.
Coffee and sandwiches, a simple delight,
To satisfy hunger, without breaking the heart.

An Americano, a drink of choice,
With a proscuitto sandwich, a tasty voice.
On a baguette, a meal most fair and bright,
For just eleven dollars, a true delight.

And in the back, a shop doth lie,
Where merchandise doth wait, for thine eyes to try.
Cups, cookbooks, aprons, and more,
Some with a Paris theme, to make thee adore.

So, gentle traveler, if thou art in need,
Of a sweet respite, and a place to feed,
This cafe, most charming, doth await,
In fair Verona, where love doth create.

"Hark! We snatched up tickets at the eleventh hour,
For Zarkana's opening night, a wondrous sight.
A spectacle true to Cirque du Soleil's name,
With garb that would shame any Halloween game.

Their cast, a group of sprightly youths, didst perform
Feats of agility that left us in awe and wonder.
And though the tale they told, we pretended to discern,
In truth, 'twas but a riddle, a puzzle to uncover.

Yet still, the show didst provide a merry reprieve,
From the clanging slots and tables that do steal our coins.
A respite brief, but sweet, from the gambling den's thrall."

In sooth, fair friends, Eggspectations doth boast  
A varied menu, fit for any roast.  
Benedict, omelette, Sugar Shack, and more,  
Doth grace the list, to satisfy thy gore.  
And though 'tis not a singular find,  
'Tis priced fair, with atmosphere divine.  
My latest visit saw me choose with care  
The Eggs Florentine, a dish beyond compare.  
See for thyself, good sir, the menu here:  
http://www.eggspectation.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/05/Menu_MTL_EN.pdf
"Charlotte, last night of my trip. Food, good. Service, friendly. Vibe, nice. Plenty TVs for sports. Pulled pork plate, huge portions. Mac & Cheese, Fried Okra, yummy. Booths, plenty."

"A modern tavern, yet cozy and bright,
With elevated British grub, a wondrous sight.
The bar, a marvel, with taps of finest brew,
And a backdrop, like iconic British booths, anew.

With friends, I visited this merry place,
And savored each dish, with joy and grace.
Deviled eggs, soup, shepherd's pie, sausages galore,
Fish and chips, burgers, squash soup, and more.

All dishes, delicious, cooked to perfection,
Leaving us in awe, with no room for correction.
Fish and chips, shepherd's pie, standouts indeed,
But all dishes, superb, our taste buds did heed.

Affordable, too, with the Caesar's card,
Our waitress, kind, and her service, not hard.
We'll return, without a doubt, to this jolly place,
For another round of culinary delight, with haste."
Arizona Donut Co., Tempe. Friendly ladies, mediocre donuts. Old-fashioned glaze and glaze twist, half uneaten. Oil evident in taste and sight. Unlikely return for donuts, possible try at boba drinks.

"Hark! What news is this? A sushi place most fair,
Where one may dine on endless delights, without compare.
I, a loyal patron, come hither oft,
For their seared tuna dish, a true culinary thought.
A local's secret, too, they hold within their walls,
A stamp card, granting freebies, for those who enthrall.
Nine purchases made, a tenth dish shall be thine,
A gift from the gods, a treasure truly divine."

"With mine own parents, I didst visit this eve,
And found them in a state of indecision, quite bereft.
We wandered forth, in search of sustenance and cheer,
And chanced upon a place called Vida, my dear.
The victuals there, didst please mine parents mightily,
And we didst dine, in merriment and glee, most rightly."

"Pizza joints come in two varieties: those that serve the real deal, like Brooklyn V's, and those that peddle a pale imitation, Ã  la Pizza Hut or Domino's. After sampling their garlic knots, which were top-notch, I ordered the 14-inch white pizza with pepperoni, onion, and garlic. The crust was light and crispy, a definite plus, but the pie itself was a bit soggy. Still, it was enjoyable, and the portion size was generous, leaving us with leftovers. Pricing-wise, Brooklyn V's falls somewhere in between the genuine article and the pretenders, so it's up to personal preference and priorities."

"Hark! A kindly receptionist didst greet me with a smile,
And gave me a chamber on the first floor, in style.
But lo, I wished to be on higher ground,
On the second or third floor, with a better sound.
The receptionist didst tell me, with a gentle grace,
That naught but tomorrow couldst grant me that place.
Good service, indeed, didst they provide,
And so, I shall observe and update, as I reside."

"Sandy Bells, a joint where folk music reigns supreme. No regard for capacity, just cram 'em in, like sardines in a tin. Impromptu ceilidh, always on the cards. Edinburgh institution, through and through. Acts, incredible. Keep an eye out for folkies at the Liquid Rooms, after party's here, no doubt. \n\nBut, alas, the smoking ban's taken its toll. Thick fog of smoke, gone. Sweaty stench, dominant. My advice? Down a few pints, ale, too. Your sniffer'll thank you."

"Methinks 'tis a wondrous place for swift repast,
Where first I came upon a Groupon's quest.
A year hath passed, yet ne'er didst I return,
For reasons such as these, my heart doth yearn.

A bargain-hunter, I, with zeal and cheer,
Do seek out deals, discounts, and sales so dear.
But alas, at Zaba's, none couldst be found,
And thus, my visits there were few and far between, profound.

Their prices, verily, do seem quite steep,
For fast food fare, a truth most people keep.
Seventeen crowns, I spent on salad and burrito vast,
Yet portion sizes, generous, our hunger did surpass.

The shrimp, freshly cooked, our taste buds did delight,
Whilst chicken, somewhat old and dry, did not excite.
But lo, the rest, a cornucopia of health and glee,
Sweet potatoes, beans, fajita mix, and rice, we did enjoy with glee.

In conclusion, full and content, I did depart,
Wishing only, that some coupons they would impart.
Fresh Mex, feel-good, a meal most satisfying,
Leaving thee, dear reader, with naught but joy and gladness."

"O, what a wondrous brunch place doth this be!
Always full, yet seats are found in ten,
And food doth come in twenty, by my reckoning.

Scones, oh how delicious they doth taste!
Savory ones, my heart doth sing with joy!
Quiches too, they doth please mine appetite.

Pastries, if thou desirest them, doth wait,
But walk a short ways down, and find thee
The pastry shop, where sweet treats doth abound.

Pigs in a blanket, oh how novel an idea!
Sausage in pancakes, who hath not tried it?
Mac and cheese pancakes, with andouille sausage,
A dish most wondrous, and worth mine usage.

Speedy eggwich, for those who crave simplicity,
A humble dish, yet full of flavor, I do declare.
Grits with sausage patties, my newfound delight,
Leaves me fulfilled, with leftovers to boot, in faith!"

"Outside Inn, it's a joint I dig. Beer selection's decent, grub's not too shabby either. Pretzel chicken sandwich, sliders, they're my jams. Bar food, but a cut above. Wine-o Wednesdays, not a bad deal. My wife and I, we hit it up after work, grab a bite, couple brews. Air's clean, don't notice the smoke much 'less it's right on top of me."

"Hark! In days of yore, 'twas Lucky's, then Albertson's,
This Greenland Supermarket, where I didst roam.
But now, alas! 'Tis changed, like all around,
On Spring Mountain, betwixt Rainbow and Decatur, profound.
Chinatown doth flourish, a wondrous sight,
A food court within, doth pique my appetite.

A Hawaiian stall, with sweet spam musubi,
Sushi, too, doth tempt, with nigiri so cheap.
Korean fare, I tried, with kim-chee and meat,
But found the aftertaste, a curious treat.

A coffee shop, with Boba, doth quench my thirst,
Though out of stock, a pity, I didst not desist.
In conclusion, a fair experience, indeed,
I shall return, though variety doth decrease.
A Vietnamese booth, or more, wouldst be grand,
To make this food court, a true Shangri-la land."

"Sesame Inn, again. Time to kill before the Richard Thompson show, so I went for Chinese. Egg rolls, shrimp with pea pods, good stuff. But Jesus, they give you way too much. Lunch portions would be nice for dinner. Stashed the leftovers in my office fridge for later."

"A humble abode, this eatery doth seem,
With fare that doth delight, and prices so keen.
Their hummus, though not to my taste, doth flow,
For they must cater to the masses, I do know.
But oh, their babajanoush, how rich and divine,
Made with love and care, a true work of art, fine.
The pita, warm and soft, doth fill the belly,
And tabulli, a mix of flavors, doth dance merrily.
In balance, all doth seem, a feast for the eyes,
A pleasant repast, at this cozy surprise."

"Thrive/Fresche's got great bowls, but their joint's got a funny smell. Like bleach or somethin', but it ain't clean. Seats are stained, look dirty. Can't blame 'em for customers makin' a mess, but they should take pride in cleanin' up quick and replace broken stuff. Sit outside? No way, smells like trash. Prob'ly got a dumpster nearby, outta their control. Get your bowl to go, call ahead to skip the wait. Enjoy."

Yesterday, went in with a buddy. Service was alright, server checked on us only when necessary. Ordered beef tips, enjoyed 'em, but needed a to-go box. Packed up leftovers, left 'em on the table, and headed to the ladies' room with my friend. Came out, and our table was cleared, including my to-go box. Found the waiter, who apologized and offered a new, smaller portion. Didn't have time to wait, so passed. Annoyed they didn't wait a sec to ensure we were gone before tossing my stuff. Appreciated the quick resolution, though.

"Hark! Good sirs and madams, gather 'round,
And heed my words of wisdom, proffered with haste.
A place of wonder, a cinema of renown,
Where films are shown, and tales are told with grace.

The prices, fair and reasonable, doth please,
$10 for adults, on Friday and Saturday eves.
For matinees, the cost doth drop, to $8,
A bargain, indeed, for those who do arrive early.

But wait, there's more! A special deal, for thee,
Who doth desire to save a few coins, with glee.
Combo deals, at the concession stand, doth abound,
And discounts, for students and seniors, are found.

So, sign up now, for the Cinemark email,
And receive coupons, of which thou shalt not fail.
And, lo! On Mondays to Fridays, before the sun doth set,
Seniors, doth pay but $4, a sum most frugal, I reckon.

Thus, hasten thee well, to this theatre of delight,
Where movies doth play, and fun doth take flight."

"A wondrous abode, with space enough to spare,
The staff, kind-hearted, did our needs prepare.
We chose the North tower, as wise men do,
For updates fresh, our stay to make anew.
A minor blemish, paint peeled from the bath,
But elsewise, joy did our hearts engage.
Our time there, pleasant, we would not part,
And thither, again, our steps would move with haste."

"Hark! To rate Stoney's N40 aright,
Two sides must thou consider in sight,
The saloon, where food doth reign supreme,
And club, where dance and music do gleam.
A smoke-free place, a virtue indeed,
That sets it apart, a crown to proceed.
I've dined at many a place, my friend,
Famous Dave's, Mesquite BBQ, Dickie's, Lucile's,
But Stoney's, with its service so fine,
Doth rival them all, a gem divine.
Their food, a feast for the taste buds,
Substitutions, no problem, they'll budge.
Weekly, we dine there, a treat for us,
For those who don't enjoy, alas, what fuss!
But, alack! The club, a different tale,
Lacks the luster, the charm that doth prevail.
Revolver, nearby, doth steal the show,
With Stoney's, a mix of genres, they do know.
Country hats, flat bills, young and old,
A diverse crowd, but not as bold.
Gaming machines, a solution, perchance,
To draw in more, a better chance.
Then, mayhap, they shall turn anew,
Back to their roots, a country bar, anew."

"A place with too much variety on the menu raises suspicions. Can they truly excel at everything? Doubts lingered as we ordered alfredo pasta, burgers, carne asada burritos, and cheesecake.

Burgers, cooked to order, impressed. Rare to well-done, they nailed it. Medium-rare for me, medium for my companion. Frozen beef patty, perhaps, but flavorful toppings made up for it. Fried egg and sautÃ©ed mushrooms elevated the burger.

Crisp veggies, soft bun, and salty fries pleased. Ketchup complemented them nicely. Dill pickle, a delightful surprise. Fruit punch, however, lacked oomph. Watered down, it seemed. Recommendation: drinks without ice, add when ready.

Iced coffee, standard, yet satisfying. Quick delivery, a plus.

In conclusion, extensive menu, average burger and fries. Delivery, fairly priced and prompt."

"Tasty grub and a swell joint. Got a table in the bar, no fuss, no muss. No gluten-free options, but they whipped up something nice. Looking forward to seeing what's new on the menu next time. Highly recommend, but call ahead or get there early."

"A feast most wondrous, with dishes galore,  
Didst please my palate, and left me wanting more.  
The cost, alas, didst climb to lofty heights,  
Yet, for such victuals, 'twas a fair price to pay.  
I shall return, with hunger pangs anew,  
To savor more of this most delectable brew."
"Aria's got a fresh joint, real swell grub, and atmosphere to boot. Been there a few times, always a stylish crowd, top-notch service. John Venegas, he's my man, go say hi."

"Hark! A cheese pizza didst I have today,
And verily, 'twas a feast for mine eyes.
The victuals and service, both were of high degree,
A place most worthy of thine culinary cravings, an it please thee.
The salads, too, didst delight mine taste buds,
And swiftly came the server, with nary a pause or fuss.
Aye, 'tis a place to dine, when thou dost seek
A meal of merit, and a pleasant time to speak."

"Verily, 'twas a merry night, indeed! This place, Kazba, doth beckon with its lively atmosphere and warm reception. Methinks, the folk here be friendly and welcoming, eager to share their revelry with strangers. I chanced upon this place, seeking diversion on a Friday eve, and found myself swept up in the mirth.

"The interior, though compact, did teem with people, making it quite warm within. Yet, the heat did not deter my enjoyment, for I found solace at the bar, whereupon I requested a surprise concoction from the bartender. He, in his haste, did present me with a refreshing elixir, Electric Lemonade by name, most delectable!

"As I waited, engaged in sprightly banter with those nearby, I noticed not the delay, for the bartender did attend to his duties with diligence. And lo, upon my invitation, I did join a group of merrymakers on the balcony, reserved for a private gathering, partaking in the finest spirits, Grey Goose and Red Bull, plentiful and free.

"Huzzah! To Kazba, and all who dwell within, for providing a most excellent experience, replete with conviviality, fine music, and potent potables. May this night be remembered, and may future visits be forthcoming!"

"Marry, what a wondrous sight doth lie before mine eyes!
The players, with their skills so fine and fair,
Do conjure up a show most magical and bright.
I could not follow every twist and turn of tale,
But grasped the gist of it, in general, well enough.
The plot, alack, doth not the reason make,
For one to witness this most wondrous play.
In conclusion, 'twas an evening most delightful,
And one I shall not soon forget, by my troth."

"A hidden gem, this place, on north side of town,
Gives Swingers' vibe, with drinks of island renown.
Mix of cocktails, with names so bright,
And games of chance, for those who dare to fight.
Funky jukebox plays tunes of old,
But don't expect free drinks, unless you're bold.
Seats in back or at bar, are best, I say,
For tables in center, are not the way.
Bartenders friendly, service quick,
I look forward to my next trick."

"Fare: marvelous, a feast most fair and fine,  
With bone-in rib eye, a cut divine.  
Price: alack, 'tis true, yet still I say,  
In Vegas, worth the cost, come what may.  
Ambiance: pleasant, not too much ado,  
Service: waiters, staff, most courteous, too.  
Overall: mark my words, a steak most prime,  
If premium fare be thy desire, 'tis thine."

"A hidden gem, this sushi place, away from prying eyes,
All-you-can-eat, for a fixed price, a veritable surprise.
I, a man of discerning taste, with an appetite quite vast,
Do justice to the menu, and leave not a single morsel past.

The catch of the day, be it salmon or tuna,
Fresh as the morning dew, and just as succulent,
Tempura, a delicacy, fried to a golden hue,
Satisfies my craving, and leaves me feeling anew.

Uni and amaebi, a treat for the refined,
One dish per person, a rule to keep in mind.
Toro, a rare delight, when in season,
A flavor so exquisite, worth every single reason.

Verily, a place to return, when in this fair town,
For the sushi, a feast, and the service, a crown."

"Methinks we had a most enjoyable time at yonder Summerlin place,
The staff were pleasant, and the surroundings didst grace,
A right merry eve we didst have, save for one small thing,
The barbecued shrimp, alas! didst not please our king.

Four medium shrimp, overcooked and hard as stone,
Didst lie upon the plate, a sorry sight alone,
The rice, too, didst lack the flavor that doth bring,
A proper sauce, to make the dish worth a king's ring.

Oh, how I wish they had used large shrimp, in shell,
And rethought the sauce, to make it more swell,
